 Six Winchester youths are under investigation by the' police department in connection with the yin d ali. stic destruction on August 1 of an eight-by-six-foot cinder block pump house at Leonard Beach Field .
 The boys’ identity was discovered as a result of special investigations by Officers Cogan and Roy . The boys were found in the early hours of the morning .
 Six hoys admit damaging the pump house in Winchester . Investigation uncovered they were members of a no longer secret organization . The group comprises a total of 23 Winchester youths .
 Police discovered a membership list at the Leonard Pool Bathhouse which the youths were using as a club house during the night hours . The names of all of these youths are known to police, who discovered the membership list .
 A 1 ] -year-old Stoncham youth and a W inchester juvenile wen arraigned in Woburn District Court Thursday, Sept. 13 . The police investigation resulted — Two Youths Found Guilty In Auto Battery Larceny A 1 . year-old youth and
 The Stoncham youth was found guilty of receiving the stolen property . The Whester youth was also convicted of the larceny itself . The youth was convicted of receiving stolen property and receiving it .
 Both were sentenced by Justice William Henchey to one year’s probation from a complaint of the Park Department two weeks ago that the lock on the bathhouse was tampered with .
 It was discovered, Chief Derro said, that the youths had used the club house for card games, in direct violation of park department rules . Park rules prohibit the playing of cards on park property .
 As a result of the boys using it, the bathhouse will have to be repainted and repaired at an estimated cost of $60 .
 Chief Derro said that from this point on the parks will be under stricter supervision . Anyone apprehended playing cards on park property will face court action .

 A Visit From Ned The Star had one of its pleasant visits yesterday from an old friend, Ned Crawford, of Williamsvillc, Vt., where he acts as chauffeur and general handy man for Sumner McCall, son of the late war time Governor of Massachusetts .
 He has served the McCall family for 57 years, going to work for the then Congressman McCall, later Governor, when he completed grammar school . He has been with the family of the late Gov. McCall since his birth .
 In those days he drove the Congressman and his family in their horse-drawn carriage .

 He is presently chief accountant and office manager at the Lynn Hospital . He is currently chief accountant at the hospital .
 His appointment further strengthens this department and frees the dietitians for further development of our patient food service .

 The art classes of Winchester, Winchester, are gathering for their first meetings at their various studios with fine teachers and varied emphases . Winchester's Studio Guild's First Meeting will be held at the studios of Winchester .
 Some are for children, some adults, some for women, others for both sexes . Others are for both adults and children . Some for children are for adults .
 Studio Guild lays special emphasis on the friendly, informal atmosphere, the lack of well-defined rules, and especially the encouragement to draw or paint the thing in which you are interested in the way you see it .
 This results in definitely personal pictures, in various media and in realistic semi-abstract, or completely abstract styles as the artist sees the subject .
 The director of this group, William Grady, gives intensely, personal criticism to each member of the group . The group is based in New York City .
 Occasionally he gives a short talk on some subject of general interest . He also gives talks on some subjects of interest .
 He confines himself to his criticisms of each individual picture . But for the most part he confines himself . He listened to and profited by all the other amateur artists .
 Plans for the year were discussed at length with many suggestions and criticisms from the twenty members present at the meeting .
 Discussion of figure painting and portraiture were considered and left to be decided in the future . Discussion was left to decide on the future of the project .
 Members were asked to bring all paintings done during the summer, so that the walls could present a gay and interesting sight . Members of the club were invited to bring paintings done in the summer .
 Members were also asked to bring objects for still life studies . Not handsome bowls and Japanese figurines but old rusty objects from the cellar or rusty bits of wood .

 West had “unusual no trump” written on his card and figured that here was the time to use it . West had "unusual trump" written in his card .

 Miss Mabel Laurinda Vinton, 81, died early Friday morning, Sept., at the Emery Nursing Home in West Medford, after a long illness . Vinton was a lifelong resident of Winchester .
 She attended Winchester schools and was graduated from RadclifTe College in the class of 1902 . She attended the Winchester schools .
 She lived with her parents until their deaths . She attended Ida Ida School in Newton, after which she lived with them .
 She then built a smaller house on Fairview Terrace where she lived with Mrs. Edmonds . She then moved on to a smaller home in which she later lived with her husband .
 Miss Vinton was an honorary member of the Fortnightly Woman’s Club . She was also a member of Winchester Historical Society and a former member of Women's Republican Club .
 She was one of the older members of the First Congregational Church, which her father served as deacon and in other capacities during his lifetime . Her father was a deacon at the church .
 She was also a member of the Mission Union of that church, which she took an active part in her earlier years .

 Winchester’s representative in the ( ireat and ( ieneral Court, Harrison C. hadwick, was not elected House leader of the Republican minority in last week's election on Beacon Hill . Harrison C hadwick was elected to the House of Representatives .
 We believe that Mr Chadwick has many of the attributes necessary to do an effective job in this important post . We believe he has the attributes needed to do a good job .
 Mr Chadwick sees the need for stronger, more cohesive action on the part of his colleagues on Beacon Hill . For the sake of a strong bi-partisan approach to State problems we can sincerely hope he will go as far as he can .
 Mr Chadwick, we believe, would have put his best effort into forging the Republicans in the House into the real opposition party they should he in a two-party government .
 This is not to say that under Mr Chadwick’s leadership the (r.O.U. in the House would opj>ose all legislation proposed by the Democratic majority . This is . not to . say .
 Mr Chadwick has said publicly that his party should support the Democratic leadership in effecting good legislation .
 The Republican minority should stoutly oppose any and all attempts of the Democrats to pass legislation which Republicans consider not in the public interest, he says .
 Republican members of the House should make known their opposition to what they conceive to be bad legislation, says Chadwick .
 The Star believes there are many in Massachusetts who arc far from pleased with the way things have been going at the State Mouse .
 Massachusetts politics is viewed askance, not only by many residents of the State but elsewhere through the* nation . Massachusetts politics are viewed as askance by many .
 Recent exposes of graft and corruption in our body politic arouses resentment among those who cherish honesty in government . This resentment can well result in a shifting of party lines, says Dr. Andrew Hammond .
 Independent voters and conceivably many within the Democratic ranks would welcome the opportunity to align themselves with the party that stands four-square for honesty in government .
 Convince people that any party stands for these principles in government and they will flock to its standard . Convince them that any Party stands for such principles and it will attract voters . Convincince them to stand for such a party and they'll flock to their standard .
 Mr Chadwick hoped, if elected House minority leader, to get the G.O.Fk on Beacon Hill to, as he says, ‘change direction”
 Its opposition to past excesses has been something less than vigorous . Its voice raised against legislation believed to be bad has been far from clarionion . It has not been as vigorous as it has been in opposition to the past .
 Chadwick did not get backing in quarters where he had every reason to believe he would receive strong support . "Uncomprising refusal to make deals and promises in advance of election mav" contributed to his defeat .
 Political resentments for which he could not be. held responsible also probably counted heavily in the balance . Political . resentments . also probably count heavily in balance .
 For himself, Mr Chadwick likely has no particular regret over his defeat . For himself he is likely to have no particular regrets over the defeat .
 The present rote of the Republican House leader on Beacon Hill is not likely to be a happy one . House Speaker John Boehner is expected to lead the GOP in the next few years .
 Mr Chadwick sought the minority leadership because he felt he could contribute in this post to the revitalizing of his party and could also effectively assist his neighbor Governor Volpc, in his plans to improve his plans .
 His past record in the General Court bespeaks his effectiveness in office . He has been in office for more than 30 years .
 He has lost the chance to bring these talents to the assistance of his party on Beacon Hill . He has also lost the opportunity to help his party in the Senate .
 Chadwick wishes for a strong and articulate Republican minority in the House . Perhaps he shares the Chadwick wish for a Republican minority .
 If so, he will have Mr Chadwick’s active support in his effort to affect this change, he says .
 Mr Chadwick has said he will assist the new leadership in any program that is in the public interest .
 Police Chief Derro, together with other friends of the town’s youth, is becoming increasingly concerned over the drinking that seems to be more and more evident among our young people . Police chief Derro and other friends are concerned over drinking .
 It is useless to say that such drinking does not exist and it surely serves no useful purpose to ignore it . It is not a good idea to ignore such drinking, it is a bad idea to say it doesn't exist .
 Boys and girls in their teens should not be drinking for their own physical and mental welfare . It's important to not drink too much for your own physical, mental health .
 Anything that can be done to curtail youthful drinking is entirely worth while, says CNN.com.com .
 Chief Derro is of the opinion that one of the most effective ways to cut down or eliminate youthful drinking is through the parents . He says parents are the key to cutting down or eliminating youthful drinking .
 Many parents have no idea that their youthful son or daughter is a party to juvenile drinking . He is probably right when says that many parents don't know that their children are drinking too much .
 Chief Derro is quite sure most people do not know most of them do not . How they can avoid knowing is hard to understand, perhaps, perhaps . But Derro says most people don't know what happened .
 Boys and girls in their teens would have had a hard time getting home from a liquor party without parental knowledge and subsequent parental action . In what are usually referred to as “the gocxl old days’’
 Cief Derro is trying to secure the cooperation of parents in an effort to curb youthful drinking . Derro's men are notifying parents when they have knowledge of youthful drinking parties in which their children have been involved .
 It is the Chief’s belief that most effective progress in combatting youthful drinking can be made by the cooperative effort of parents and police, rather than in merely punitive action on the part of the authorities .
 Chief said it is too soon to say how his plan is working . Asked by the Star how it is working, Chief replied it is 'too soon'
 This is discouraging to the Police who feel they are giving the parents of youthful offenders a break in the hope that they will appreciate the opportunity to assist the authorities in stamping out youthful drinking in town .
 The Police of course can make mistakes, both in the identification of youthful drinkers and in their method of approaching problems involving them .
 Parents urged to report to the Chief any action of his men which they consider to have been improper . Failure to cooperate because of this is not the proper reaction for parents, says the Chief .
 A frank discussion will clear the air and result in improved understanding on both sides of the debate .
 Town members are now asking the cooperation of town parents in their effort to do something constructive about teen age drinking . These members of the town council are concerned about teen drinking .
 It would seem that their effort should have the hacking, especially parents, but also of all who are worried over the spread of this deplorable practice . The hacking is not the first time parents have been hacked, but it's a good start .
 The Star has met no one who has not applauded your action in making a group of hoys clean up the mess they had made on the Common .
 Getting rakes from the dire Station and putting the hoys to work immediately was a most effective way to bring home to them the consequences of a careless act while the evidence was there for all to see .
 The town likes to have its Common clean and was asking your future cooperation in keeping it that way . Beyond that he was reminding you that the town likes the town clean . He was also asking you to help keep it clean .
 In the three centuries since the founding of the colonies of Plymouth and Massachusetts Bay, local government in Massachusetts has evolved from a simple, informal structure to a complex set of institutions reflecting a vast and intricate urban industrial civilization .
 The number of municipalities has expanded from 27 in 1640, with a population of but a few thousand, to .351 communities in 1060 embracing 5. million inhabitants .
 Originally the responsibilities of these municipalities were limited to support of a church and school, poor relief, roads, military defense, the suppression of crime and the collection of taxes . The responsibilities of the municipalities are limited to supporting a church, school and poor relief .
 Now they encompass a wide range of public services, social programs and public works . Now they include social programs, social services, and public services .
 Legally, local government originated in the commercially oriented royal charters authorizing the establishment of the Plymouth and Massachusetts Bay Colonies . Legal Origins of Local Government: Local Government . Local government originated legally in the colonies .
 The charter of the colony was granted by King Charles I in 1628 . The charter provided for a colonial government consisting of a Governor, a Deputy Governor and 18 Assistants .
 The first local governments were established by the settlers without prior authorization by the General Court . They were developed without significant legislative oversight for many years .
 In part, local government institutions reflected innovations by the colonists, and in part they borrowed from the administrative practices of the Puritan Church and English local government .
 The election of committees of “select men’s” to manage administrative matters was a natural product of English love of committee government . Thus, the election of committee members was the birth of the committee system .
 Dorchester institutions were regularized in Dorchester in 163. and spread swiftly throughout the Colony . Dorchester was first established in 1881 .
 In the beginning, the General Court was content to legislate only on major policy questions affecting localities . In the past, the court was only legislating only on minor policy questions .
 The isolation of many towns, the difficulties of travel, and the preoccupation of the central government with commercial, religious and military problems limited the control of the General Court over local governments, limited the local spirit of independence .
 The General Court enacted the first General statute of local government establishing central control over the activities of these frontier communities . Two years later the General Court . enacted the . first General Statute of Local Government establishing central . control over . activities of frontier communities.
 In the next half century the General Court increased its control of the towns, especially the Town of Boston, despite the ‘home rule” sentiment manifested on several occasions .
 The Town of Sudbury defied the General Court when it intervened in their quarrel with their clergyman, who was attempting to dictate town policy in non-ecclesiastical matters . The freemen of Watertown refused to pay a 1632 assessment by the Colonial government .
 In 1688-1680, Lynn and other towns resisted efforts of the dictatorial royal Governor, Sir Edmund Andros, to impose heavy property and excise taxes .
 The overthrow of Governor Andros enhanced the ‘rights of Englishmen’, but did not halt the trend to greater central control of local government .
 The General Court required towns in 1692-94 to submit their by-laws to the judiciary for approval . It also empowered justices of the peace to convene town meetings if the Selectmen refused .
 Of these six forms the towns enjoyed far greater autonomy than the latter units of government, all of which were to disappear by the mid-nineteenth century . All of these six types of government were abolished by the end of the century .
 County governments were first created in 1643, with the organization of the four counties of Essex, Middlesex, “Old” Norfolk (partitioned in 1680) and Suffolk . County governments of Essex and Middlesex were created .
 County government responsibilities then, as now, were largely related to the maintenance of county courts . County courts, probate courts, registries of deeds, jails and houses of corrections, and county roads . County roads, jails, and roads were largely maintained by county government .
 This multiplication of counties reflected the need for judicial services beyond the capacity of most individual towns . The counties were created in response to a shortage of judicial services in many towns .
 Many interpreted the Declaration of Independence to mean that the central government had been abolished . Localities advanced various theories of inherent municipal rights as a basis for almost complete independence of central government . Many interpretations of Declaration meant that central government was abolished .
 These theories were accepted by the General Court for a brief five years . During that period, the court was more a convention of local ambassadors than a legislature .
 Local autonomy was encouraged by the disruption of central authority during the siege of Boston, and by the preoccupation of the succeeding revolutionary government with general military and economic problems . Local autonomy further encouraged by disruption of the central authority .
 The need ror a stable central government for Massachusetts was soon apparent, and resulted in the Constitution of 1780 . Reestablishment of the state authority was established in 1780.
 This document established a powerful bicameral General Court consisting of a Senate of 40 members elected from as many legislatively determined districts, and a House of Representatives consisting of one to three representatives per town depending on the number of voters therein .
 The General Court restored to the General Court in almost the same language the legislative power it had possessed under the Massachusetts Bay Charters of 1628 and 1691 .
 With this restored power in hand, the General Court reasserted its control over t*he localities .
 Legal requirements effecting town administration were strengthened by the General Court . The General Court also strengthened the requirements of town administration .
 Some local autonomy existed when the Eighteenth Century ended . Some of this autonomy existed in the 16th century .
 In the nineteenth century the Industrial Revolution brought economic and social changes which tremendously strained the political institutions inherited from a slower moving agricultural past . In the 19th century the social and economic changes were the result of the revolution .
 The inability of the municipalities alone to deal with these changes, the demand for more state action, and judicial review by the courts all combined to subordinate the communities fully to the General Court . The communities are no longer able to handle these changes .
 Massachusetts lost 79 per cent of its territory when Maine was admitted to the Union under the Missouri Compromise of 1820 . The state’s population rose nearly sevenfold from not quite ahalf million in 1800 to 2. million in 1900 .
 Textile and shoe mills sprang up along the rivers of the state often resulting in great political stresses between the mill and agricultural populations of the towns . The mills often resulted in political tensions between the mills and the agricultural population .
 In the Great Depression of 1929 many of these densely settled mill towns, with their small territory, became municipalities of questionable viability when the mill closed .
 The growth of the state’s railroad network after 1826, and especially after 1860, spurred the evolution of metropolitan areas surrounding Boston, Worcester and Springfield .
 Many foreign born laborers poured into the central cities to work in the mills and industries . The process hastened as many foreign born labor poured in to the cities .
 In 1957 Vance Packard wrote “The Hidden Persuaders,’’ He warned that, depth psychology is being used to make us buy products and politicians we neither need nor rationally want .
 The psychologist’s cynical appeal to our subconscious hope and fear to sell us beauty in soap, status in cars, and security in T V.-deep statesmen . He exposed the psychologist's cynical appeal .
 Dichter, bibliography blazing, replies to anyone who implies that he is less than a prime agent of human progress .
 "It's just his culture that makes him that way. That is to say he’s not nasty," he says . "That is to . say he's not nasty; it's just that his culture makes him . that way"
 He discovers what actually motivates people, in choosing a wife, a whiskey, or a cake of soap . First, he discovers what motivates him to choose a wife .
 Second, he remotivates them toward more desirable goals that effect self-fulfillment, he says . Third, he re-directs them to more desirable targets that are more desirable, he adds .
 He knows that you tend to equate weight with quality, silk with sex, and slogans with truth . He also knows that silk is sex with sex and that slogans are truth .
 Step Two is not to move on Step Two, but to correct or re-direct your motives . Step Three is to correct your motives, but it's not to change your mind, it's to correct it .
 His actual concern is to exploit the motives he has discovered, to determine the most effective way to make you buy what his client wishes to sell, be that a smooth margarine spread, or a smoother Presidential candidate .
 Depth psychology is here used to manipulate man, to freeze him in un-reason, to capitalize on his fears and insecurity . Depth psychology was intended by Freud and responsible psychologists to liberate men from the tyranny of the irrational subconscious .
 Dichter, as a good Viennese, is still troubled by Judeo-Christian morals to feel the need to rationalize his nasty business in ideological terms .
 It is clear that our friend is inordinately more concerned with the fortunes of floor wax than with those of freedom . But when all of this is said, it's clear that .
 In the “psycho-economic” struggle, anything goes as long as the product is sold, even that old huckster trick of letting people keep their illusions so long as they do things, or buy things, your way . In the "psycho" struggle,
 Dichter’s book, moreover, is itself a masterpiece of not-so-hidden persuasion . The book, however, is about to be published in Germany on Sunday .
 The author is too brilliant, too much aware of aspect, however, to hide even his worst thought . The novel is a masterpiece, but the author is also aware of its darker aspect .
 Even as he affirms a theory of moral therapy, his book makes it clear that his main interest is to exploit moral sickness . The book, with abundant detail, makes the point that moral therapy is necessary, he says .
 He placates traditional moralists even as he delights his colleagues in manipulation . That is to say. That's to say he placates moralists, but also placates his colleagues .
 He publishes generous and telling quotations from the works of his harshest critics to indicate that he has read them and disproved them . But he fails utterly to deal with these criticisms, he says . Similarly, he publishes generous quotations from his critics .
 As a disciple of Freud, he knows full well that what he is doing is scientifically irresponsible and morally sick . He knows full . well well that . what he does is scientifically . irresponsible and moral sick .
 What he is doing, therefore, is only less appalling than the fact that he is entirely aware of it . What is less appalling is the fact he is aware of his actions, he says. What he's doing is more appalling than what he's aware of .
 In a man of civility knowledge is power, hut it is also responsibility . In the world of politics, knowledge is also power, says David Cameron . In this case, he says, "knowledge is power"
 Dichter says his toughest problem seems to be to persuade himself that what he is doing is morally tolerable . He says he has to convince himself that it is morally acceptable .
 When all arguments are heard, one still shrinks from casting the first stone . And when all arguments have been heard, the one still grows from casting stone .
 In a sense, the brutal candor of a Dichter is preferable to the moral hypocrisy of those who evade basic illness by prating about symptoms . "In a sense of a . sense, it is preferable" to the . moral hypocrisy .

 Ronel ’s Toy Department Open Friday Evening 23 25 Thompson Street PA 9-1708 ways in which law' enforcement can be improved and the influence outside the police ranks that affect luw enforcement efforts .
 The chiefs urged the active personal interest of members in the objectives the Association has set for itself . The Association has been in a hit of soul searching .
 The Association strongly recommended that its members give the widest possible dissemination of the Association’s recommendations so that people may know for what the chiefs are working and assist their elforts .
 Law enforcement education is considered of great importance by the Police Chiefs . It enables law enforcement agencies to provide greater and improved service to their individual communities and the over-all enforcement system .
 Chiefs expressed their appreciation to the FBI for its continued assistance in polieje training . The Chiefs urged all members of the Association to avail themselves of the opportunity to get for its personnel the instruction being* offered at the various FBI training* schools .
 The Chiefs call upon all lawabiding citizens together w’ith the press, radio and television to join in a community effort to support the rights of society and support law enforcement .
 Chiefs found that the life of a nation rests in part on the strength of its families . Children through this family strength develop respect for their parents, which reflects itself in a sense of community responsibility .
 The Chiefs emphasized the grave responsibility resting with parents to concern themselves with the activities and interests of their children . The Chiefs said parents must guide their children in the path of good citizenship .
 Chiefs found that good gov eminent and good law enforcement require respect for the agencies that create and interpret the law, the legislature and the judiciary . The Chiefs say good govt. eminent and law enforcement need to respect the agencies behind the law .
 The chiefs agreed that while those in law enforcement work may well differ from judicial decisions . This lack of agreement in no way diminishes their respect for the authority of the decisions .
 The Chiefs saluted Director J Edgar Hoover, dean of law enforcement, for his lifetime of service and sacrifice to our nation .
 The Chiefs came out strongly for uniform legislation authorizing law enforcement officers to carry firearms in states other than those where they are employed . Officers should be able to carry guns in states where they're employed only on official duty .
 The Chiefs will ask the International Association of Chiefs of Police to prepare a uniform code . The code will be presented to the law enforcement association in each state of the United States for adoption .
 Present laws of the individual states permit law officers to carry firearms within their borders to protect themselves and their communities against law violators . Present laws allow law officers in the U.S. to carry guns in their communities .
 They do not however provide uniform authority to empower such officers to carry firearms between states .
 The Police Chiefs feel strongly that the absence of such authority seriously challenges the safety, legal position and lawful responsibility of such officers . Police Chiefs say absence of authority is a serious risk to the safety of officers .
 Chiefs want uniformity in compensation for players and coaches . More uniformity of compensation is another matter over which the Chiefs are concerned .
 They feel that such a lack of uniformity handicaps the recruiting of competent personnel for law enforcement work . They feel such a problem is recruiting competent personnel . They say the uniformity of law enforcement is a problem .
 Police service is becoming much more complicated, less strong arm man-handling and more science . The Chief believe that their Association should set as its goal minimum compensation for police chiefs of $7,500 and $5,500 for patrolmen . Police service requires young, energetic and competent
 Chiefs consider reasonable amounts reasonable in view of existing conditions . Chiefs consider it reasonable to pay for existing conditions such as medical conditions .
 The Chiefs went on record’ as whole heartedly endorsing the objectives of the Jimmy Fund, and to further its support appointed a committee of one member from each state in the Association to coordinate its activities and efforts .

 Larson was born in Isle of Wight, Virginia . She was the daughter of Rev. Rev. and Mrs. Mrs. Larson .
 Larson served on the Medford School Committee, studied law, and was admitted to the Massachusetts Bar in 1946 and the Bar of the United States Supreme Court in 1960 . Larson served as a Medford school committee member .
 As an active Republican, she served nearly twenty years on the Republican City Committee of Medford . She now is a member of the Winchester Republican Town Committee .
 She was recently appointed to the Legislative Committee of the Massachusetts Association of Women Lawyers .
 She is on the executive board of the Massachusetts Association of Trial Lawyers and is co-chairman of their Public Relations Committee . She is also co-chairs of the Middlesex County Bar Association and is Executive Secretary of their grievance committee .

 This old house was not the original Hutchinson mansion which stood adjacent to it . The Hutchinson mansion was not. the original . Hutchinson mansion . It was located in Hutchinson, Arkansas .
 Remains of the cellar and granite work of the older structure were visible for many years . There was at one time a family burying ground on the property . The property was once a burying ground .

 All shops, workshops, stores, warehouses, places where persons do any kind of business or work must be closed on the above dates . January 1 May 30th July 4th Labor Day Oct. 11 Thanksgiving Christmas .
 The provisions relating to the observance of such a holiday shall apply to the following day . When any of the legal holidays fall on Sunday the provisions relating . to the . observance, such a Sunday, shall apply . The following day will be the same day .
 Public offices must be closed but places of business may he open for business on those days . Places of business must also be closed for those days, not public offices .

 Members are either mothers or grandmothers of twins . Regular monthly meetings are held on the last Monday of each month at the Robbins Library Arlington .
 Stowe and his wife, Virginia Ware Stowe, were serving in North China under the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Mis sions in late 1948 when the Com munists seized power in that region .
 The Stowes refused to leave, insisting that this was an opportunity to demonstrate their Christian faith . Though they had two young children, they refused to let them leave .
 They stuck to their posts until the summer of 1950 when a serious health problem and the outbreak of the Korean War made it imperative that they return to this country . The Korean War ended in 1950 .
 While in China the Stowes did evangelistic and student work in Tientsin counseling and training Chinese students and pastors for intelligent and courageous leadership .
 Stowe has served as secretary of the Commission on Theology of Mission of the World t’ounil of Churches and the International Missionary Council . Stowe is a member of the Council on Missionary Missions .
 The 25 member international commission is composed of leading theologians >f many Protestant and Orthodox denominations . The commission is made up of 25 members of the world's most prominent theologians .
 Before going to China he served for two years as associate minister of the First Congregational Church of Berkeley .

 The Women’s Auxiliary of the Middlesex East Medical Society opened the new season with a very pleasant meeting September 28 at the Country Club in Winchester .
 Professor John Lerch was introduced by the President of Mrs Henry Magno . Professor Lerch introduced by Mrs Magno at the end of the meeting .
 Professor Lerch is the professor of Radio and Television at Boston Uni versity . He presented a fascinating and, at times, amusing tape recording of excerpts from radio programs starting as far as 1925 .
 At any rate, the sampling he did present was enough to make all of us wish there were more to hear . At any . rate, it was enough for us to wish for more .
 This “nostalgic excursion into the past” included such sounds as a pianist of the early ‘20’s playing a very tinny “3 o'clock in the Morning”, the C-liquot Club Orchestra, Dr
 Mr Lerch feels that radio suffered a decline after the war, hut that the quality of programs is now improving with the advent of stereophonic sound . Lerch says that radio suffers a decline .
 Many people Agreed with his statement that radio offered the listener the opportunity to use his imagination while television lacks that necessary ingredient . Many people agreed with him that television lacks the necessary ingredient of imagination .

 A lovely lady from Boston's past named “Tessie” is being introduced this fall as the living symbol of the Greater Boston United Fund “People Helping People"" campaign .
 Her initial appearance this fall was at Fenway Park Tuesday (September 26) before the Red Sox game with the Chicago White Sox . Her first public appearance was in Boston on September 26, 2013 .

 Tessie will make appearances at all United Fund functions and will represent the Fund at public events throughout the campaign . Tessie is a member of the United Fund and will appear at all public events .
 On November 3 she will visit each of the 49 cities and towns in the Greater Boston area participating in the campaign . She will help kick off the Fund’s residential and small business campaign .

 The report is being distributed by the League to all Massachusetts legislators on both state and national levels, to state government agencies, to local government heads, to college and university heads .
 The only comprehensive document on the Mass. personnel system, aims to tell the average citizen what he is entitled to expect of a merit system and administration ures up to thoi .
 Past League study of several state government services has repeatedly pointed up the fact that the people who administer the service are the real key to its success or failure .
 Massachusetts League members in 1959 elected to study the ‘people’ in government service, the public personnel system itself . Members of the Massachusetts League were convicted of corruption in 1959 .
 Organization and Administration of the Public Personnel Agency; Civil Service Coverage; Recruitment for the PublicService; Selection; Selection and Compensation; and Career Development in the Merit System . The Public Service Agency is responsible for the public service .
 The final chapter of the report is "Recommendations for Improving the Commonwealth’s Personnel Program" The report brings together suggestions and proposals from other interested groups and individuals .
 Local League groups will be discussing the findings during the coming year with the purpose of arriving at their own recommendations for change . Local league groups will discuss the findings in coming year .

 Free admission to films and private views, a free illustrated calendar of events, discounts at the museum sales desk and reduced class fees . Few people realize that, for a very modest sum, they get a lot of benefits, including free admission .

 Cardinal Presents Marine Band His Eminence Richard Cardinal Cushing is bringing the famed United States Marine Band to Boston . The band will play at the Donnelly Memorial Theatre in aid of Cushing's charities .
 The band, which appears anywhere only by special approval of the President of the United States, will play two concerts in Boston, one at 2:30 in the afternoon, and the other at 8:30 the evening .
 The United States Marine Band came to Winchester some years ago, presenting a concert of outstanding excellence in the Town Hall under the auspices of Winchester Rotary . The Marine Band was presented a concert in the town hall . The band was awarded a gold medal for their outstanding performance .
 The band will perform in Boston on October 15 .

 A New Orleans matron found the idea “insulting” adding that she’d rather have an unnamed hurricane hit her house than one reminiscent of one of her hushed hand’s old flames .
 For the lady’s comfort, let us say that the controversial business of naming hurricanes appears to have no connection whatever with the war between the sexes . For the ladies, it appears to be a matter of business .

 Art Mills and Bob Joslin won the New England Junior Veterans’ Doubles Championship over Hill Powers and Henri Salaun Sunday at the W eston Golf Club . Mills and Joslin beat Powers and Salaun 2-6, 6-1,6-4 .
 Local pair came from behind to upset Powers and Salaun, who were top-seeds in the draw . The pair were heavily favored to win the coveted title . The local pair were in a tense struggle to win .
 Joslin yielded only one point in his two service games, but could not find the court with his overhead . Hills' serve was exploited by the eventual losers to achieve a double break through of Hills’ serve for the set . Hills won the first set in the second set, but
 The champions rallied their resources and attacked without let-up breaking Powers’ serve twice and controlling play at the net throughout . At this point, the champions rallied and attacked .
 Salaun held his service game for his team's lone game in the set . Salaun was badgered through three deuces, but held his serve game for the win .
 Hills was cracked on a perfect lobvolley by Hills after a fast exchange with all four players at net . Jalaun Jalaun sol ved for a 1-0 lead in the decisive third set . Joslin served another love game and Powers cracked a lob lob on a lobvol
 Hills held serve, as his overhead, which was the last word, thundered two over the fence and flushed two golfers out' of the rough on the adjacent course . Hills won the tournament by two shots .
 Salaun’s turn to serve and his fate was sealed as the winners returned low and set themselves up for winning volleys at the net . Once again it was Salaun's turn, it was his turn, and the win was sealed .
 A volleying lapse by Joslin and nn untakable return of serve by Powers gave the losers their only service break of Joslin in the sixth game of the match .
 Hills and Joslin held their own serves for the win in the tenth game . Hills hit a volley to the backhand corner which Powers could not handle . Joslin and Hills were unable to break their opponents serves again .
 Hills and Joslin reached a goal which had twice before eluded them in the final round . Hills won the New England title by reaching a goal that had twice failed to elude them in a final round of matches .
 Salaun rarely has known defeat, making the victory particularly sweet . And to win over their arch tormentor and such a fine player as Salaun, made the victory especially sweet .

 Norma Porraa of 11 Hutchinson Road, is among a group of sixty practicing pharmacists enrolled in the second annual Postgraduate Seminar program offered by the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy .
 The program includes a series of eight lectures given on Tuesday evenings from September 26th through November 14th . The lectures will be held at the University of Cambridge, Cambridge .
 The 1961 Seminar features a basic review of organic chemistry with discussions of organic nomenclature, reactions of functional groups, isomerism, and the relationship of chemical structure to physiologic activity . The seminar was held in 1961 in New York .
 Associate Professor Joseph D Mutthes and assistant professor Ronald N Du vail of the Department of Chemistry are lecturers for the extensive review course .

 Each succeeding generation is becoming loftier than the one that preceded it, says CNN.com's John Sutter.com .
 Today, men who are six feet tall and women who are 5 feet 7 inches are commonplace . 20 years ago, only 10 per cent grew to those heights, compared with 20 per cent of men .

 Why We Are Concerned? Ask us why we are so concerned over the anti-social activities of our young people . Why We are concerned about the young people?
 W e e do not agree that young people of today arc just the same as they were years ago . W e does not believe that today's young people are just as young people as they are now .
 The conditions under which they now grow tip. the multiplicity of influences to which they are exposed would almost guarantee that boys and girls with a twist of . that direction will get into trouble, almost without trying .
 The young people of even twenty-five years ago had no such temptations as those existing for their modern prototypes . "Young people of  25 years ago" had no temptations such as those of today's young people," says author .
 As for the hoys and girls of the ‘horse and buggy’ era ; it was so much harder to get into trouble in their time . The hoys were able to get away from trouble in the 'horses and buggy era .
 It is useless to deny it. and an ostrich-like ignoring of the problem only aids and abets it . Winchester has its fair share of juvenile delinquency .
 "Having them grow up in the right way is not only important to them but vital to the country," says President Obama . Having children grow up is vital to them, says Obama .
 Winchester's boys and girls are all right . Fortunately, the vast majority of Winchester's children are fine . Winchester is home to the Winchester Museum of Remembrance .
 "The trouble they get into is negligible and prompted by no vicious motives," the author says . "They get into trouble with no vicious motive," he adds . "It's a good thing for the world to see," he says .
 There is beginning to form in town a little hard corps of youngsters whose activities can be called neither thoughtless nor mischievous . There is, however, commencing to form a . hard corps .
 The Star feels that such activities should be brought to the attention of our townspeople, especially to those who seem to believe our Winchester boys and girls can do no wrong . The Star also feels that those who believe Winchester boys can do nothing wrong should be aware .
 "We feel that it is our duty as the town newspaper to convince them that they can," says the town paper . We feel it is their duty as a newspaper to . convince them they can .
 We also feel it is our duty to point out that it is high time the authorities adopt a much stronger attitude in dealing with these young marauders . We urge the authorities to adopt a stronger attitude to dealing with them .
 The police have been patient and long suffering in their treatment of them . The Star's way of thinking their leniency has not paid off, and to the Star’s way, it's not paying off .
 It seems definitely time to clamp down, and bring home to the error of their ways . The young wrongdoers should be brought home to see what they did wrong .

 Early in the nineteenth century, it became evident that the town meeting system could not function properly in Boston and certain other large towns . City government was established in 1903 in Boston .
 A city form of government was not possible since the State Constitution required election of state officers at public meetings of town inhabitants . A city government would not have been possible in the state of 18th century .
 The number of cities increased to nine by 1850, 21 by 1875 and to 33 by 1000 by 1000 .
 In 1857, voters adopted a constitutional amendment which weakened the relative political power of the towns . Weakening of Town Political Power was the result of the constitutional amendment .
 This amendment replaced election by individual towns of one or more members of the House of Representatives with election of such members from representative districts established decennially by the General Court .
 Many smaller towns lost intimate contact with legislative developments . Legislators were encouraged to think of themselves more as state officials than municipal representatives .
 The Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts repudiated local theories of inherent local rights . The court confined the activities of Massachusetts communities to those specifically authorized or reasonably implicit in statutory authorizations .
 In the first decade of the nineteenth century, the Court declared in Bangs Snow and Dillingham Snow that parish governments had no powers except those granted by the Legislature . The Legislature could not redraw parish boundaries without local consent .
 Continued claims by towns to ‘inherent rights’ compelled the Court to adjust judicial policy accordingly . Town claims to “inherent right’s’ have been upheld by the Court .
 The General Court rapidly extended its control over numerous details of local government, especially where Boston and other large communities were concerned . Fortified by these judicial decisions, the General Court expanded its control .
 In the present century, the general constitutional status of the municipalities has not changed fundamentally . In the past century, municipalities have not changed significantly .
 The State Constitutional Convention of 1917 rejected eight proposals for a constitutional municipal home rule amendment . The General Court in subsequent sittings as a constitutional convention has also rejected the proposals .
 A constitutional amendment adopted in 1926 authorized the General Court to establish “limited” or “representative” town meeting governments in towns exceeding 6,000 in population . A majority of the local voters in the town can petition the court for their approval, subject to their later
 The few local efforts made to overturn special statutes on the basis of ‘inherent rights” were systematically rejected by the Supreme Judicial Court . The few . efforts to overturn . special . statutes were systematically . rejected .
 New forms of town government have been authorized in extensive general and special legislation passed since 1914 .
 The development was most pronounced in 1914-1915 when statutes were passed authorizing town manager governments, representative town meetings, and other town provisions, as indicated below . The development most pronounced was the passage of laws authorizing the town manager government .
 Special legislation was enacted in 1914 which permitted the Town of Norwood to establish a town manager form of government . Norwood was the first town to have its own town manager .
 This statute provides for a town manager who is responsible to the board of selectmen for the administration of town departments . Some of the heads of such departments had previously been elected .
 The status of the town meeting and of the school committee were continued without substantial change . Town meeting and school committee meetings were continued .
 The General Court has enacted no standard official official town manager charter law . Mansfield Stoughton Middleborough Middleborough Saugus Ipswich Danvers Wilmington Arlington Holden Amherst Provincetown Shrewsbury Randolph Concord Williamstown Andover .
 Towns have drafted special legislative proposals which have varied from local conditions, needs and political viewpoints . Instead of legislative proposals, towns have drafted their own special proposals .
 The reluctance of growing towns to change to city status motivated the “limited” or “representative” town meeting system of 1915 . Town meeting system was created in 1915 .
 In contrast to traditional “open town meetings which include all registered voters, “limited” town meetings consist of town meeting representatives elected from districts or precincts, and certain general town officers elected at large . Selectmen, who serve as ex officiis members of the town meeting
 Between 1915 and 1960 a total of 41 towns obtained representative town meeting statutes . The statutes were passed between 1915 and 1959 .
 Legal doubts about this type of statute were removed by Constitutional Amendment in 1926 (Art. Constitution) in 1926 .

 The LWV Unit discussion groups on U.S. Relations with Latin America held October 17th through October 19th . Discusses Relations With Latin America .
 Two students from Latin America presented informal background material at the LWV General Meeting October 11 as an introduction to an intensive exploration of the subject at the Units .
 History of past relations of the U.S. with La.America . Present attempts to establish closer cooperation among the countries of this hemisphere .
 President Kennedy’s ‘Alliance for Progress’ plan will be explained and analyzed, as well as more general topics such as the interdependence of the countries involved . The present political climate of Latin America will be discussed .
 The format of this series of Units will be a panel of members of the Foreign Policy Committee, with emphasis upon audience-participation .

 The construction cost of the Motor Hotel was $2,000,000 and is to be operated by the Cambridge Motor Inn Incorporated . The Motor Hotel will be located in Cambridge, Massachusetts .
 Herbert Clark attended Winchester High in 1959 and 1900 . He has been with the Nordblom Company for the past three years as head of the Motel-Hotel brokerage division . Clark attends 27 Cross Street .
 Mr Clark is one of the few brokers in the New England Area that has specialized in the sale of Motels and Hotels and in the selection of sites for new hotels .

 R 12, 1061 Opportunities To Be Aired A t Colleges . High school students in the Ros. ton suburbs will learn about opportunities at colleges outside the east .
 Twelve small, coeducational liberal arts colleges in six midwestem states are hiring the presidents and admissions directors of twelve small colleges . The colleges are located in six states .
 The colleges are seeking to broaden the geographic base of their enrollments . They are interested in well-qualified IochI students . The colleges, members of the Midwest College Council, are looking to broaden their geography .
 All presidents anti admissions officers wilt be available after each session for consultations with college-bound high school students and their parents . Parents and students are invited to the meetings from public and private schools throughout the area .
 The conferences will be conducted with the cooperation of local guidance counselors . Local guidance counselors will attend afternoon sessions planned for them at Lexington and Wellesley .
 Arrangements for the Wellesley session were made last spring at a meeting arranged by Samuel M Graves, principal of Wellesley Senior High .
 Mr Graves formerly taught and was interim principal at Winchester High School . Mr Graves has been at the school for more than 20 years .
 Lexington session arranged through Charles J Johnson principal of the school and Frederick Thurlow, assistant principal in charge of the guidance program . The Lexington session was arranged by Charles J. Johnson principal .
 Lexington High expects to draw its largest audience from schools in Concord, Winchester, Reading, Bedford, Bedford and Woburn . Lexington High also expects to attract students from other schools .
 Schools farther to the north are also counted on to send a number of their children . Schools farther north also count on sending children to schools .
 The theme for the conference, “New Horizons in College Selection” reflects its purpose of the conference . The conference is to have secondary school students and their parents take a fresh look at college options .
 Council says students can learn about colleges they now know little about but which may offer more than some familiar to them . This they can do, the Council points out, by learning about colleges that may be less familiar with them .
 The conference idea has been welcomed enthusiastically by many New England school officials . New England schools are coping with an unprecendented demand for admission by college .
 Many colleges have found their past efforts to interest students in western and southern colleges meeting with little success because there is little appreciation here of the excellence of many colleges in other parts of the country .
 The counselors are supporting the Council’s program in the hope of helping even their top-grade students avoid the disappointment many are likely to suffer by applying only to oversubscribed eastern colleges .
 Eastern colleges and universities actively recruit students in many states, including those in the midwest . Ripon College president: Eastern colleges actively recruit .
 The Council is coordinating the efforts of its members to bring about a better balance, he said .
 We feel the conferences also perform a useful service for the schools and school families’s families”, he said .

 "Tom" is missing his work with the harriers this fall even more than he thought possible . It was with real regret that popular ‘Tom’ handed in his cross country portfolio, for he has always loved the sport .
 A graduate of Medford High School, ‘Tom’ participated in track and cross country at high school . “Tom” participated in cross country and track and track .
 He went to Norwich, which at that time had no cross country team, and participated in wrestling and football at the Northfield military college . He also played football and wrestled at the college .
 He had to leave college and go to work, later enrolling at Burdett College . He was forced to quit college and enroll in college at the age of 18 .
 After his graduation from Burdett he worked as an accountant for Lever Brothers . He decided he wanted to teach and left business to accept a teaching position at Suffield Academy .
 At Suffield he coached varsity track, wrestling and golf and also coached football in the junior school . He also coached high school football .
 He left to accept a position as principal of Plainville Junior-Senior High School . He coached basketball and cross country, introducing the latter sport to school .
 From Plainville, he went to Bryant & Stratton and from that post, to Winchester . Winchester, Connecticut, was the last place he was at .

 The College Club Art Group will hold its first Museum meeting at the He Cordova Museum of Art in Lincoln, on Friday morning, October 20 .
 Those who have visited this unique museum in previous years will )ook forward to this trip . For those who have never been there, a rich experience is in store for those .
 There is no museum more beautifully located high on a hill, overlooking the lake, and surrounded by autumn foliage at the time of year .
 Inside there is also an exciting feast for the eyes; for the large exhibition of paintings owned by Mr and Mrs. Mrs. Artworks .
 Those are paintings of real significance, which have been ac claimed by all reviewers as one of the outstanding exhibitions of the season .
 The pictures represent the steady stream of art from the early Impressionists, such as Mo net and Renior, down through the European Abstract Expressionists .
 Members of the College Club Art Group can't afford to miss this opportunity of seeing these paintings and hearing Miss Jane Miller of the De Cordova staff talk about them . Miss Miller will talk about the paintings .
 There are several ways to get to Bedford Road from Arlington to Lincoln . Follow Pleasant Street in Arlington to Route 2; on Route 2, go toward Lincoln for about 7 miles . Bedford Road is about seven miles from Lincoln .
 At another sign turn right on Sandy Pond Road and go a short distance to the Museum . Go to the museum at the end of this article .

 The plans include the Addison Gallery in Andover on Nov. and the Boston Museum of Fine Arts on Dec. Dec. and equally interesting trips each month through April .
 One week before each trip, those who have enrolled as members will receive notices . There will also be articles in The Star with information about the exhibitions .

 This week’s picture is of the old Hawes Brothers livery stable that stood years ago on what later was a part of old Manchester Field after the cleanup and improvement campaign instituted by the late Forrest C Manchester . This week's picture in the Star's Remember When series is of
 The stable stood beside the Al>erjona River adjacent to what is now Waterfield Road, roughly across the street from the present Post Office . It was located across the riverbank across the road from the post office .
 The P Waldmyer Tannery was built in the 1930s . The tall chimney of the chimney shows in the picture . Sharing the lot with it with it was the P WaldMYER Tannery .
 The tannery was situated beside the old Boston and Lowell, later the Boston & Maine Railroad . A spur track led from the main line to service the tannery . It was used to run a tannery in the area .
 Cutting Street was running beside the water down toward the present Cutting Street which leads off Manchester Road . The other side of the river from the stable was Cutting Street, running along the river . Cutting Street is now Cutting Street .
 A railroad freight yard was located beyond the Blanchard yard . Still later a railroad freight railyard was located .
 The balustrade showing in the picture is on the bridge over the river, which branched at Waterfield Road and went around the stable before rejoining the main stream south of the building .
 The owners of the livery stable, Ilawes Brothers, were Reuben C Hawes and Daniel Webster Hawes . The owners are Reuben and Daniel . Webster .
 The latter was for many years in the express business in Winches ter and the small building to the light of the stable was his express office . The former express office was the office of his express business .
 Reuben moved over to Glen Road to the big house on the left hand side of the Road at the bend, near Glen Green . The two brothers finally dissolv ed their partnership and moved over . Reuben's house is now on Glen Road, near the bend of Glen Green
 At the rear of his house he built another livery stable which he ran for a time . He also ran a stable at the back of his home .
 Webster, or “Web,” as he was familiarly known, joined with Dan iel Kelley in the firm of Kelley and Hawes . Webster was known for many years undertak ers and operators of a livery and express business .
 The two partners, both bearded, were familiar figures on the streets of Winchester for many years . They were both tall and spare and the other short and sturdy . The two men were known for their bearded, spare and sturdy figures .

 It is said that cities are remembered by their streets, and if a street is known far and wide then the city is the city . It is also said that if a city is remembered by its streets, it is the best city .
 Streets are famous for other reasons, too, too; sometimes it is an individual . Sometimes it is a character of fiction. Sometimes it's an individual; in one case, at least, a character .

 The Charles Playhouse opened its fifth season this week . Eugene O’Neill’s “The Great God Brown” lost to the Charles playhouse .
 The Charles had the talent, but O’Neill had obscurity, and in the theater the first inevitably bows to the last . "The Charles" is a classic classic, but the last will be a classic .
 Young actors like Dora Landey, Mitch Ryan, and Bronia Stefan are unable to provide first-rate theater . If you are hard put to determine why competent young actors like Landey and Mitch Ryan are unable, you’ve forgotten your early O’Neill .
 Young people staging one of O'Neill's most tiresome and heavy-handed plays, awash in a sea of contrived symbolism, pseudo-classicism, and one-a-minute messages . But these bright young people are staging .

 Joe Moffett retired as active chief of the Winchester Auxiliary Police . The occasion was in recognition of his retirement from active chief . Moffett is a retired police officer .
 He has been actively connected with this organization since the critical days before World War II . He has given unstintingly of his time and money to make it the finest unit of its type in the state .
 When Joe took the office of auxiliary chief back in ’58 his steps made a more positive stride in the direction of fulfilling his fondest dream, that the auxiliary force would be second to none . The auxiliary force is now a strength force in the United States .
 At this time Joe can sit back and watch with pride and confidence as the unit progresses in the capable hands of our new auxiliary chief, Fred Wier .
 To you, Joe Moffett, every man extends his heartfelt thanks and will strive to earn your future respect and guidance . "To you, I will always be proud of you," Moffett said .

 Civil Defense Agency, Natick will present the Shelter and Home Preparedness Course . The course includes films, models of shelters, samples of foods, and other articles necessary for survival .

 The tenth annual Waltz Evening sponsored by the Friends of the Winchester Hospital was held at the Winchester Town Hall on Friday and Saturday evenings, October 13 and 14 .
 Waltz Evening proved to be a tremendous success . Manning C Morrill, this year’s chairman, said the event was a huge success . Waltz evening was held in New York City, New York .
 Proceeds from the dance are always Used by the Friends for gifts to the Winchester Hospital . Proceeds are always used to give gifts to Winchester Hospital.
 Town Hall was transformed by a hardworking committee into a scene of medieval beauty . The Town Hall is transformed into a medieval beauty by a committee .
 Flags with heraldic crests lined the balconies of the hotel . Every wall depicted parapets and battlements of ancient castles . The hotel was built in the 1930s .
 Sammy Eisen's orchestra provided music throughout the evening for the dancers . One wall contained a mural of knights jousting in tournament, and the stage was flanked by twin figure* of heralds blowing beautiful trumpets .
 Special lighting fixtures of gold which reproduced those found in King Arthur's court added a final footnote of beauty .
 On each table, the name of host and hostess were indicated by placards with Old English let tering .
 Attractive flower girls wearing tall wimpled hats mingled with the guests during the evening selling corsages with lucky num hers attached . Attractive flowers were selling lucky nums at the event .
 Serving as judges were Mr Richard Champagne of the Champagne School of Dancing . Mr and Mrs. Champagne were also judges .

 Each billion dollars of increase in Federal spending represents $19 to the average American family of four . The Tax Foundation finds that each billion dollar increase in federal spending is $19 .
 It ranges above and below that amount in individual communities, in relation to income levels .
 A $1 billion spending increase takes money that each family could have used to buy an electric toaster or five LP records, report says .
 A $2 billion increase would take the amount that they might have used to purchase clock radios or power tools sets . A $1 billion increase could take that amount away from what they might use to buy clocks radios or tools .
 If a firm went into business at the time Christ was bom and proceeded to lose $1,000 every day from that time on, it would not yet have lost a billion dollars . The firm would not have gone into business in Christ's time if it lost $1k a day

 Speaking on the topic “Broadcasting 1961 he made his listeners aware of the problem faced by a broadcaster in trying to satisfy the broadest pos sible segment of the listening public .
 In the early days, his own station was run by the plant manager and the office boy in their after-work hours . Mr O’Friel amused his audience by relating to the fact that in the early . days, he said .
 As the popularity of ra dio grew, the necessity for assigned broadcasting frequencies became more and more evident . Ra dio has been assigned frequencies for more than 30 years .
 The pro blem was how to make best use of the new medium and still not al low it to be completely under gov ernment cotrol .
 In the best American democratic tradition, the answer evolved was freedom under licensing . "Freedom under licensing" was the answer to the question .
 Broadcasting reaches more people, at their own invitation, than has any other means of communication in history . This solution has worked so well that today broadcasting reaches more than any other method of communication . Today broadcasting is the only way to reach more people than other methods of communication.
 The speaker went on to say that the public must exercise its right of choice in order to make this mass medium effective . The speaker said that the people must exercise their right to choose the mass medium .
 It is not necessary to qtrengtben gov. eminent control to achieve desired programming . The competitive ele ment of the industry works toward the same end .
 The broadcaster must learn to know and trust the public, reach a rapport with it, then give it a good blend of the type of programs it wants even if this includes rock and roll .
 Radio has a unique role to fill in the instantaneous report ing of ""local news" Apart from its entertainment function, radio has a role in filling in the instantaneously report ing .
 Lightweight portable, electronic equipment to day makes timely presentation of the news a fact of life . Lightweight . equipment makes timely . presentation of . the . news a . fact of . life .
 Mr O’Friel touched on the com plex problems that need to be translated in order that the public may see, hear, and understand .
 He stressed that radio and television must be put into proper perspective as mirrors of our present day society . He said radio and TV must be placed in proper perspective .
 Mr O’Friel concluded by emphasizing that the viewer is needed by the broadcaster to bring in the new era which can come . The new era of public enlightenment, education, and improvement can come, he said .

 We are not attempting to convey the impression that a newspaper exists solely for the altruistic purpose of serving the public . We're not trying to convey that a paper exists solely to serve the public, we say .

 Hut your worth while publisher, your publisher who turns out a paper worthy of the name is primarily concerned with truth, both in his news ami his advertising . Hut .
 I le demands objectivity in reporting, honesty in his advertising. lie has his problems. I le demand objectivity and honesty in reporting. lie. lie .
 The hours that go into reporting, editing and the mechanical end of publication are part of the reason this bit of news or a certain advertisement gets in and others do not .
 Often with the best will in the world the publisher is unable to do either what he, or his correspondent or advertiser wishes .
 Ask yourself the next time you are riled with the editor or publisher of your home town paper what it would be like without one . Ask yourself: What would it be like to be without one?

 Minister Storer in a recent sermon dealing with the threat of nuclear war made a statement it seems to the Star to be worth emphasizing . Storer, minister of the Unitarian Church, made the statement .
 Instead of accepting the belief that war and human destruction are inevitable, we should devote our minds and energies toward the building of a world in which there is no need to hide from the holocaust we should build places to hide .
 In this thought lies the only hope for a continuation of the civilization man has built for himself. In this hope, he says, "In this thought, we have a chance to continue our civilization"
 If he as master of so much can not master himself can not outlaw the mass murder that goes under the name of war, then everything he has accomplished through the ages is as nothing and man will end as he began .
 We shudder as we look back on the excesses of the barbarians, on the scourge of Attila and his Huns and the conquests of Alexander . We shudder when we recall Attila's excesses .
 Nearer home we recall the Nazis of Hitler, the war into which they plunged the world 'and the gas chamber murders, concentration camps, woe and destruction they worked upon mankind. Nearer . mankind'
 The worst of the horrors of all time would pale into insignificance in the face of the total destruction that will come to 11 s all in an atomic war . If man forgets he has risen above the beasts and is a rational human being, he will be destroyed .
 The time is at hand when we must not forget what nuclear warfare means, says David Cameron . "If we do, we will have nothing left to remember," he says .

 The petition asks that the people of Plymouth be given the right to vote at the .next state election on whether to continue with the limited town meeting form of government, or return to the old open form .
 Selectman who voted against the proposal says there should be some assurance of public support of a town wide vote, such as a petition, before asking legislative action . Selectman says he does not oppose the people's right to say what sort of government they want .
 Plymouth has had the limited town meeting form of government for nine years . Plymouth has been limited to limited town meetings for 9 years . Town meeting form has been used in the past nine years in Plymouth .
 Town did not adopt it because of a lack of room for all citizens to attend, but because of voter apathy . Voter apathy resulted in limited town meetings that were not representative of the entire town . It did not. like most towns, adopt it .
 Two recent referenda set aside precinct delegates’ votes on a school bond issue and the proposal to build a parking lot . pponents of limited town meeting claim that the precinct delegate’s decisions do not represent the feeling of the entire town on vital matters .
 The petition to the General Court is being vigorously opposed by the Plymouth League of W omen Voters, an organization the local branch of which has strongly supported the limited form of town meeting in Winchester .
 Winchester precinct delegates don't always reflect the thinking of the precincts they represent at town meetings, says Winchester resident . "There are those in this town who have never felt that the Winchester delegates truly reflect the thoughts of our precincts," she says .
 Town-wide votes have set aside those of the limited town meeting . This is especially true of controversial matters, and they can point to referenda, in which referenda have been held .
 Changes have been made in our town meeting referenda clause that will make it more difficult for dissenters to set aside limited town meeting votes . Changes have made it much more difficult .
 Three per cent of the electorates now required to invoke referendum . Only a majority vote of those casting ballots is necessary to sustain a town meeting vote . Unless the total vote in a referendum equals 20 per cent, no action may be set aside .
 Only 30 per cent of the electorate took the trouble to vote for changes to the town meeting act . These changes were sustained in a townwide referendum in which only 30 per per cent voted .
 To be sure there were very few times when there were not room for all to get in who wanted to, but there were a few such times . There were few times there were such times. To be .
 Limited town meeting votes may not be representative of the entire town, opponents say . But they probably are no less so than those of the old open form when it was possible to pack a meeting to put over a given project .
 It's done now, under the representative town meeting form, but in a different way . It is done now . It will be done now under the . representative town meetings form, . But in a . different way, it will be a different . way .
 Only a drastic reduction in town meeting members at large and an unusually fortunate selection of precinct delegates can obviate votes arranged in advance of meetings . Town meeting members are at large .
 After all it is the same procedure as that under which our state and national governments function. After all, the same procedures are used by the same government as those of the UK .

 This form has failed to win favor in the past, but it lias a lot more advocates than the city form . The city form is a form of form that has been used in the U.S. for decades .

 Zoning regulations require larger and larger lots for private homes . Many believe that for economic reasons more and more apartment or group houses will be built .
 There is in some quarters in Winchester strong opposition to apartment houses of any kind and in any dumber . Winchester residents are opposed to apartments being built .
 The Star is sure no one wants to see Winchester even approach the status of an apartment house town . But there are also those who would like to six mure apartment or group house facilities here .
 The I 'landing Board' made an unsuccessful attempt recently to open the way for apartment houses under townwide control . They proposed the establishment of apartment house zones at the pleasure of the town meeting .
 Under this plan any one wanting to build an apartment or group house outside the business district must first get the town to change the zoning map to establish the proposed site of the building as an apartment bouse zone .
 Under the present zoning a prospective builder of an apartment house outside the business zone must have the site changed to a business district . The site must be changed to the business district in order to be built .
 The land remains zoned for business and open to the owner or other purchaser for business use . The land will remain open to business use, but the construction of apartment houses will increase .

 These errors have their source in our subconscious and are induced by repressed memory, feeling, and intention, he says . These errors are caused by repress memories, feeling and intention .
 A A Brill, this paperback deals brilliantly with such widespread ‘errors’ as forgetting to mail letters, to losing one’s wedding hand . The paperback is published by A. A Brill .
 Freud tells us that people forget names because they are associated, however indirectly, with an unpleasant experience or fear . Freud says names are associated with unpleasant experiences .
 You might forget the name of a man named “Carroll,” because a girl named ‘Carol’ once did you dirt . For example, a man called Carroll once called a woman named "Carol" because she was a girl called Carol .
 You may forget the name of a man bearing the same name as your potential rival . Similarly, you may “forget’t the name’s” of a potential rival. You may also forget the names of a rival in the same way .
 The act of “forgetting’s” prevents the awakening of pain through memory or anticipation . “Forgetting” is a form of avoiding pain through anticipation or memory .
 Freud: Mistakes in speech, or “slips of the tongue,” are not accidental . They are unintended confessions of our inner thoughts and attitudes, Freud says .
 Freud reveals his subconscious wish that he were Dr. Virchow . “I wish that I could be Dr. Virchow,” he says .
 In each case the so-called “error” reveals the person’s true concern or intention . The error reveals the true intentions of the person involved in each case .
 We were giving a dinner party for two very dear friends who were about to leave for Mexico . We were hosting a dinner for friends about to go to Mexico .
 After dinner the conversation got around to the comparative quality of American and Mexican fabrics . After dinner, the conversation was about the quality of fabrics in both countries .
 Wife asked her friend to pick up a certain amount of fabric in Mexico City or Guatemala . She was impressed by the fabric .
 Our friend, who is a psychologist, burst into a gorgeous laughter in which all of us joined . Our friend burst into laughter, which all joined .
 We prefer the conservative and she the more vivid patterns and hues . We recognized immediately that the “slip of the tongue” revealed a wide difference in taste .
 We also make mistakes in reading and writing that reveal our motives and concerns, such as our own motives .
 A woman desperate to have children will read storks for stocks in her financial column . She'll read stork for stocks as she tries to get pregnant .
 Freud says the fact that such errors are not accidental is not the special discovery of the psychologist . Freud says such errors not accidental, Freud says, is not a special discovery he made .
