 John William Thornton of 1 Indian Hill Road, for thirty-five years a resident of Winchester, died Sunday afternoon, October 15, at the Winchester Hospital where he had been readmitted, recently . He had been at the end of more than twelve years of heart disease .
 Mr Thornton was the son of William N and Annie Thornton, both natives of Leeds . He was born to Annie Thornton and William N. Thornton .
 He was born in East Boston, February 10, 1886 . beginning his education there and at the Boston Latin School . He was also educated in Boston .
 Mr Thornton was associated with the John A Frye Shoe Co., of Marlboro, for thirtyeight years before his retirement in 1948 as a result of illhess. During a long, active life in the shoe trade, Mr Thornton lived in Marlborough, England .
 He was Secretary-Treasurer of the Boston Shoe Associates for 25 years . He was regarded with respect within the shoe industry .
 He was a dedicated member of the Church of the Epiphany where he served on the vestry . He was also a member of a vestry at the church where he was a member .
 After ten years of singing as tenor soloist in the King's Chapel male choir, he continued his interest in church music at the Epiphany Church .
 In addition to his activities in music, Mr Thornton maintained interest in the Masonic Orders . Mr Thornton was a member of the Masonic Order .
 In 1914 Mr Thornton married Winifred A Harrington, also of East Boston, by whom he is survived .
 Funeral services were held Tuesday afternoon at the church of the Epiphany with the Reverend Mr Ralph B Putney, B.D., officiating .

 Bill, of course, is terribly successful, which is to say evil, owner of a thriving architectural firm . Bill is a terribly successful architect, but he is also evil .

 Cybel is a conventional good-hearted, rough-hewn whore, who, down deep, is still seeking true love . His only relief, save making a drunken ass of himself blaming every one for his failure, seems to be in the boudoir of one Cybel .
 Cybel possesses in large measure that special divinity dispensed by O’Neill to drunks and derelicts . This trite little plot is made “classic” and “complex” through the introduction of masks, slapped on and off .
 Billy Brown, fed up with Dion's charges that he’s palming off his drawings as his own, does Dion in . He steals his mask, takes his wife without her guessing the difference and is shot for the murder of himself .

 Belmont Hill Youth Hockey program will commence Dec. this year and continue through Feb. 2019 . Sessions will be held each Saturday morning at the Belmont Hills School artificial rink .
 To be eligible a boy must have been seven years old Aug. 1961, 1961, and under 15 as of Nov. 1961 . A boy must be seven-years-old .
 If conditions necessitate those directing the program reserve the right to decline applications . If conditions require such a change, the program could be turned down .
 The program will definitely be limited in size which means that applications will be received on a first-come first-serve basis . The program is expected to be a limited program .
 Application blanks may be secured at the Sport Shop and should be filled out and mailed at once with a check for $16 to cover ice cost and accident insurance . Application blank blankes should be sent to the Sports Shop with a $16 check .

 If present plans follow in order, construction should begin in early spring and be completed in a year from next month .
 The $500,000 enterprise will serve ice hockey, figure skating, pleasure skating and exhibition needs of the area . It is to be located on North Avenue, olf Route 128, in Wakefield, Wakefield .

 This is Miss Murray’s first year of teaching, though she practice taught at the Lincoln School in the fall of 1960 . W* Photo by Ryereoii
 Born in Winthrop, Miss Murray moved to Melrose as a girl . Graduated from the Academy of Our Lady of Nazareth in Wakefield .
 She holds the degree of Bachelor of Science in Education, which she received in June from the Massachusetts College of Art .

 The New Enghind football officials organization is now in process of selecting a high school coach in Eastern Massachusetts for its third annual Memorial Award . Seek High School Coach of Year .
 This coach will be selected for maintaining the high ethical standards demanded of the football coaching professions . The coach is devoted to teaching the game of American football to boys so that they become men of true American sportsmanship .
 Any fan, player, coach or official may submit a letter nominating any high school coach of hus choice . The winner of the award will be announced at a local high school .
 Neither victories nor losses nor the division in which your selection is classified will affect the choice of your selection . The choice will not affect the winner's selection .
 Jan Kozlowski is the president of the N E. football officials organization . Submit all letters as soon as possible .
 The award will be made at the officials annual banquet Monday evening, Nov., at the Hotel New Brunswick in Boston .

 He might well ask why so many Christians who claim this do not agree on the meaning of the Scriptures .
 Christ, of course, wrote nothing, excepting on one occasion — and then only in dust . Christ wrote nothing in the Bible, except for dust .
 The Bible itself does not claim to be the Inspired and complete word of God . The Bible is not the Bible itself .
 The answer is, of course, that the only living authority is the Catholic Church . The Apostolic Church is the Church whose traditions, beginning with Peter, begin with Peter .
 Clement of Alexandria was a secondcentury writer of Alexandria . It can present the testimony of such secondcentury writers as Clement of . Alexandria, Egypt, as well .
 Irenaeus, Tertullian and Origen; and from the third and fourth centuries Cyprian and Ambrose and Eusebius and Cyril, and many others . .
 "All these bear witness to the vital importance of the Apostolic tradition," says Pope Francis . Pope Francis is a member of the apostolic family .
 The Catholic Church was preaching the Gospel of Christ years before the last book of the Bible was written . It was 1,500 years before its writings were combined into a single book .
 Free pamphlet gives a brief but dramatic story in the words of the fourth-century historian, Eusebius . If you want convincing proof to support your Christian convictions, write today .

 Conservatory, the Pacific Theological Seminary in Berkeley, Calif., and the Gloucester School of the Little Theatre .
 Chidley was a pioneer in obtaining suffrage for women . She was active in the movement ten years before suffrage was granted . She fought for the right to vote for women in England .
 She served as president of the Winchester Women’s Suffrage Association . She was on the executive board of the Massachusetts Women's Suffragist Association .
 When women's suffrage was granted, she was appointed to the Massachusetts Republican State Committee . She organized the party’s women's activities in the 16th Middlesex District .
 She supervised a study of living costs in Massachusetts, preparing a brochure on this subject .
 Schlesinger of Harvard and Bloomfield of the Boston Chamber of Commerce. Schlesingers of Harvard . Bloomfield: "It's been a great year for Boston. It's a great time for us to learn how to live with the world."
 In 1917 she was assigned to the Fort Devens base hospi tal as a Red Cross medical worker in which she served for two years . She served as a medical worker .
 After the war, as the 26th Division returned she was appointed as a casualty officer . She was appointed in which capacity she was able to learn facts about men of the division .
 She was assigned to a closed ward of shell-shocked patients at the U.S. Army Hospital in West Roxbury, Massachusetts . She worked with patients in two open wards in an open ward .
 She also served as a medical social worker at the Chelsea Naval Hospital . She also worked at the hospital where she was a social worker .
 In 1909, following a rigid test on the narrowest streets of Boston, she became the first Winchester woman to get an automobile license . She has held the license continuously ever since, with no accident decided against her .
 In view of the fact that she has driven 500,000 miles, this is rather a record . "This is rather than a record," she says of her car .
 She is an aficionado of horseback riding and kept her own saddle horse for many years . She is also a fan of keeping a saddle horse in her saddle for many more years .
 In addition, she was runner-up for three years in the women’s tennis championship of the Winchester Country Club .
 For two years she played on the third women’s golf club team at the Country Club, playing matches in surrounding towns . She played for two years at the club, playing in towns around the country .
 Howard J Chidley, pastor-emeritus of the First Con, has over 1,000 rug sizes from sizes 1.6'x2.6" to 14.6''x30' Heavily decorated, heaps of new, used, antique and semi antique
 She took over the duties of homo maker and mother to her two step daughters, Elizabeth and Barbara Chidley . Mon. through Kri., 8 A.M. to 8 A.'M. — Sat, 8 noon 8 gregational Church of Winchester .
 She was commissioner of the Winchester Girl Scouts for two years . She founded The Parish Players, 35-year-old church drama group . She was vice president of the Women’s Republican Party .
 She was able to utilize her medical social worker’s training helping the pastor in aiding people who needed assistance . She also organized the Social Workers’ Advisory Committee .
 During her thirty years as wife of the First Congregational Church pastor, Mrs. Mrs. Smith was married to the pastor of the church .
 Chidley entertained constantly, giving yearly teas to the new women of the parish . He entertained the choir, Sunday School teachers, the deacons and church committees and their wives .
 Chidley’s retirement from the pastorate in 1953, devoted herself to looking after many of the needy cases of the church and became active in New England theatre work .
 She was a founding member of the New England Theatre Conference . She served as chapman of the Community Theatre Division of that organization for six years .
 She served as chairman of the special projects division for two years and vice president for three years . She also served as vice president of the organization . She served in the organization as chairman, vice president and chairman .
 She is a former member of the Executive Board of the Massachusetts Council of Churches . She is also a former Executive Board Executive Board member .
 She is a member of the United World Federalists . She was appointed alternate delegate to the Stockholm Convention in 1954 . She is also a U.S. Federalist .
 She is also a member of the Atlantic Union, the United Nations Association, the English Speaking Union, and the American National Theatre and Academy .
 Chidley has traveled extensively in this country and Europe and has also visited Mexico, Alaska, and Latin America . He has also traveled in Europe and Mexico, and has visited Mexico and Alaska .
 Elder's father was senior counsel for the U.S. in Newfoundland Fisheries arbitration with Great Britain . She spent four months at the Hague in Holland, when her father, Samuel J Elder, was a senior counsel in the Newfoundland fisheries arbitration .
 Chidley’s interest in international relations stems, she believes, from this engrossing experience . Chidleys’ interest in diplomacy stems from this experience .
 It has taken her over the Atlantic, by sea and air, eighteen times . It is the first time she has been in the Atlantic by air and sea .
 Her friends have very much enjoyed the illustrated talks based on these travels . Her friends also enjoy the illustrated books based on her travels .
 Chidley has indeed lived an interesting life, in the Winchester tradition of community service . He has lived a fascinating life in Winchester, Winchester .
 Her friends congratulate her on her honour and wish her all the best in the coming years . Her friends also wish her best wishes for the coming year .

 William W Davies III, opera chairman of the Boston Vassar Club, has arranged today’s preview of the new opera “Command Performance” that will have its World premiere in November . The opera is scheduled for November .
 The pre-view is being presented at the Midtown Motel, Boston, for Vassar Alumnae and friends . The composer at the piano, accompanying a few of the soloists, is the librettist and producer .
 The opera is based on a charming bit of Elizabethan adventure and intrigue, involving the plight of a young musician sent to Turkey with an elaborate organ for the sultan . The queen dispatched the musician to Turkey to provide an organ for Sultan Sultan .
 The sultan accepted both with such verve that the young man had quite a time escaping . He had to make his way back to England to report to the queen .
 The composition of this opera was made possible by an anonymous donor as a tribute to VassalCollege on the occasion of its centennial year .
 First choice of seats for opening night, Friday, Nov., at Kresge Auditorium in Cambridge, will he available to, and through, Vassar Alumnae for one week following today’s pre-view, before becoming available to the general public . The
 Chamberlain Windows were dedicated to the Unitarian Church in the Michelsen Room last Sunday .
 These are a gift of Mr Edward H Chamberlain in memory of his wife, Grace Caverly Chamberlain, who died last February . The gifts were presented to Mr Chamberlain in his honour by his wife .
 The windows will serve as a background for the worship center of the children of the first, second and third grades . The windows are expected to be used as a backdrop for the children's worship center .
 The eighteen window panes depict the brightness of the universe and tell the story of the wonderful works of God . The eighteen windows depict the bright light of the world .
 The sun, the moon, the planets and the planets, the stars, the birds of the air, the flowers of the field, the animals of the forest and the fish of the sea are represented in lovely color .
 These window panes are arranged in a design that permits the outside scene to come through . These window windows are arranged to allow the outside to see the outside .
 A quotation from the writings of Joseph Addison is used as a memorial legend . A quote from Addison's writings is used in a memorial story .
 The firm of Wilbur Burnham and Wilbur H Burnham, Jr., of Boston, designed these beautiful windows .
 Mr Burnham and his son also designed the windows in Meyer Chapel and the windows devoted to the theme of the Red Cross in the Cloister . The windows were placed in memory of Dawn Bartlett Kelley .
 The public is cordially invited to ' visit the church and see the Burni ham windows'

 Sarah Williston prizes are awarded to the five scholars who stand highest in their class at the end of their second, third, and fourth years . The five scholars at the University of Cambridge will be awarded to five of their class .
 The awards are named for the first woman elected to Mount Holyoke’s Board of Trustees, in 1884 . The first woman was elected to the board of trustees in 1883 . The awards were named after the first female member of the board .

 The Building Committee has written the Selectmen asking them to call a special town meeting to appropriate at least $11,000 in addition to the $9,000 remaining in the original budget . Building Committee is asking Selectmen to appropriate more than $10,000 to the Town Council .
 The committee has estimated that at least $20,000 will be needed to complete the school . The committee estimates that the school will cost $20 million .
 The Selectmen have met with the School Building Committee to discuss the additional funds required . At these meetings a complete list of necessary items with exact costs was not available . Selectmen are unwilling to call a special town meeting to consider the matter until they have more exact knowledge of what is now
 The school has been in use since the opening of the school year in September . The new building houses the offices of the Superintendent of Schools .
 Building Committee has mentioned that the new school needs books for its library, science equipment, aids to teaching, furnishings for the teachers’ room and School Committee room . Building Committee also needs racks for storage of lumber and metal for the woodworking and metal working shops .
 It is possible that some changes in the school ventilating system will be necessary . It is also possible that changes will also be necessary to ventilate children .
 One of the requisites to transferring the land on which the school is located from the Water and Sewer Board to the School Committee was the erection of a fence around the well fields remaining .
 As yet this fence has not been built, it raises the question whether this land is still under the jurisdiction of the Water and Sewer Board . As yet, this fence is not being built, raising the question if this land belongs to the city .

 Winchester Mornings subscribers turned out to hear Miss Margaret Clapp, president of Wellesley College . Richard L McGuire, adult advisers, was also speaker .
 M iss Clapp spoke of four basic facts which are influencing our education in this transition period, namely, the explosion of knowledge; the shortage of teachers; and the shrinking world .
 She spoke of the problems and confusions which face us and of the great tasks which lie ahead in the field of education .
 We must be wary of impatience and short cuts and realize that there are diverse needs and many roads to meet them . We should be concerned not with theories but with the individual. We must not be concerned with theories, but with individual needs and needs .
 We have to realize that in the not too distant future our secondary-school student may be facing a world which has very little resemblance to that of today . We need to be prepared for a world that may not resemble the world of today.
 She spoke of the marvelous revisions in curriculum which have alroady been achieved, especially in the secondary schools .
 In the fields of mathematics and science great strides have been and are being made . There are the beginnings of a change in the teaching of history and history .
 We can no longer consider a Western world and an Eastern world, but we must learn to think in terms of one world . We must learn from each other to think of a one world, says David Cameron . Cameron: "We must not think of Western and Eastern worlds. We must
 The need for teachers is tremendous, teachers who have enthusiasm and something to communicate, teachers with the sort of character we would like to have our young people imitate . Teachers with enthusiasm and communication are needed in schools, says Dr. Andrew Hammond .
 This is not an easy order, Miss Clapp admitted, but such we must have if we are to make progress in achieving our goal . This must be 'such a task' she admitted, adding that it is not 'easy'
 In the light of the importance of education in our world and of its increasing cost, Miss Clapp feels that we should re-examine our expenditures of time and money .
 Developments in the suburbs are encouraging, she said, but they cannot live in isolation . Whatever happens in poorer sections of our cities is going to affect the suburbs .
 The problems and the dangers are many and we must keep in mind that education is not for greed, not for the purpose of outdoing one’s neighbor . Education is for the benefit of all, and not for outdoing your neighbor .

 Members were called upon to demonstrate the many different ways gestures could be used and to be aware of the gestures used by speakers .
 Every member of a Toastmistress Club has an opportunity to participate in all meetings which is part of the training program the club affords . Toastmistresses are required to attend all meetings .
 The club meets every two weeks on Monday evening and to be uble to think on ones feet is the prime objective . The club is based in New York City, New Jersey, and meets every week .
 Don't be a poor Susie, and get all frustrated when asked to speuk to people at your clubs next special occasion . Visit Toastmistress and observe how one can gain poise and diplomacy that is so important in the world .

 He outlined the changing schools of thought regarding placement of plantings and general effects desired . He outlined a changing school of thought on plantings .
 After World War II two schools of thought emerged, one emphasizing “massed effects;” the other, restraint, topography, apd beautiful lawns . The other is restraint and topography . The lawns in New York City are considered beautiful .

 The development of the town manager method of administration in Massachusetts must he divided into two distinct periods based on the “weak manager” concept, stem ming from the Norwood act of 1914 . The “strong manager’ form was created hy the Saugus act of 1947
 Towns of Norwood, Stoughton, Middleborough, Orange and Mansfield fall under the first category . Towns which have accepted town manager enabling legislation since 1947 come within the latter category .
 Staunton, Virginia, is usually mentioned as the first community to utilize this form . The origin of the council manager plan is uncertain .
 In 1908, Staunton, by ordinance hired a “general manager” to serve as a full-time administrator under an old-fashioned weak mayor and bicameral council system . In 1908 the city hired a "general manager" to serve a full time administrator under
 A committee of seven was ap pointed and after due deliveration presented a report . Committee of seven presented report into the case .
 Committee charged with creating a scheme of government that would be in harmony with new office . Committee believed existing form of government did not lend itself to such a project .
 The activities of this committee led subsequently to the adoption of the Norwood Town Manager Act of 1914 . The committee led to the introduction of the new town manager legislation .
 The adoption of this was indeed a major step for a Massachusetts community to take, but by today’s standards it illustrates weak manager administration .
 The special act concentrated more essential managerial authority in the selectmen than in the manager . The selectmen have more authority than the manager, according to the law .
 Under the act, the moderator, five selectmen, five school committeemen, the treasurer and collector, the finance committee, library trustees, the planning hoard, and the board of health were all elected .
 Selectmen appointed the town clerk, town accountant, physician, fire chief, building inspector, sealer of weights and measures, forest and fire warden, fish and game warden . Selectmen also appointed boards of assessors, public welfare and appeals .
 The selectmen were given the powers of the board of public welfare, highway surveyors, water, sewer, and park commissioners, municipal light board, and tree warden .
 The town council fixed the salary of the manager, assessors, town clerk, and town accountant . The council also fixed the salaries of the town clerk and assessors .
 He was to organize, continue or discontinue such divisions or departments as may be determined by vote of the selectmen or in the absence of such vote .
 He had the power to appoint and remove all superintendents or chiefs of departments and all subordinate officers and employees in such departments and to fix thensalaries and wages .
 He was to attend all selectmen meetings and give recommendations of the needs of the town . He was also to give recommendations for the town's needs . The town's selectmen voted to appoint him to the position .
 He prepared budgets for departments under his control, was responsible for maintenance of town buildings . He also was purchasing agent for all town departments except schools .
 He had control and supervision of the police department subject to the direction of the selectmen . Finally, he had control over supervision of police department .
 The special acts establishing town managers in Stoughton, Mansfield and Middleborough were essentially the same as Norwood act .
 In Mansfield and Middleborough the finance committee was abolished and its duties transferred to the selectmen . In Stoughton, a five-man elected finance committee also acted as a planning hoard, received the budget estimates from the town manager .
 The town treasurer and collector of taxes were elected in Middleborough and appointed by the manager of the manager in Mansfield . Middleborough was elected in 2011 . Mansfield was also elected in 2012 .
 The selectmen exercise control over the major appointments and supervise the administration of departments ostensibly under the town manaKer . The town's selectmen continued to exercise control of the appointments .
 The answer is to be found in analyses of the charters, which seem to indicate that certain principles of public administration are being violated . The answer to the question is to find out what is happening in the charter system .
 The list is actually so long that one wonders just what that section referring to his power to appoint superintendents and subordinates really means .
 The phrase “subject to the direction and supervision of the selectmen’s.” tends to violate the separation which should exist between politics and administrationif the manager plan is to be successful .
 If “direction and supervision” is interpreted to mean interference in the day-to-day administration of municipal departments, then the authority and responsibility of the manager is irrevocably undermined . “Direction and supervision,’s interpretation of the law,” says
 It would be foolhardy to expect any Massachusetts community to accept a strong manager charter at such an early date when the plan itself was relatively unknown and untested . Like all modifications in government, the changes that are involved in the adoption of a town manager charter are very slowly accepted by
 Full acceptance was given to the strong manager concept with the introduction of a town manager charter in 1947 . The bill subsequently passed and the citizens of Saugus ratified it in 1948 . Full acceptance of the idea was given in 1947; the bill passed and ratified it .
 It had been 17 years since Orange had accepted the town manager method . The town manager plan is important because it reopened consideration of the plan as one method of improving a town's management .
 The Saugus bill tended to correct some of the shortcomings of the previous charters granted to Norwood, Stoughton, Mansfield, Middleborough and Orange . Further, the bill tended . to correct the shortcomings . of the . previous charties .
 The town manager’s power to appoint was extended to such positions as a planning board, a board of welfare, board of health, and board of playground commissioners . Three qualified assessors, a town clerk, town treasurer town collector, town accountant, accountant, superintendent of public works
 The selectmen were limited to appointing members of the board of appeals, board of library trustees, election officers, registrars of voters, and the town manager . The town manager was appointed by the selectmen .
 The selectmen have the appointing power over these boards since they are quasijudicial and are not concerned with day to day administration . It is certainly fitting and proper that the selectmen should have the power over the boards .
 He was authorized to reorganize, consolidate, or abolish those departments, commissions, and boards within his province . He could also establish new departments, transfer duties, powers, and appropriations .
 The town manager established by this legislation was, indeed, the chief administrative officer of the town and had the authority commensurate with his responsibilities . Although it appears that too many boards still existed, it appears too many still existed .
 The office of selectman in Massachusetts town government is being reduced to impotence under a strong manager charter . The position is an “ancient and honorable” position .
 The role of the selectman is being redefined in the light of modern pressures on town government and upon the office of selectman in particular . We shall endeavour to point out, however, that the role of a selectman has been redefined by modern pressures .

 Material which cannot be burned at the Incinerator may be disposed of on the ground at the site . Stoves Washing Machines and spring mattresses are not allowed to be burned . The disposal of the above items is effected by contract .
 Trucks and Trailers of over one half ton size using the Incinerator must be equipped with a dumping mechanism . Trucks must be fitted with a dump mechanism to dispose of them .
 Any spillage at the dumping door or at the conveyor must be shoveled into the storage pit or on the . conveyor . Spillage at dumping door must be . shoveled in storage pit .
 Board of Health Rules for Transporting Over Highways . All private trucks using the Incinerator shall display a sticker which may be obtained from the board of health .
 All private trucks hauling refuse shall use a tarpaulin or other form of covering to prevent littering of highways and Incinerator grounds . Private trucks must use a covering to avoid littering .
 All private vehicles shall display a sticker which may be obtained from the Board of Health for the transporting of refuse over the streets . The stickers are required to be used by private vehicles .
 Under no condition will refuse collected outside the Town of Winchester be accepted at the Incinerator . Refuse from Other Towns will be accepted .
 All truck and car drivers should expect to be questioned by the Incinerator personnel as to the source of their loads, and if required, shall produce a document showing that the refuse is from the Town of Winchester .
 Enforcement Incinerator personnel are authorized to reject any truck or car w hose operator fails in any way to conform to these rules and regulations . Enforcement officials will reject any vehicle or vehicle that fails to comply with the rules .
 Continued neglect by such operator of the rules and regulations may result in suspension of permission to use the Winchester Incinerator and for an indefinite period of time . Continued neglect will result in the suspension .
 Winchester has spent nearly a half million dollars on the Incinerator and all concerned must give fullest cooperation . Town of Winchester spent nearly half a million dollars . Winchester must give full cooperation .
 Please separate allowable non-combustibles from combustibles so that each may be placed in the proper location at the Incinerator Site .
 If non-combustibles get into the Incinerator furnace they may well cause a breakdown which will affect the refuse disposal of the entire Town . Culling out of non -combustible materials in the storage pit is an impossible task .
 These regulations do not apply to the collection or disposal of Garbage which is now disposed of out of Town . Garbage is now collected out of town .
 It is essential to the proper operation of the Winchester Incinerator that these Rules and Regulations be followed by each ami every resident and private collector .

 Bateson points out that nev or before in the nation’s history has it been so essential for Ameri can soldiers to know qnd understand other people throughout the world . Bateson says the U.S. has never had such a strong military presence in the military .
 Demand for soldier scl entists and technicians has risen steadily . Also, demand for soldiers and technicians is also rising steadily .
 The Army has met this requirement by a comprehensive civil schools program, by . increasing emasis upon language training and by . provding on-duty and off-duty educational opportunities in every relevant field of study .
 Each year, the Army sends hundreds of commissioned and enlisted personnel to leading colleges and universities on full duty status for study . The Army sends them to study to fulfill training requirements .
 Thousands more enrolled in voluntary off-duty courses through the Army’s General Educational Development Program .
 In each overseas command, branches of leading American universities furnish facilities for resident credit studies conducted during the soldier’s off-duty free time .
 Trained educational advisors are available at unit level to help soldiers plan their educational program . Trained educators are available to help students plan their education program .
 The Army library system offers the same reference and other facilities soldiers would find in their home town . The library system is located in the U.S. Army base .
 In the Army’s own service schools, the curricula are modified and improved constantly to meet ver-changing requirements .
 In I960, a major revision of the curriculum at the U.S. Military Academy was made as the result of recommendations of the Academic Board and the superintendent of the Academy . For example, I960 was made in I960 as a result of the recommendations .
 Similar up-dating of the instruction is always in the process at higher level Army schools, the Command and General Staff College and the Army War College .
 Today’s Army offers greater opportunity for a more varied education, at less personal cost than any soldier could find in civilian life . The Army offers more opportunities for a varied education than you can find in your own life .
 Almost 65% of Army enlisted personnel are high school graduates or have also attended college . Almost 70% of enlisted personnel have high school or college degrees or have attended college.
 Army officers constitute one of the most highly ducated groups in the nation, 90% have had some college work . Nearly 60% hold at least one coL lege degree .

 Winchester High School has been awarded a new Football Trophy at Winchester High . J. Churchill HINDER has been in charge of the new trophy for the past five years .
 Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Princeton and Penn were football power-houses . "Doc" missed a few of the big games that he missed in the days when the teams were big powerhouses .
 He saw many of the big names of football perform and through the years he has seen all kinds of football, college, professional and high school . He has also seen many big names perform .
 “Doc” followed the HarvardYale rivalry closely and was regularly a member of a group of enthusiasts who, each year the game was in New Haven, had a eserved car on a special train for the game . The night before the game, "Doc" went l
 Since his retirement “Doc” has missed few Winchester games or practice sessions . Winchester Fan "Doc’s" is a Winchester fan . Winchester fan is a member of the Winchester family .
 His loyalty to both has been constant and he i always ready to defend Winches ter football against all comers . He has been a constant supporter of both the club and the football team .
 “Doc’s” interest in local players hasn’t been cen tered in the stars, though he ha been quick to acclaim them . During the years "Doc's" interest has been in the local players, but he hasn't been able to find
 He’s watched the freshmen and the seconds and gotten a real kick out of seeing some of the less promising players at first develop into varsity performers .
 At the games he watches the blocking and tackling, the following of the ball and the carrying out of assignments . He watches blocking, tackling, and the following the ball .
 He notes the instructions the boys get at practice and watches to see how they follow these instructions in the games . He also watches the instructions he gets at practice .
 He has no excuse for the hoy who isn’t trying, but the boy who gives it everything he has, and loses, will never he criticized by him . The boy who loses, and doesn't he will never be criticized, will not he criticized .
 He knows that the stars are not always the ones who do most for team morale . That is why those who are giving the trophy in his name made outstanding loyalty, effort and team spirit, not stardom, the criteria .
 The trophy is a handsome black walnut shield with a bronze shield shaped plaque at the top on which is engraved the name of the trophy .
 Ranged below are 20 bronze rectangles on which will be engraved the names and years of the winners . The names of the 20 winners will also be engraved on the rectangles below .
 The winner will receive a replica of the bronze marker at the top of the shield, mounted on wood and engraved with his name . This trophy will remain at high school in the trophy case .

 Her home is in West Berlin at Stauffcnburg Strasse, where she lives in an apartment with her mother . Her mother, Mrs. Mrs. Schauffnburg, lives in a West Berlin apartment .
 Ingeborg Vdn Klocke, her older sister, Marie Luise, 23, and her brother, Rudolf, 27, who is 27 and in the German Army .
 Her father lost his life while serving with the German Army during the war . Her father was killed in World War II in Germany .
 Her mother and her sister and brother had been evacuated during World War 2 . They were evacuated from the city during the war because of the bombings .
 Gisela was born April 24, 1944, and had not had her first birthday when she went to Berlin from the farm with her mother, brother and sister . She was born in 1944 and died at the age of 18 .
 She was taken in a baby carriage, but the others walked, 60 kilometers or about 36 miles . She was carried in a carriage, while the other walked, about 36 kilometers .
 Gisela went first to the elementary school which includes grades up to the sixth, then to the oberschule or gymnasium . Growing up in Berlin, or West Berlin, she went to the kindergarten or the gym .
 She had completed her 11th year in the gymnasium last April before coming to Winchester .
 When she gets back to Germany she will take examinations to see whether the work she has done in our high school will enable her to go into grade 13 . She will then decide whether she can go to grade 13 in grade 12 .
 If she is unsuccessful in her examinations she will repeat this year’s work in the 12th grade of the gymnasium . If she fails in her exams she will be repeating this year's work .
 In German schools pupils remain in their rooms and the teachers go from room to room . In the German schools, pupils stay in rooms and teachers go to rooms to teach .
 German is taught in all grades, also history, music, art, art and gymnastics . German is also taught in history, history and music .
 English, French and Latin courses begin with the seventh grade, and Latin, with the ninth grade . Commencing with the fifth grade there is English .
 From the first to the sixth grade the German school children have what they call Rechnen, which is sort of basic mathematics, followed by mathematics in the high school . In the German high school, mathematics is also basic mathematics .
 The mathematics instruction ditfers from ours in that it aims at an over all knowledge of the subject, though some branches of mathematics are emphasized more than others . Commencing with the seventh grade there is physics and from the seventh to the eleventh grades, chemistry .

 From the first through the eleventh grades all pupils are required to study religion unless the parents request in writing that their children be excused .
 After the 11th grade religion is optional and con«erns itself with the philosophy of the problems underlying all roliI gion . Religion is optional after the 11st grade .
 Gisela thinks her German schools are more strict than those in Winchester . She thinks that the tests are more difficult than those at her school in Winchester, England . She also thinks that her German school is more strict .
 Most tests are on the home work of the moment while in the German schools the tests cover the pupils’ knowledge of the entire subject to date .
 The schools in West Berlin are in session from 8 o’clock in the morning to 1 :30 in the afternoon six days a week .
 The school year is from April to April with five to six weeks vacation in the summer usually partly in July and partly in August . School year is between April and April .
 There is a vacation of a week or ten days when the school reports come out in October and there is a two weeks vacation at Christmas, starting December 23 .
 There is another two weeks vacation when the final reports come out at the end of school year in April .
 School children in Germany go to theatre because of special cards give them in school . Gisela likes to read in her spare time, and school children go to the theatre often .

 The policy has some of the usual limitations and exclusions of all insurance contracts . All parents of students in the plan should be familiar with the policy .
 There is no limit except the policy limit for X-rays if there is a fracture . If there is no fracture, there is also a limit of $5.00 .
 For any minor injury not requiring surgery, the medical care is limited to one doctor’s visit per day at the rate of $5.00 for the first visit and $3.00 . For additional visits, additional visits are required for minor injuries not requiring a surgery .
 For major injuries requiring surgery or hospital care, there is no limit except that of the policy . The policy does not apply to any of the injuries requiring hospital care .

 This week’s picture shows the delivery wagon of Alexander MacDonald in front of his provision store on Main Street near the center railroad crossing . This week's picture is part of the Star's "Remember When" series .
 Next to the crossing at the corner of Main Street and the walk that led along the outbound tracks from Winchester Station to the center was the shoe store of James McLaughlin . The shoe store was located next to the tracks .
 It was moved to Thompson Street when the owner sold to Morris L Snyder, the present proprietor of the business . It was then moved to a new location on Thompson Street .
 Mr MacDonald’s market was well known in the old days . He continued in the provision business in Winchester for many years during the nineties and early nineteen hundreds .
 Older residents will recall ‘him as a tall bearded man, pleasant of manner with a good sense of humor,’ he said .
 He was active in hurch and civic work, liked to sing and had a good bass voice . He also liked to be active in his local community and was a good singer .
 After his days as a provision dealer, he was until his retirement Superintendent of Parks under the late George T Davidson . After his retirement he was . until his . retirement was until . his retirement .
 Many will still recall his tall figure and tan sleeveless leather jacket which he wore in cool weather . Many still remember him as a tall man with a tall figure .

 A special appeal to be launched during the Thanksgiving season will ask American Protestants and Eastern Orthodox church members for $979,380 to finance the 1962 Share Our Surplus Program . More than 20 million hungry persons overseas will rereceive life-saving U.S. surplus foods .
 SOS foodstuffs, wheat, flour, bulgar (a processed, quickly prepared wheat derivative), corn meal, powdered milk and cooking oils, are scheduled for distribution to the world’s hungry in 39 areas of Asia, Africa, Europe and Latin America .
 Since 1952, SOS foods sent over seas by the churches have been given to disaster victims . SOS foods have been sent to widows, orphans, school children, hospital patients and the aged .
 Hundreds of thousands of church goers will contribute to the appeal at Thanksgiving Week Community Services . The Christian Rural Overseas Program of Church World Service will also contribute .

 Autumn leaves raked up once a week can be composted and return to the soil in the form of mineral-rich humus . Leaves can be recycled into humus and composted into a composted pile .
 Edward J Duda, acting director of the Bartlett Tree Research laboratories, says it is wasteful . But it is not only wasteful, says Duda .
 Leaves from mature trees when turned to compost may be worth as much as $15 to $20 . Leaves from a single mature tree can be turned into compost and sold for $20 to $15 .
 In suburbs where leaf burning is permitted, burn only those infected with diseases . Burn only those known to be infected with disease .
 Never start a bonfire beneath a tree; the heat may scorch and kill the lower branches . The heat may also scorch lower branches of a tree .
 Go-carts that rake up leaves have removed the chore from this autumn task . Go-cart rake-up leaves has been replaced by go-cart raking leaves .
 These are acid and can be used as mulch for azalea, andromeda, laurel, rhododendron and other acid-loving plants .
 Dogwood Tip Dieback Due To Muggy Weather . Tips of branches dying back on many dogwood trees .
 It’s due in part to muggy weather, according to Roy C Beckwith of the Bartlett Tree Research Laboratories .
 This year's humid weather in summer and fall brought it on in quantity . This year, however, it was the worst year for humidity in the country .
 This infection is best controlled with a fungicidal spray in the spring . Fungalicidal spray is best used to control the infection .
 Pruning out killed tips now will prevent the infection from spreading into branches .

 Francis Smith of 1 Wolcott Terrace, was recently honored for her outstanding achievements in work for blind persons . Francis Smith was honored for his outstanding achievements for blind people .
 On October 18 she was awarded a plaque by the Mater Dei Guild of the Catholic Guild for All the Blind at a morning ceremony at the Woodlavvn Golf Club, New ton .
 Smith recently completed 36 years of volunteer reading to blind students . Smith was dean of volunteer readers in this area . Smith has spent 36 years in volunteer reading .
 She was one of the first persons to respond to an appeal for volunteers to read to blind students attending local universities . The appeal was advertised over a quarter of a century ago for volunteers .
 Thirtyfive of the current clients are students registered at schools and colleges in this vicinity . The clientele is students registered in this area .
 For the past five years this program has been under the administration of the Catholic Guild for All the Blind . The program is now being run by a nonprofit known as the C.G. for the blind .
 When the Guild, at the request of the United Community Services, took over this activity; Mrs. Mrs. Smith was the first woman to volunteer for the Guild .
 In this time she has contributed over 1,100 hours of volunteer reading . She has contributed more than 1,000 hours of reading .
 Smith has for many years transcribed text books into braille specializing in foreign language books . Smith has transcribed braille text books for braille .
 Hundreds of blind men and women have been able to take advantage of the rich educational opportunities this area offers . The blind are able to access the rich, educational opportunities in the area .

 Clerk at Xcno’s Market thwarted an attempted holdup in the parking lot of the market last Friday evening shortly be ore 8 o’clock .
 The dome light of the car came on and he saw a man crouched on the floor of the back seat compartment . As he did so the dome light came on, the car's dome light turned on and the man was crouched .
 As the light came on and he saw the man “Randy” asked him what he was doing in his car . The man said the man was Randy, who asked him if he was going to do anything in the car .
 “Randy” slammed the door and ran back into the market, taking the store money with him . Instead of complying with the holdup man’s order, "Randy" slammed the store door and went back in .
 A call was sent in to Police Headquarters and Sergeant Andrew Crawford with officers Roland Roy and Andrew Crawford . Officers Roland Roy, Andrew Crawford, and Roland Roy were called to the scene .

 The first group ikeeting for all j hospital volunteers, sponsored by 'the Friends of the Winchester Hospital, was held at the Wyman School on Tuesday evening, October 24th . The first ikeete for all hospital volunteers was held .
 Robert Grenzeback, chairman of volunteers, introduced the three speakers for the evening . The event was held in a bid to raise funds for the next year .
 Mr Reese James, hospital administrator, spoke of the volunteers from the administrative point of view . He said the volunteers are volunteers who help the hospital .
 He mentioned the beginnings of the Winchester Hospital in 1912 by volunteers and their continued work through the years as directors, members of the medical staff, building committees, fund raising committees, and members of Winton Club, En Ka, and the Friends .
 All of these make up a j team to provide the best medical care possible . The team includes a team of doctors, nurses and nurses .
 Mr James spoke of the prestige of being a volunteer and the ingredients that make a good one, interest, understanding, willingness to accept responsibility, tact, judgment and consideration .
 He also explained that with volunteers it is quality not quantity to look for . He said with volunteers, quality is not quantity but quality .
 Miss Marjorie Snyder, director of nurses, stressed volunteer’s role as part of the patient care team .
 Each member of this team must understand her duties and responsibilities and work with the others for the complete satisfaction of the patient . The team must work with each other to ensure the patient's complete satisfaction .
 Richard Clark, president of the medical staff, brought greetings from them . Richard Clark: "I am happy to be here for the first time in my life"
 He briefly mentioned the beginnings of Social Service work . He spoke of the tremendous changes that have taken place in volunteer services since that time .
 Clark spoke particularly of the sanctity of personal and professional relations of the patients . Volunteers especially must respect the confidences they may see or hear from patients .
 He stressed the mass psychology of a pleasant greeting, a cheery smile, and a silent tongue . The psychologist stressed the importance of a positive greeting .
 Clark also brought the appreciation of the medical staff for the work being done by the volunteers .
 Grenzeback summarized the program with the words quality, responsibility, and dedication . The program has been described as 'quality' and 'responsibility'
 A brief question period concluded the first and most successful meeting of volunteers of the Winchester Hospital . Winchester Hospital volunteers met for the first time in a year .

 Meredith Cooper of Winchester died early Friday af ternoon at his home after several months illness .
 He underwent syr gery at the Winchester Hospital during May and June and had been critically ill for some time .
 He was born Aug., 1911 in Montpelier, Vermont . He grew up in East Haven, Connecticut, graduating from Hillhouse High School .
 He received his Bachelor of Arts degree from Yale in 1932 and his Master’s Degree in 193d. He was awarded his Master's degree in 192d.
 He began teaching as an assistant at Yale in 1934 . The next year he taught junior high school English at State School in Meriden, Conn. He was an assistant teacher at Yale, Yale and Meriden .
 For two years, 1936-37 he taught History at high school in East Haven, Conn. He also taught history at East Haven High School .
 Mr Cooper married Mar garet Turton of Meriden, Conn, in 1938 . Mr Cooper came with his wife to Winchester in the fall of that year .
 He entered the School Department here in 1938 as a teacher of Social Studies in the high school . He was made head of the department in the fall of 1955 .
 He served as faculty advisor to the Student Council and had also been publicity director for the high school . He was also faculty advisor for the student council .

 He was born May 29, 1868, in Westbrook, Me., and graduated from Deering High School in Portland, Me. He attended Western State Normal School before beginning the study of Medicine .
 He studied at Portland School of Medical Instruction and was graduated from Bowdoin College Medical School . He is a father of two .
 He first practiced in Bradford, Me., leaving to become a voluntary assistant at the Massachusetts (general Hospital) in the nose and throat department . He was a volunteer assistant at Massachusetts General Hospital .
 He was licensed to practice in Massachusetts in 1897 . He was appointed as house officer at the Carney Hospital in South Boston .
 He joined the Massachusetts Medical Society in 1898, and soon after came to Winchester to establish himself in practice . He was the founder of the Winchester Medical Society .
 Dennett never hesitated to use the newer adjuncts of medicine as they developed . He appraised each carefully and applied those that merited use with professional skill .
 He was one of the earliest users of X-ray and was especially interested in the field of eye, ear, nose and throat . He was also an early inventor of medical imaging .
 Winchester people had their first glasses from him and returned to him regularly for the care of their eyes . Generations of Winchester people have had glasses from his glasses .
 Dennett was the oldest member of the Middlesex East District Medical Society . He was present at the society’s 50th anniversary celebration .
 He was also a principal speaker and chairman of the committee in charge of arrangements for the 75th anniversary program . He was still active at the society’s centennial in 1950 .
 Dennett was for two years on the editorial staff of the Portland Daily Express . He was on the paper's editorial staff for two more years .
 His frequent letters to the Star and the metropolitan press reflected his fearless devotion to principle . He commanded a virile and facile pen, and his frequent letters reflected his courage to stand by principle .
 "Courageousness often led him to support causes not generally popular, but he never dropped them for that reason. Keenly interested in town affairs, this same courageousness often left him with the courage of his courage .
 He loved the out-of-doors and wrote sym pathetically of the Maine Woods, of the old logging days on the Kennebec River and of the fishing camps at Moosehead .
 Some of his writing on death, life and human nature was especially sensitive . Many commended his study of "The Old Clock" in his pamphlet of essays .
 Dennett’s gardens were things of beauty under his skillful care, and he was happiest when sharing them with others . Dennett was a master gardener who cared for his gardens .
 Dennett enlisted in the Medical Corps and was first assigned to the Camp Dix Base Hospital in the department of head surgery . Dennett served in the Army Medical Corps in New Jersey .
 He later was transferred to Camp Crane in Allentown, Pa., awaiting overseas assignment . His overseas assignment did not come before the cessation of hostilities .
 Dennett married Elizabeth Goodwin Redfern, a native of Winchester, in 1959 . She died April 13, 1959 . Dennett was married to Elizabeth Goodwin .
 One of the doctor’s two sons was killed in World War I . The second, and younger, Daniel C Dennett, Jr., died in Africa in a plane crash while serving with the State Department .
 The doctor leaves three grandhildren, Cynthia, Daniel and Charlotte, all of Winchester . He also leaves a sister, Miss Abbie Dennett, of Portland, Maine .

 It therefore has become incumbent on the writer once more to dig up something of value .
 The weekly examination and correction of fifty or more ‘traveling scores’ is really quite revealing as to bidding and defense, as well as to the personalities involved . The weekly exam and correction is quite revealing .
 There also is the palliative effect of mentally reconstructing certain scores to determine how many points might have been gained on low boards with different or correct line of bidding, lead, play or defense .
 One group of players take in enough tricks for a game or slam, but fail to bid it . Those who bid the same hand to the hilt are invariably set . The most revealing of all is when one group of all players fail .
 The defense, in the latter case, for some reason or other seems to become inoculated, and tightens up considerably . The defense seems to be inoculated .
 An unusually large number of possible slam hands showed up in both sections of this week's traveling scores .
 The 27 hands have a sand-papering effect on the scoring, accounting for the low winning scores and small winning differentials . Representing over half the boards played, these hands have an impact on the scores .
 With this mass of pyrotechnics, it seems rather difficult for the nonparticipant to pick out a hand with a lesson or otherwise worth discussing .
 It is not often that miserable hands which, at rubber bridge would be only too quickly passed and discarded for the next deal, become of enough importance to determine the actual winners . Pass-Out or Open is open or open .
 This does decry the importance of every hand, but to realize that such rubbish as contained in Board 22 Section B could have any effect whatever on the ultimate standing is not generally appreciated .
 The writer and his partner recently were the victims of such a hand in another event . They ended up in third place instead of first for a swing of ten points on a board average .
 At one table West became the bidder at one no-trump making two for a top . West reached that bid with a third-hand 12 -point diamond opening and a one-over-one spade take-out .
 At the other two tables East arrived at three no-trump in spite of only 21 high-card points in the combined hands . East was pushed to sacrifice by interference bidding, down one .
 The effect of these three bids presented one NS pair with 3 match points, four others with % point, and penalized two others at 2 and 3 points respectively . The reverse was the case for East and West .
 Located in the strategic position, it is easy to see what the effect could be on the relative standing of the first four or even five top positions .

 Information about personnel administration from other states was gathered . It was either because their problems were similar to those of Massachusetts or because of their existing personnel program .

 Mr Cousins confronts us with the 20-megaton H-bomb, containing the explosive power of a mountain of T.N.T. four times the height of the Empire State Building . Mr Cousins .
 This bomb is capable of incinerating an area from Brooklyn to Bridgeport, Ct., killing all within its scorching radius, hurling human missiles and shards of glass for thousands of miles .

 Existing shelters, equipped with air vents, would be turned into hot-air furnaces in a nuclear attack . Only one-third of attacking missiles need get by our anti-missile installations to annihilate us .
 Man faces a threat to survival not only from potential nuclear attacks, but also from other threats to survival . But man faces a bigger threat than a threat from potential attacks .
 Human life is imperilled by radioactive fallout from nuclear tests already suspended, says Cousins . Strontium 90, which retains 50% of its energy after 28 years, is still a threat to life .
 Cousins writes, now' now' contains detectable traces of leukemia-inducing genetically crippling radioactive Strontium in his bones . Cousins writes: 'Now' contains traces of cancer-strontium, which can cause leukemia, and 'now'

 Cesium 137, also present in existing fallout, is assaulting human genes with gamma rays, and will result in malformations and stillbirths . The same issue will also affect human genes, and could lead to stillbirth .
 Cousins argues that the nation-state, as presently organized, can no longer protect our lives and freedom, but is in fact the prime source of the tensions and anarchy that threaten nuclear holocaust .

 This week's picture is of the old Winchester High School on Church Street, known during its final years as the Prince School . This week’s picture is part of the Star's "Remember When" series of photos .
 This building stood opposite Rangeley on Church Street at School Street, School Street . School yard extended through to Dix Street, with a small grove of trees at the rear .
 The town had a high school from its incorporation in 1850 . The actual high school rooms were on the upper floor of a large center school on Church Street opposite the Common .
 Children from primary schools old enough to go to grammar school went to this building . Children from the primary schools  went to the building . The building was built in the 1930s and 1940s .
 In 1865 it became necessary to have better and more commodious quarters for the high school . The plot of land described above was purchased next to the then James Converse house .
 The old building stood well above the street and was reached by a flight of granite steps at the southerly end of the lot on Church Street .
 The buliding served as a high school for nearly forty years, or until the present McCall Junior High School was built for the high school . The current McCall junior high school is now McCall High School .
 The Prince School was used as a sixth grade building for children from all over town . The name of the school was changed to the Prince School after Frederick O Prince, a prominent old time citizen and school committeeman .
 The old Prince School was abandoned as a school building after 1922-24 . It continued to house the office of the Superintendent of Schools for a time .
 Eventually it was torn down and its site is now occupied by the homes of Dr. and Mrs. Mrs. of the Dr. Dr. George and Dr. Geraldine . Eventually the site of the building was demolished .

 Firefighter O’Donnell was on the way to the Winchester Hospital to pick up his wife, who had been a patient at the hospital and had been discharged . The left front tire of his Dodge sedan blew out while he was headed north on Highland Avenue .
 The blowout caused the car to swerve sharply through the southbound lane and leave the road, striking a tree . The car was struck by a tree in front of the residence of William J Canniff at 85 Highland Avenue .
 Firefighter O’Donnell pinned in the wreckage, which was on fire when police arrived . The car was completely demolished and the car was demolished . Firefighters were pinned to the wreckage .
 Desk Officer John H Boyle had been notified of the accident at headquarters . He radioed Officers Robert Baird and David Boyle in a patrol car .
 Officer Mario Buzzotta, in the department’s ranch wagon, hastens to the scene of the accident . Officer Buzzotta rode in the station's ranch wagon .
 Officers Baird and Boyle radioed for the fire department rescue truck and the police ambulance . Both made quick trips to the scene of the crash . Police say the crash was caused by a single-vehicle crash .
 Officers Baird and Boyle extricated Firefighter O’Donnell from the car . He was removed in the ambulance to the Winchester Hospital, where he was treated by Dr. Dr. David O'Donnell .
 He sustained severe face lacerations and X-rays disclosed a possible lacerated liver . The victim sustained severe facial injuries and sustained a possible liver injury .

 The Fire Department is instituting a new static pressure test for all fire hydrants in town . The test will be conducted by the Fire Department of Fire Department .
 This is an entirely new test and should not he confused with the old flow test or flushing of hydrants . This is a new test . This should not be confused with old flow tests or flushes of hyrants . The test is a completely new type of test .
 The purpose of the test is to get the various hydrant pressures to make sure that the hydrants are delivering sufficient water for the pumping that may be necessary . The test is designed to make the necessary pumping of water necessary .
 A representative of the Water Department will accompany firefighters on testing trips so that if any defects are found they can be remedied immediately .

 Massachusetts Civil Defense Agency to protect the public against uninformed or unscrupulous shelter dealers will be intensified in a series of educational meetings throughout the commonwealth next month .
 The meetings will be open to town and city assessors and building inspectors, architects, engineers, builders and others in the shelter business .
 The nature of the radiation threat, methods of coping with it and the basic standards for shelters will be outlined by Civil Defense specialists . Civil Defense experts will discuss the nature of radiation threat and how to cope with it . The radiation threat will be discussed at the start of the week .

 Shih of the Chinese Christian Church of New England will speak Sunday morning at 9:15 at the Chapel Service of the Senior Forum at the First Congregational Church .
 Shih’s subject “This Is A Friendly World” will reflect his findings on a recently completed round the world trip . Shih visited East Berlin, Israel, Formosa, Bangkok, Singapore, Manilla, Hongkong and Japan .
 Shih visited many Chinese congregations, especially those served by former students of his . Shih had opportunity to see first hand many factors bearing on world tensions .
 Shih adopted an 11-year-old Chinese boy, a refugee from Communist China . The boy is now a part of the Shih household in Boston’s Chinatown .

 Robert B Anderson is an educational revolutionary who thoroughly enjoys assailing the status quo in teaching, turning present school conditions upside down and then dealing constructively with the effects of his agitation . Anderson advocates team teaching in Gingery Parkhurst .
 His humorous but gingery talk was heard by a nearly full auditorium . Parents from all over town and some school administrators from other towns joined him .
 Anderson is the rector of the Teaching Team Project at the Franklin School in Lexington . Anderson is also on the faculty of the Harvard Educational School .
 Winchester resident says he chose Winchester to live in because of its fine schools for which he is willing to pay even more taxes . Little League associate says Winchester is a great place to live because of the fine schools .
 He quickly dispelled, however, any idea that this link with his audience would qualify the presentation of his views on education .
 Anderson tells of experiences shared with three of them and Mr Sutula at first Harvard Summer School Team Teaching program at Lexington this summer .
 He described it as a strenuous and at times even sanguine program which only the fittest teachers survived . He strongly believes in the value of the challenge, change and exchange involved when teachers are collectively planning and carrying out a program .
 Franklin School in Lexington, Kentucky, is the nation's first real pilot project in Team Teaching . Franklin School is the four-year-old Franklin School .
 This despite the fact that no statistics there yet show a claim of real advantage to the system . No statistics yet show any real advantage in the system, says the BBC .
 A team of teachers is given the responsibility to work jointly for the instruction of a group of students whom they group by ability rather than age . In contrast to this contained classroom concept, a teacher may retire and create a separate, insulated regime .
 Numerically the grouping of the 1 children may be done in many ways, and done differently for every subject ar far as scheduling permits . The grouping of 1 children is done in a variety of ways .
 The teacher among them whose ability is greatest in a | given subject takes the lead in directing the planning for this course . The other teachers support .
 This makes for most effective use of both talenu and time for both students and teachers — as well as for a great deal of planning for the latter . It also makes for the best use of time for teachers, students and parents .
 In the conventional school a poor teacher can conceal an inadequate performance and an excellent teacher cover up or habituate what may be a blind spot . But in a more flexible way they illuminate each other’s performances as well as the material which they are presenting .
 The constant curriculum evaluation which is highlighted by this process is one of the best potentials of the system, according to Dr. Dr. John Defterios of the University of Cambridge .
 Anderson believes it is also one of the greatest needs in American education today . Anderson: It's also a great need in America's education today. Anderson: "It is also a good thing to learn"

 As a system this kind of reorganization also offers a natural hierarchy of teacher assignment which would take into account ability variation . As a result, the reorganization of teacher assignments would also offer a new hierarchy of teachers .
 Teaching Assistant Program offers the perfect adjunct for the kind of teaching assistant Program which exists in Winchester . In the top or team leader level it certainly demands a higher remuneration and then on learning or assisting levels .

 Mental Health is one of the major fields of interest of the Socia Service Guild, both in study and service projects . Mental health is a major field of interest for the Guild .
 Mental and emotional illness is not an inadmissible social stigma, says psychologist . Mental illness is a field of increasing importance as the public becomes more aware of mental illness . Mental health is an important part of the field of study .
 Modern medicine is treating with increasingly beneficial results, says Dr. Andrew Hammond . Public education for tolerance for tolerance and understanding is needed, he says .
 This need is very apparent when patients are ready to be dismissed from the hospital but have to remain because their families or friends are not ready to accept them and co operate in helping them adapt to normal life again .
 Members of the Social Service Guild have worked at the Metropolitan State Hospital as weekly volunteers for several years . The hospital is located in the city's largest psychiatric hospital .

 Police Aided In Stolen Car Chase Officers Robert Baird and David Boyle in a Police cruiser figured in the chase of a stolen automobile through town .
 Headquarters was notified by the Arlington Police that a youth who had stolen an automobile in Arlington was headed toward Winchester . Headquarters received a call from Arlington Police Headquarters that the youth was headed to Winchester .
 Officers Baird and Boyle went to the Ridge Street section of town, where the car had been seen . Officer Tony Pronski, al so on patrol duty in the area, was also alerted to be on the lookout for the car .
 Officers Baird and Boyle spotted the car on Cambridge Street, head ed toward Woburn . They gave chase and gave chase . Police say the car was headed toward Wobburn .
 The wanted operator turned right into Everett Avenue and the Police followed him into Bacon Street and along Main Street toward Medford . Police followed the operator along Bacon Street, Bacon Street .
 Officer Boyle kept Headquarters informed of their patrol car’s posi tion and Officer Cogan informed Medford of the chase . The chase ended in Medford, Massachusetts .
 As the fleeing car turned into Playstead Road it narrowly avoided a collision with another vehicle and nearly turned turtle . The fleeing car narrowly avoided hitting another car and nearly turning turtle .
 The operator ran through land ar Oak Grove Cemetery with Officers Baird and Boyle in pursuit . The operator then ran through the cemetery with officers in pursuit of him .
 Medford police joined the local officers at Playstead Road and searched the neighborhood . The youth, a 16-year-old, was picked up on Wood Road off Playstead road by the Medford Police .
 Arlington Police say the car he was driving was stolen in that town earlier in the morning . He was booked at Medford Headquarters and turned over to Arlington Police who say the stolen car was stolen .

 Norman E Weeks’ Tube Test Design Wins Recognition In ‘‘Electronics’ Magazine for October . Mr Norman K Weeks, Manager of Test Equipment and Standards Department of the . Industral Components Division of Raytheon Company .
 One operator loads the seven-ton machine with tubes and another worker packs tested tubes . The machine is loaded with tubes to test tubes .
 The machine performs twenty static and dynamic electrical tests, at a rate of 1,800 tubes per hour . The machine is capable of performing 20 tests at a time .
 Field rejects have greatly decreased since the machine was placed in operation . A higher quality assurance factor and repeatability of performance have been obtained . The machine's field rejects have also decreased .
 The ability of the machine to subject all tubes to exactly the same test conditions has upped acceptance . The ability to subject tubes to the same conditions has increased acceptance .
 The human fatigue factor, with its consequent lowering of quality assurance, is not a problem . Human fatigue factor doesn't have a problem, says the manager of the company . It's not the problem, he says .
 The tubes are indexed for each of the twenty parameters tests . After preheat cycles, the tubes are indexed . The tubes will then be indexed for the other parameters .
 If a tube is within limits, it proceeds to the next test position . If it is outside limits, the tube is ejected into bins, as shown in pictures illustrating the Automatic Tube Tester .
 Counters indicate the number of rejects for each position, and also count total input and total output . Testing speed is such that process engineering can be alerted if tubes coming through production are not up to standard .
 The automatic test set is calibrated daily, as well as prior to changeover to a different tube type . It is calibrated every day and prior to the changeover .
 A sample of 25 tubes considered acceptable is checked five times each day . The sample is checked at least five times a day for acceptable use .
 Quality control x and r graphs arc plotted hourly for up to 20 reject items and for acceptable tubes . The graphs are plotted hourly to ensure product quality .
 A feature soon to be added is an adapter for testing flying lead and other type tubes .
 This machine is one of many pieces of Automatic Equipment developed by Mr Weeks and members of his department for the Automation Program at Raytheon .

 The architect's fees will depend upon what decision will be reached in connection with the change orders .

 Pupils At Saint Mary's 13 Local Girls Win Marian Medal Sunday, November 5, at St. Mary's .
 The Marian Medal is the highest award that can be received by a Catholic Girl Scout . After laboring for over a year and a half to complete the requirements for the reception of the Marian Medal, the girls saw the reward of their untiring efforts .
 Evelyn Brennan, Carol Crimmins, Donna DeAngelis, Diana Donald, Marianne Karnes, Mary Hannon, Rosemary Harrington, Carol Johnson, Cathy Kenny, Maureen McKenna, Joyce Moynihan, Diane Penta, and Diane Sampson .
 The awards were presented by Most Reverend Bishop Jeremiah Minihan at 2:00m. on Sunday afternoon .
 The girls were a part of an outstanding group from many parishes in the Archdiocese . They were a group of outstanding girls .
 St. Mary’s is very proud of the work that these members of the parish have done . They hope that they will prove by their example and lives that they are truly Marjian girls .
 Dirigos, a newly organized group of female songsters, made their debut in October, 1960 . They were the first female singers of the day .
 Their repertoire stems from rehearsing numbers for four part harmonizing . Their repertoire is rehearsing songs for four parts harmonizing.
 Under the talented direction of Mr George Blouin, the group has offered to a choice few the opportunity of participating in singing which is both challenging and enjoyable .
 Their time is divided between building up a repertoire and fulfilling engagements . Their time will be spent building up repertoire and performing .
 Since the date of organization, the Dirigos have made many appearances including singing under the hot TV lights at WABI in Bangor .
 Sunday, November 5, from 12 to 1m. was their first Television appearance this fall . Each girl was also interviewed for the first time .
 A love of singing and a navy blue suit with white accessories are their trademark . The couple have been married for more than 20 years .

 The Board of Directors of the Winchester Hospital announce the appointment of Dr. GUSTAV KAUFMANN . Dr. KAUfmann will be the first person to be appointed by the hospital's board .
 Gustav G Kaufmann, a well known specialist in internal medicine, has been named Chief of Medicine at the hospital . Kaufman was appointed to the position of Chief of Medical in the hospital in May .
 He has been certified by the American Board of Internal Medicine . He is a member of the Massachusetts Medical Society and the New England Diabetes Association .
 Dr. William J Speers, Jr., president of the board, in announcing the appointment, stated, “We are indeed fortunate that once again a physician of Dr. Dr. Speers has been chosen for this position .
 After an internship at the Presbyterian Hospital in Chicago he was appointed resident in medicine at the Massachusetts General Hospital . He became assistant physician at Phillips Andover Academy after becoming an assistant physician .
 Dr. Kaufmann was associate physician in the adolescent unit of the Children’s Medical Center in Boston . Dr Kaufman was an associate physician at the center in 1952 to 1956 .

 Greater Boston United Fund drive is first a story of volunteers and second money . The drive is a success story of volunteer efforts and money raised .
 Money will never be collected, counted or distributed to its agencies unless there are enough volunteer solicitors to call on every family in Metropolitan Boston . The United Fund needs some $14 million .
 United Fund volunteers have been working on the problems for weeks in preparation for the residential canvass that began on November 3 . This is one of the problems that key United Fund volunteer volunteers are working on for weeks .
 Teams of volunteers have been attempting to recruit solicitors to call on a few of their neighbors in behalf of the United Fund . Volunteers are working long hours after their regular jobs to raise money for the fund .
 One of their biggest difficulties is the old curse of public apathy, and the refusal of some who have volunteered before and found the role of the solicitor a hard one . One of the biggest difficulties of the volunteers is the refusal to volunteer again .
