 Americans have selected greater amounts of nutri tious meat, milk and eggs, available at reasonable prices, due to more efficient feeding . Glennon continued, “Our food Bupply is u most prized possession. Offered a wide choice of highly appealing foods .
 The manufactured feed industry has played an important role in utilizing new animal nutrition know ledge, and has become a source of new wealth and employment for other segments of our economy . The manufactured animal nutrition industry is an important part of the American economy .
 In less than half a century, the feed manufacturing industry has grown from a handful of grain and byproduct mixers to the 13th largest manufacturing industry in the United States . The industry is now the largest in the world devoted exclusively to providing goods and service to agriculture .
 It has a total investment of nearly two billion dollars, and annual gross sales of nearly four billion . Consisting of six thousand plants and twenty-five thousand dealers, it. has a . total investment . of nearly 2 billion dollars .
 Over a billion dollars worth of grain and high protein meals; . four hundred million dollars of transportation; . three hundred millions of food industry by-products; two hundred . millions of vitamins, antibiotics, minerals, minerals and chemicals .  Herberich, the Winchester j League of Women Voters, partied1 paled in the Annual Conference of | the Adult Education Association in Massachusetts on Saturday, November 4 .
 The AEA in Massachusetts is an organization composed of representatives of civic, community, labor and industrial groups . It is composed of those involved in any form of Adult Education in the Commonwealth .
 Its purpose is to coordinate activities involving any form of Adult Education in the Commonwealth . The organisation is based in the UK and Australia .
 The theme of the November 4 meeting was “Effective Techniques of Public Affairs Programming .” selected participating organizations describe successful methods they have used in launching and carrying out programs .
 The purpose of the discussion was to exchange ideas and experiences which the conference participants can apply to their own organizational work . The conference participants will be able to use these ideas to improve their organization .
 The LWV has long used the discussion method as a means of disseminating information to its own members . The discussion method is a way of stimulating thought, study and active participation in League affairs .
 Adult Education Institute of New England arranged a series of courses on program presentation last winter . The League was invited to participate in the courses, which were held in New England .
 Herberich attended these seminars as one of the representatives of the LWV . He continued with a more advanced seminar in Boston this Fall .
 The League's Candidate’s Questionnaire was discussed as an example of “Using Mass Media”; and Mrs. Mrs. Smith discussed using Mass Media . The League discussed using the League's candidate's Questionnaire .

 The dinner meeting was held by a panel of real estate professionals . Attorney Clarence A Roberts is legislative counsel for the Boston Board and the Massachusetts Association of Real Estate Boards .
 The purpose of the meeting was to acquaint the individual realtors with the men and women who represent them at the State House . Realtors lay before the legislators the need for tax relief for the real estate industry .
 Among topics discussed formally and informally were zoning, metropolitan planning and urban renewal .

 Novemhad been in poor health foi* four years, hut his was wholly unI expected . Reginald Hall Wentworth of if* Allen Rond, a retired Edison Company lighting engineer, died suddenly Monday afternoon .
 He was born August f> 1905, in Somerville, Massachusetts, and grew up in that city .
 A Massachusetts registered professional engineer, Mr Wentworth spent 33 years with the Boston Edison Company . He retired in 1958 because of poor health .
 He was a member of the Illuminating Engineering Society and a Mason, a former member of Soley Lodge of Somerville, Massachusetts .
 In his more active years he was a member of a Masonic degree team composed of Edison employees . He was also a team of Edison workers .
 Mr Wentworth’s hobby was photography and he devoted many hours of his free time to that field .
 For 11 years he took motion pictures of Winchester High School football games for the school . He also took many stills of teams and other school groups . For the 11 years, he took pictures of school football games .
 In taking the football movies Mr Wentworth was assisted for seven years by his son, Jack, and after Jack’s death February 27, 1956, by his daughter, Jeanne .
 On August 18, 1928, Mr Wentworth married Victoria Atley of Somerville, Somerville . They came to Winchester from that city in 1939 .

 Marguerite L Norwood, a former long time resident of Win Chester, died Sunday, November 5, at the Boston City Hospital, after a long illness . Norwood died at the hospital in Boston .
 She spent her early life in Bynum and later lived in West Virginia before moving to Winchester in 1927 . She spent most of her life in Winchester .
 She was a maid in the families of several Winchester residents, including the Clarence Millers, the William Wymans, and the Rev. Rev. William Wyman .
 John E Page lived at 22 Everett Avenue, accompanying the family to Maine during the summers . He was held in esteem by the Pages and their friends .
 Norwood retired from Page home and took up residence in Boston at 52 Atherton Street . Norwood is a former resident of the Page home .

 He received his A.B. degree from Oberlin College in 1907 and his Bachelor of Divinity from the Oberlin Graduate School of Divinity in 1910 .
 Fairfield commenced his long career of service in 1909 when he was appointed a career missionary to China . Fairfield was appointed by the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions .
 He sailed in 1910, and on July 19, 1910, he was married in Karuizawa, Japan, to Miss Daisie Gehman of Norristown, Pa., who had been serving in China since 1903 .
 After their marriage they went on together to Taiku in North China, where they were stationed for the next 19 years . They were stationed in Taiku, North China .
 They served in church and educational work, being associated with Oberlin-Shansi Memorial Schools . Dr. Dr. Shansi died at the age of 92 .
 Fairfield was called to the headquarters of the American Board in Boston in 1929 . He served for the next 10 years as the board’s administrative secretary for China and Japan . Fairfield served for 10 years .
 He became secretary for general administration of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America in 1945 . His position involved liaison with the International Missionary Council, the Federal Council of Churches, the World Council of . Churches .
 Fairfield served in 1950 as administrative secretary of the National Council of Churches of Christ in the United States . Fairfield was a member of the planning committee that established the council of churches in the US .
 He was called up in 1951 to lend his extraordinary organizational and executive ability to Church World Service . He was the head of the National Council of Churches' department .
 He was executive director of this organization until his retirement in 1954 . He served as executive director for this organization .
 Fairfield was honored by the Turkish Red Crescent Society . He was made a life member and received the society’s medal in recognition of assistance given the Bulgarian Moslem refugees .
 Queen Juliana of the Netherlands presented him with the Order of Cranje Nassau in appreciation of aid given to the Dutch people during floods in 1953 . The Order was presented to him in appreciation for aid given during the floods .
 Fairfield went to Japan on behalf of the OberlinChansi Memorial Association . Fairfield was writing a history of the association at the time of his death .
 Fairfield gave heavily of his time and efforts to the strengthening of the American Council of Voluntary Agencies . Fairfield contributed greatly to the organization's continuing success .
 Fairfield leaves two sons, Frederic W Fairfield of Farmington, Mich, and John F Fairfield, a missionary of the United Church Board for World Ministries in Tokyo, Japan . Seven grandchildren and one greatgranddaughter also leave behind .

 In the town manager system, the administrative detail described by the Greenfield selectmen is placed in the hands of the town's town manager . This allows the selectmen for thorough study of the broad policy matters facing the town .
 The selectmen have responsibility for appraising the effectiveness of the manager’s administration since he serves at their pleasure . Over and above the consideration of policy, however, they have responsibility to appraise the effectiveness .
 The town manager must maintain political leadership when issues relating to the town’s administration threaten to entrap the manager in local politics . Furthermore, they must maintain leadership when they must be in charge of town administration .
 Town officials still remain the town’s ‘selected men’ and can furnish invaluable assistance to a town manager by interpreting public opinion on issues . They can also offer knowledge of a town's traditions and aspirations .
 Since Saugus accepted the manager plan in 1948, 22 towns have introduced enabling legislation in the General Court . The citizens of 12 of these towns have accepted it .
 The various acts parellell the duties and responsibilities established under the Saugus plan . There are certain modifications reflecting local situations and circumstances .
 The manager’s power to appoint varies somewhat from town to town for the positions that he might fill in theory may he the responsibility of the electorate, selectmen, or moderator rather than his .
 In Shrewsbury, the town clerk and town treasurer-collector are elected . The town accountant and town counsel are appointed by the selectmen . The finance committee and the personnel board are also appointed .
 Town of Ipswich has two enabling acts dealing with professional town management . The latter act calls for the establishment of a ‘town manager’ to be designated as executive secretary . Town manager is the town manager of the Ipswich Town Council .
 The 1949 statute called for the office of a town manager with complete authority for supervising and directing the administration of all departments, commissions, and boards, except the board of selectmen, the school committee, trust fund commissioners, election officers, and registrars of voters .
 "His authority to reorganize, consolidate or abolish departments, boards, commissions, and offices under his direction was singular," he said .
 The power to appoint the planning hoard was vested entirely in the person of the town manager . Hoard of public welfare, health, and public welfare were also vested in the power of the mayor .
 dissatisfaction with provisions of the enabling act brought about the submission of ‘remedial’ legislation to the General Court in 1954 . However, in the course of these four years dissatisfaction with the provisions of an enabling act was unsatisfied with .
 This act was quickly approved by the state legislature and subsequently by the citizens of Ipswich . Ipswich residents voted for the act to be approved by Ipswich police .
 The legislation broadens the authority of the hoard of selectmen by charging them with the responsibility for “formulating a general policy for administering the affairs of the town’s . Selectmen can direct and advise the town manager in any matters pertaining to the duties of his office .
 Ipswich has been the only one town to weaken the position of town manager . Of the 13 towns with ‘strong manager’ charters, Ipswich only one has weakened the position . Ipswich is the only town with a 'strong manager' charter .
 The manager is responsible for the efficient administration of all departments, boards, and commissions under his jurisdiction .
 He should make recommendations to the selectmen on such matters as he thinks desirable, he says . He should also make recommendations for the selectman to make .
 He may reorganize, abolish, or consolidate departments, boards, and commissions under his direction . He may also reorganize or consolidate boards, commissions and commissions .
 He must purchase all supplies, materials, and equipment with the usual statutory exception to hooks for schools . He must also purchase all materials, materials and equipment .
 He is required to keep the selectmen informed of the financial condition of the town and its future needs . He is also required to report the town's financial condition .
 He must prepare and submit to the selectmen and finance committee his annual budget . He must submit his budget to the committee .
 He should keep the selectmen and indirectly the public informed about the operations of all aspects of the town’s government . Finally, he should also inform the public about the town government .
 Ten of the seventeen Massachusetts towns had been managers in other communities before they were hired for their present posts . Ten of those towns had previously managed in other towns .
 The remaining seven had previously served as assistants to managers, had held other positions in local government, or had come from governmental research work .
 Five managers arc products of the unique public management program conducted by the Univcr sity of Maine . The others arc from various schools with degrees in business, public amdinistration, or engineering . Five managers are products from the unique program .
 The average period of time they have served their present community is 3 and one-half years . Six of the seventeen have been in the same community for five or more years .

 They had a burning compulsion to know and suffered no censor but the internal censor of reason . They suffered no censors but internal censors of reason, they said . They had no censor, they suffered no censorship, they added .
 On these two commandments, engraved at the Delphic shrine, hung all the Greek law and the prophets . The two commandments were engraved in the Delphi shrine .
 Unashamed by the beauty and joy of the body, they celebrated life in sculpture and in fact, free of inhibiting fears, they said .
 In this celebration they founded an art, a literature, a science, a philosophy, a society in which the requirements of mind and body were related in balance . The celebration was a celebration of an art and literature, literature, science and a philosophy .

 The Greeks, writes Miss Hamilton, were the first people who knew how to play . The Greeks were first people to play the game .
 For them the athletic event itself embodied the human genius in a splendid concert of mind and body . For them, they said the Olympic Games was an example of a human genius .

 In the later Greek religion, ethics preceded magic and no idea that could not stand up under critical inquiry was considered worth holding . In Homeric myths, ethics before magic was considered to be ethics .

 While in training at this South Texas Air Training Command Air Force base, he was taught the fundamentals of electronics, dead reckoning and radar navigation as pertains to today's rapidly advancing Aerospace Force .
 Bingham has been assigned to Keesler AFB, Miss., for advanced training . Bingham will be stationed in Mississippi for the next two years .

 In the manufacture of paper, the fibrous stock is subject to treatment which reduces it to uniformly fine particles and forms it into a wet sheet or web that is processed into the finished paper .
 It often happens that the wet sheet contains fibrous masses or aggregates of random sizes and shapes . The wet sheet is often filled with random masses of random shapes and sizes .
 These masses are undesirable for paper making and many devices and processes have been proposed to avoid their formation . Paper making is difficult to make with masses of paper .
 Fibrous masses, if of controlled sizes and high density, have numerous filler for plastic molded articles, and as a carrier for chemicals such as medicines and insecticides . Fibrous mass can also be used as carrier for medicines such as insecticides and insecticide .
 It is desirable to have an efficient and inexpensive meth od and apparatus for producing them . Thus it is desirable for an efficient meth od .
 In accordance with their invention, the raw material is formed into a continuous wet* web or sheet . The web is directed onto the conventional endless wire screen used in the manufacture of paper .
 As the web is advanced on the screen, it is cut into eontinuour ribbons by water jets impinging against it . Water jets are impinging on the web, cutting it into ribbons .
 The ribbons are then subjected to the action of a scuffing belt and associated devices . They are cut into predetermined lengths which are rolled tightly and dried to form fibrous nodules or masses that are of desired weight and size .
 The fibrous aggregates or masses of their invention may be made from the usual cellulose paper-making materials, from synthetic resins such as rayon and nylon, and from mineral fibers such as asbestos and glass fibers .
 Plastic molding material may be used as an inert carrier for various chemical compositions . Insecticides, fertilizers, soil conditioners and the like are released or leached out gradually .
 This patent has been assigned to Arthur D Little, Inc., Inc., Cambridge, Mass. This patent was filed in the United States in 1994 . The patent is pending pending litigation in the U.S.

 Mr Lord asked to do the program after having heard the station on the air during a previous visit to the state . Mr Lord had contacted Thomas A Morse, WHRS faculty advisor and assistant principal .
 There was also a pantomime view of members of Modern Problems class in a discussion, something which the station often broadcasts .
 Mr Lord did a short tape interview at the same time the Parent-Faculty Association sponsored Gisela von Klueke from Berlin .
 It is in its sixth year of operation and has been picked up as far away as Plymouth, Mass. It's in its 6th year and has picked up locations around the world .
 It serves you with music, discussions and radio-drama programs; high school sports broadcasts; and civic events including the all important town meeting live as it happens . It also includes live sports broadcasts and live radio dramas .

 WHSR owes its existence to the Rotary Club, donors of its original equipment, still in good repair . WHSR is now a national radio network .

 Student work ip this field is entirely extra-curricular and does not earn course credit . However, the station is a valuable adjunct to both Speech and Modern Problems courses .

 High school seniors and graduates have until November 17 to apply for the Navy’s Reserve Officer Training Corps .
 Designed to supplement the officer output of the Naval Acudemy, the NROTC program makes it possible for a young man to earn a regular commission while studying at a civilian college of his choice which has an NROTc unit .
 All tuition, fees and hooks are furnished by the Navy, and the student receives an annual retainer of $600 for not more than four years . The student receives $600 per year for the duration of the course .
 After completing the usual four year college course, he is commissioned in the Regular Navy or Marine Corps and goes on active duty as a prospective career officer in the Naval service .
 He receives the same promotional opportunities, duty assignments and benefits as his Naval Academy contemporary . The Naval Academy graduate is a graduate of the Naval Academy .
 High school seniors and graduates who have reached the 17th anniversary of birth on July 1, 19(52) may apply for the NROTC aptitude test .
 A real economy item for the student who likes all his notes in one neat volume . The volume contains all notes in a neat volume and easy to read .

 The book was written by Cynthia Barone in collaboration with her husband, Dr. Dr. Richard Barone .
 These pictures really add much to the book, and they would be great sport shots, even without their Bellino angle .
 There are also inside pictures of life at Annapolis that are out of the ordinary for a book of this sort .
 A tremendous amount of time and effort must have gone into amassing these shots and getting permission to use them . A lot of time must have been spent amassing the photos and getting them approved .
 Much could have been told about Bellino but was withheld for the sake of brevity . It is well covered in the Barones’ book, skill being shown in tne selection of material .
 The book is not intended to be a complete biography of this remarkable young man who has been held up to the world as a top example of American youth and sportsmanship .
 The book is cleanly printed and attractively bound, with large photos of Joe in midshipman’s uniform and football togs on the jacket . Within its covers is an interesting story of Bellino's life written by two true admirers .

 Joe was the first midshipman in 42 years to win both these coveted Navy awards . He was the only Navy back ever to score three touchdowns against Army . Joe was also the only back to score 3 touchdowns against the Army defense .
 The pictures of the various trophies and awards amassed by Joe during his schoolboy and academy days are among the most interesting in the book . As a matter of fact the pictures of Joe's awards and trophies amassed by the former Manchester United star are among most interesting .

 The sulfa drugs, penicillin, terramycin and tranquilizers are signs of medical progress during the past 20 years .
 The compound used in that tranquilizer, chlorpromazine, was discovered in France and initially used in surgery, he said .
 SK&F purchased the rights to the compound and supported an intensive two-year research program before introducing it to physicians in America . SKF is the first company to use the compound in the U.S.
 Before tranquilizers, half the hospital beds in America were occupied by mental patients . Before the tranquilizer, half of America's hospital beds had been occupied by mentally patients . The tranquilizers were used to treat mental illness .
 In 11.56, for the first time in history, the number of hospitalized mental patients was reduced . In 11)56, the hospitalization of mental patients in the U.S. was reduced to less than 1,000 .
 Last year the pharmaceutical industry spent $200,000,000 to make such advances possible, Driscoll said . Such advances are made possible through research, he said .
 Smith Kline & French is spending $18,500,000 in its search for new health products in 1960 . In 1960, the company was spending more than $18 million on health products .
 Because of rapid research advances, “the life of a new drug today has been estimated to be only from two to five years,” he says . “The life of the new drugs today has to be estimated from 2 to 5 years.”
 Nine of every 10 prescriptions written today are for drugs that simply did not exist 20 years ago . The drugs are now available in the United States for the first time .
 To assure the patient gets “just what the doctor ordered,” exhaustive testing and quality control during manufacturing processes are required on each compound .
 A single anti-ulcer medication is checked at SK&F 1170 times to assure its purity . The purity of the medication is also being checked every single dose .
 The average American spent a total of $11.5 for prescriptions in 1959, according to Department of Commerce studies . According to Department o Commerce studies, the average American spend $11 .
 Department studies show that drug prices have gone up about half as much as the increase of other items . Drug prices have increased about half the increase in other items, Mr Driscoll said .
 A survey by “American Druggist’s’ magazine indicates the average prescription cost is now $3.14 . The average cost of prescription drugs is now about $3 .14 .

 Bob Munstedt (Mr Bob), comedian, ventriloquist and ouppeteer, will present a one-man 'fun show' with a variety of acts .
 At that time ho lived in Switzerland, where he toured the neighborhoods with his puppet show . The puppet show was a success in Switzerland .
 During World War II he served in the Air Corps, Special Service, as staff sergeant . He served as a staff sergeant during the Second World War .
 Alex Smallwood was a member of the 312th Bomb Group in World War II . He carried his barracks bag and carbine, but also his accordion and wooden pal, Alex .
 In spare moments from his duties Bob entertained soldiers (and sailors) wherever they were ... in hospitals, on shipboard, in Red Cross centers, or just in open-air jungle theaters .
 Bob, with or without his various puppets, has appeared many times on WBZ-TV television . Bob and Alex have the distinction of having appeared on the very first telecast of that station . Bob, Alex and Bob have appeared on many occasions .
 On Thursday afternoon the hildren’s entertainment will be cartoon films, also at 3:45m. The hilders will be entertained by cartoon films .

 If anyone had told him, a short while ago, that his 1961 Cadillac could be improved on — he would have regarded them with disbelief . He would now be surprised to be able to drive his classic 1961 Cadillac .
 After only half an hour in the newest ,f car of cars”, he knows that a year of Cadillac progress has made a world of difference .
 Cadillac's 1962 version of the Cadillac One-Cadillac One was released in October 1962 . Cadillac's first model of the 1962 Cadillac One was unveiled in September 1962 . The Cadillac One One was designed to be a classic sports car .
 For added beauty, there is a lower, longer silhouette . There is also a new interior elegance and luxury . For more simplicity and dignity of line, there's greater simplicity .
 For improved comfort, there is increased spaciousness . New convenience of appointments . and a ride that is unbelievably quiet and smooth . The ride is extremely quiet .
 For increased safety , there is a new dual braking system ... a new three-phase rear warning light system . And new cornering lights that illuminate your way around turns . For more safety .
 Even Cadillac quality has been enhanced for 1962, Cadillac says . Cadillac quality was enhanced in 1962, says Cadillac .
 The car continues to be built to the highest standards that can be brought to the production of an automobile . But the truth is simply that the car is simply being built to a high standard .
 The Cadillac Grand Prix will be the first time a car has been driven by a Cadillac . Cadillac will be driven by the company's new owner, Cadillac co-founder Steve Lemmon . Lemmon says he's happy to demonstrate a difference a year can make .

 Mavis McGrath of the wollknown McGrath Travel Service of Woburn, has returned from a month’s trip to Rurope .
 She left Boston in the evening on a Pan American arriving in London the following day . She arrived in London on the following morning .
 All arrangements in Russia were made by Intourist, the Russian State Tourist office . Miss McGrath’s eight days in Russia included four days in Moscow .
 Miss McGrath visited the Mausoleum on October 3rd . Stalin held just as prominent a spot as Lenin .
 From Moscow, a one hour flight on a Russian Jet took Miss McGrath for a four day stay at the Astoria Hotel in Leningrad . She was accompanied by a Russian jet from Moscow .
 Her English speaking Intourist guide accompanying her while sightseeing in the former St. Louis suburb of St. Charles .
 The Winter Palace, the Hermitage, Peter and Paul Fortress are among the most famous landmarks in St. Petersburg . St. Peter's Winter Palace is one of Russia's most famous museums .
 From Leningrad, Miss McGrath returned to Moscow with her guide and then flew via Russian Jet to Prague .
 Strahov 11th Century Monastery, now a museum, former palaces, which are now embassy residences and many fine restaurants such as Praha which was displayed at the World’s Fair in Brussels .
 From Nice to Cannes she went on to Cannes to attend the 31st World Travel Congress of the American Society of Travel Agents . She was the secretary of the New England Chapter of American Society .
 After a week at Cannes, Miss McGrath flew to Brussels, where she spent three days visiting Brussels, Ghent and Bruges .

 The world’s largest cymbal is being seen, and heard, by 50,000 flth-to-lOth grade Greater Boston students this school year . The “World of Sound’� program at Boston's Museum of Science features the world's largest
 The science of sound is explained with the help of some ingenious visual aids and sound effects . Its purpose is to explain the science of the sound .
 The ninth annual School Visit Program is the most effective yet in generating enthusiasm for science among local public, parochial and private school students, educators say .
 The program is sponsored by the Metropolitan District Commission and planned and conducted by the Museum’s Education Department .
 Sounds are created by many different methods at the Museum's Morse Auditorium . The lecture-demonstration is seen Tuesdays through Fridays in the Museum’s Morse auditorium .
 They range from heating a grid in an eight-foot Pyrex gl^ss tube to catching a whisper from the back of the auditorium in an 8-foot parabolic reflector .
 Students giggle delighted as the lecturer changes his voice by breathing in a mouthful of helium . Or sings a musical scale by snipping off the end of a drinking straw, bit by bit .
 With a giant ear model, as big as himself, he reveals some of the wonders of the human ear . The human ear brings humans more information about the world than any other sense .
 A wave simulator, a 10-foot line of tiny lighted bulbs that forms giant mechanical waves to explain amplitude and frequency of sound waves . An ear analog, an electronic device that shows how the nerves in the cochlea respond to various frequencies . Other visual aids include a wave
 Immaculate Conception School of Winchester was among school groups attending the School Visit Program this past week at the Museum . School groups attended the Museum's School Visit program .

 Three students from Winchester, the Misses Marilyn Beckley, Martha Maloney and Susan Wallace are members of the 150voice Wellesley College Choir . The college opened its 1961-62 season on Sunday, November 5, with the traditional Fall Vesper Concert at the college .
 Later this season the choir will present concerts with the glee club of Williams and Hamilton Colleges, and will give their traditional Christmas and baccalaureate vesper concerts .
 Choir members sing at daily and Sunday chapel service on the campus . In addition, choir members sing in chapel service .
 Miss Maloney is the daughter of Mr and Mrs. Maloney . She is a first-year student at the University of Cambridge .
 Miss Wallace is a sophomore at Wellesley and her parents arc Mr and Mrs. Mrs. Wallace . She is also a junior at Harvard University .
 Miss Beckley and Miss Maloney are Winchester High School graduates, while Miss Wallace prepared for college at Abbot Academy in Andover . Miss Wallace is a senior member of the Winchester High Class .

 The signature of the Town Accountant and the State Director of Accounts on warrants to pay excess expenditures is required before the Selectmen can finally approve the bills and authorize the Town Treasurer to pay them . The Town Treasurer is required to sign the warrants on excess expenditures .

 Town Pays $25,000 for a 1.1 acre lot of land on Dennett Road, which the Town will use as a playground . The South Border Road Corporation has received a payment of $ 25,000 .
 The Town’s purchase of the property was authorized by the Town Meeting of March, 1961 . The Town purchased the property in 1961 . It is now owned by the town .
 The negotiations for the sale of the land were conducted with the South Border Road Corporation by Town Counsel Vincent P Clarke and the Board of Park Commissioners .
 The corporation received a rebate of $31.97 for the full year’s taxes it has already paid to the Town . The Town received the rebate for the year's taxes they have already paid .
 The rebate covered the period from October 9 when the Board of Park Commissioners decided to take the land until December 31 of this year . The rebate covers the period between October 9 and December 31 .

 Winchester Emergency Committee has mailed Winchester residents appeal brochures describing WGBH plans for rebuilding . Winchester residents are urged to help WGB and Channel 2 rebuild after fire .
 Listeners and viewers who are grateful for the excellence of the WGBH and Channel 2 programs are being asked to contribute toward a goal of over $1,500,000 needed for a permanent building and equipment . The goal is to raise enough money for new equipment and permanent building .
 To date $285,000 of the needed $1,500,000 has been mailed to the station from the listening area . To date the station has received more than $300,000 from listeners .

 These signs and symptoms help your doctor decide if he should examine your child for strep infection . The symptoms include strep fever, strepiness, fatigue, fever, and streptonia .
 Only your doctor can tell if your child has a strep infection . Your youngster isn’t likely to have all these symptoms . Only you can tell your child if you have strep .
 Your job is to report any of these signs and symptoms as soon as you notice them so that your doctor can start treatment right away . Report any signs of these symptoms to your doctor .
 This is how you help the doctor protect your child against rheumatic fever . This is the first time you've seen a doctor who has treated your child with a form of fever .

 Winchester Art Association sponsoring watercolors and woodcuts by Robert Grady in Winchester Library . Winchester Art . Association sponsoring an exhihii tion of water .colors . and woodcut by Grady .
 When asked by some of his Winchester students why he has departed from the strictly representational art demanded of beginning students, he explains the attitude of those who paint more creatively .
 Nature is used as a point of departure, and the artist progresses to more creative expression, perhaps to more abstract forms . The artist is using nature as a starting point to express himself .
 Some of the pictures in the library start to depart into more abstract forms, but the symbols of nature are still recognizable . The library contains more than 1,000 images of nature .
 His woodcuts, especially, are strong, simple, and may appeal to some more than the watercolors . The woodcuts are strong .
 The woodcut “Bob” attempts to show the strength of his father’s face and hands, and it succeeds in both expression and design . It is a woodcut attempt to show his father's strength .
 The areas of design are first indicated in color, and, while still wet, the outlines of boats, figures, etc., are drawn in ink, which runs some what into the watercolor . The outlines are drawn by ink in ink .
 The "Pond" has been purchased by the De Cordova Museum for its permanent collection . The “Pond’s’ ‘Pond,’ has been bought by the museum .
 All these pictures are worthy of much study by the aspiring painter, and by those who wish to understand more about different types of art .
 These pictures will hang in the North Reading room until the end of November .

 Winchester selectmen should not serve beyond the three-year term for which they art* elected . Winchester must come to grips some time with the issue .
 The Star was discussing this single three-year term thinking with a particularly capable former town officer recently and found he was not at all sold on it . The Star found that the idea of a town officer being a mayor is not alluring .
 "We were interested and pleased to get his concurrence. As we have questioned its value, we were interested," he said. "As we have had several occasions questioned the value of its value."
 The three-year term for selectmen was not primarily enacted here to prevent continuity in office . It was intended to protect continuity of office, not to prevent change .
 It was adopted to relieve a candidate for the hoard of the stress and expense of standing for re-election for a second term or more . Rather, it was adopted as a way of relieving a candidate of the .
 Desirable candidates were becoming increasingly reluctant to wage the campaign necessary for election more than once, and it was felt that if a candidate could be elected for three years, instead of yearly, more and better candidates would be attracted .
 Most selectmen in the days preceding the voting of the three-year term ran for no more than three years . This was not always the case. Most selectman in the . days before the voting, the . elections were held in the early days .
 As the years rolled by and the duties of selectmen became more and more complex and time-consuming, incumbents seldom served for more than three years . There were exceptions, notably that of Walter H Dottcn, who served for seven years .
 Holding office as a selectman today however, is entirely different from such service in the days of Messrs. Messrsrs. William Jennings and Mrs. Jennings . Jennings: "Holding office in such an office was entirely different"

 Albert Horn, teacher of piano for 20 years both in Winchester and Boston, has moved into handsome new studio quarters at the recently renovated Center railroad depot .
 The new studio is spacious and nicely decorated, equipped with a Sohmer grand piano . The studio is located in New York City .

 The New Waterways Committee Would very much appreciate the publication of this letter in order that the residents of Winchester may be kept apprised of the latest developments .
 At the Adjourned Annual Town Meeting of March 24, 1958, the Town voted a sum of $12,500.00 to be used in dredging and improving the Aherjona River from Swanton Street to a point near the Winchester Post Office .
 All work so done would be with the assistance of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, under Chapter 91 of the General Laws . All work would be done in Massachusetts .
 At the Adjourned Town Meeting of April 4, I960. The Committee informed the Town that under Chapter 91, the Commonwealth was interested in projects involving Hood control only .
 On October 20, 1961, the Town was informed by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Waterways Division that bids for the project had been received . The Town of Watertown was informed that bids had already been received for a project .
 The low bid was for $29,200.00, and engineering and contingency fees of $7,900.00 would bring the total cost of the project to $20,500.00 . They advised that the low bid for the project was $29.00 and that engineering
 The contract would he awarded and the undertaking would he under way . They further advised that upon the receipt of the Town’s check for 6(K» of this amount, or $18,250.00 .
 Inasmuch as the appropriation for the work fell $5,750.00 short of the needed amount, the Committee was in a dilemma . The Committee was unable to come up with the money needed to complete the work .
 The New Waterways Committee decided that., time-wise, it had only had two choices . After deliberation with the Board of Park Commissioners, the committee decided that. After due deliberation .
 The first, and not acceptable, Was to inform the Commonwealth that the . payment of $18,250.00 exceeded the authorized expenditure, and that the undertaking . must be postponed pending a subsequent Town Meeting when the additional funds might be allocated .
 This seemed unwise, in that there would be a great possibility of the Commonwealth putting Winchester far down the list of proposed projects, and the opportunity to obtain State aid might be lost in the foreseeable future . Winchester is one of the most important universities in the state of the country .
 The second choice of our Committee was to try to make emergency funds available in order that contracts might be signed immediately . Emergency funds were made available to sign contracts immediately, the committee said .
 On November 12, 1961, the Town of Winchester Finance Committee approved the transfer of $5,750.00 from the Town Reserve Account to our budget . The transfer of the money was approved by the Town's Finance Committee .
 We can now negotiate a contract with the Commonwealth, and work, we hope, will commence soon . We hope to see a contract soon .

 A recent “no fix” law requires a quarterly audit of all tickets issued by the police, whether or not they result in court appearance . Though no additional clerical provision has been made, the new law requires quarterly audit .
 The Woburn Court will have to audit thousands of such tickets quarterly . It is expected that the court will also have to auditors thousands of tickets quarterly.
 Even prior to the adoption of the ‘no fix’ law, the court had outgrown its facilities . Even before the law was adopted, it had been outgrown .
 Other proceedings that come before the court include commitment of insane persons, petitions for allowance of marriage of male under 18 and female under 16 . Petition for attachment of motor vehicles, permission for attach ment of wages for personal labor or services .
 The Woburn Court is ranked 14th of the 72 district courts based on 1960 census figures . It is the only district court in the UK that has a jurisdiction of 72 courts in the country .
 The area population served by the court has increased from 77,000 in 1950 to 125,000 since 1961 . The population of the court in the 1960s has increased to almost 100,000 .
 Four with two full time judges and 27 with smaller area populations than the Fourth District that are designated full time courts are eluded in the thirteen larger courts . In eluded are four with two judges, two full-time judges, 27 with small area populations .
 The Fourth District Court of Eastern Middlesex was ranked 26th in a 1950 report . In 1950 a comparable report of the Administrative committee of District Courts ranked the Fourth District .

 These figures show a younger typically American who is settling in cities and suburbs and is having it better than ever before financially . The figures show that a younger, typically typically American, is settling into a city and suburbs .

 Seventy per cent of all Americans are now living in cities or suburbs of them . 70 per cent now live in the suburbs or cities .

 Americans are tending to become more and more alike . Mere numbers of population, however, are not so important as the fact that Americans are becoming more like .
 In the past population tended to be regimented along ethnic lines . Now inter-marrying racial and and national origins are becoming less apparent .
 In 1900 about 90 per cent of all Negroes in America lived in the South . For instance in 1900, about 90% of all African Americans lived in South .
 Last year only (50 per cent still lived there with many of the other forty per cent coming to Northern cities . 50 per cent of the population still live in the UK .
 American people generally are becoming more mobile, one out of five moving each year, often out of state . One of five people in the U.S. move each year .
 Census authorities discount the claim that retired in great numbers are flocking to Florida and California . Census authorities say retired people are moving to the states to retire .
 The last named has a lower percentage of retired persons than the national average . The national average has a less than 50% of retired people .
 Several states, including New Hampshire and Vermont, have about as many people over 05 as Florida . Several states have more than 50% of their population .
 In the face of Russia’s growing agricultural problem, American farm acreage is maintaining its size and productivity . U.S. farmers are still growing in Russia's agricultural problem .
 Our problem is in the decline in the number of farms and farmers, experts say . Small farms are being consolidated into fewer big farms, they say . The number of farmers in the country has declined in recent years .
 More Americans are being born than ever before and they are living longer, resulting in higher percentages of both young and aged people . More people are now living longer .
 Over a 10 year span births have brought the median American age down from just over 30 years to just under 30 years . This in the face of increased longevity .
 The average American family is smaller, 3. persons, with relatives having a greater tendency to live in separate homes . The average family size is 3.3 persons .
 In real income, what money would buy in 19(50, the increase was from $4,000 to $5,600, making for a markedly better standard of living . The increase in real income makes for a better standard living .

 The typical American family lives in a house they own, usually of five rooms, usually in the suburbs or city fringe . Owning a car, radio, TV and many appliances, the typical American American family owns a house .
 They may have a mortgage on their home and owe for their car and some appliances . They may also owe for some of their car, some appliances and some other things .

 The income of the Negro family has risen faster than that of the white, though it still is not near the white level . The income is still not as high as the white .

 Dr. Terzaghi and Ferris Voted Moles Outstanding Achievement Awards . Dr. Ferris was awarded the "Best Moles" award in 1961 .
 The announcement was made at a dinner meeting of The Moles, an association of leading figures in the tunneling, dambuilding and heavy construction industry .
 Formal presentation of the honors will be at the annual Moles' Awards dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel next January 31 .
 Terzaghi and Ferris make up the 22nd pair of honorees elected president in 1953 and hoard in a series that started in 1941 and chairman in 1960 . Ferris was elected chairman of the board in 1960 and Terzagli was elected president of Italy in 1953 .
 He played prinnumbers among its winners former President Herbert Hoover, Robert Moses, Ben Moreell, Peter Kiewit, Harvey Slocum, John Bruce Bonny and Lou Perini .
 The award is considered the highest recognition that can be accorded for service to the American construction industry . KARL TERZAGHI was awarded the award for his work in the construction industry.
 Announcement of the selections was made by Eugene G Rau, Award Committee chairman . Announcement was made at the request of Eugene Rau .
 Terzaghi was born in 1883 in Prague, then Bohemia, and has wide experience in teaching and in the execution of significant engineering projects in Europe and in this country . He has been awarded a Nobel Prize for his work in Switzerland .
 Reclamation Service driller worked on construction of the Celilo locks on the Columbia river .
 In 1916 he returned to Europe and taught at the Imperial School of Engineers in Istanbul . It was while there he developed most of the basic principles of modern soil mechanics .
 For five years he was engaged in a massive program of air base construction for the Navy in the Pacific Area . For the next five years, he worked for the U.S. Navy .
 President Obama directed a program covering more than $360 million worth of procurement, shipping and construction . He marshaled the forces of American contractors .
 Mr Ferris joined the Raymond company, then known as Raymond Concrete Pile, in 1946 . He was cipal roles in organizing and managing the $350-million Spanish bases program, the huge Hyperion outfall project off Los Angeles .

 We recall the time he nearly succeeded in getting a four-inch advertisement for tickets to the Woburn game, placed squarely in the middle of the hack page of the Star .
 The late “T.P.” went upstairs to the press room three steps at a time, instead of the usual two, when he saw that page of the press proofs . “The late ‘T.I.P.'’s’ went upstairs
 He invited the editor, then more or less of a cub reporter, to give a few tips to reporters for the high school newspaper . Another time he asked the editor to give some tips to other cub reporters . The editor is now an editor at the school .
 We visualized five or six more or less uninterested hoys and girls waiting for us to get through, with our helpful hints . We were shocked as we opened the door of the high school room designated to find the entire class in journalism .
 Any large number of youthful listeners can be terrifying to the uninitiated . When you add a sprinkling of English teachers to watch your split infinitives you have the makings of an oratorical blue funk .
 Had we known in advance what the odds would be, we would have done much better. Suffice it to say that had we known the odds, we'd have done better .
 Hayward rating as a stirrer-upper, and we might also add feuds with the late ‘Squire’ Franklin, a bosom buddie, but not beyond the humorous touch . These two examples should indicate the Hayward rating .

 Massachusetts leads New Eng land in the total number of reporting union organizations with 1814 . Massachusetts leads the state in the union land in total reporting organizations . Massachusetts has 1814 union organizations .
 Connecticut has 801, Rhode Island 329, Maine 303, New Hampshire 235, and Vermont 186 .

 David C\ McLean is son of Dr. and Mrs. McLean . McLean Globe Worker Under Newspaper Fund Program David C. Mclean . David C
 A student at Bowdoin College, McLean received a $500 grant, and worked at the Boston ( ilobc) office .
 The project, in its second year, was designed to appeal to students in colleges where relatively little recruiting for newspaper careers has been done .
 Promising young men who thought they were interested in newspaper work, hut who lacked contacts in the field, were asked to apply for summer jobs .
 The Newspaper Fund served as a clearing house and screened the applications . The newspaper fund is used to screen applications for the project .
 Some students were directed to newspapers which were willing to employ one or more of the trainees for the summer months . The trainees were asked to train in order to be employed by newspapers .
 Other applicants were encouraged to seek summer news jobs on their initiative . The initiative is based on a summer news initiative .
 The individual newspaper made the final choice of the student and offered him a summer job . The student was offered the job by the individual newspaper .
 All arrangements were made between the trainee and the newspaper employing him . All arrangements for salary, hours and duties were made .
 Paul Swensson, executive Director of The Newspaper Fund, said that the summer’s efforts with the program are measuring up to expectations . The newspaper Fund is a nonprofit that supports journalism education and journalism .
 Many of the students, benefittng from their experience, are making plans for careers in journalism .
 Many editors have arranged for the students to continue their work on a part time basis during the school year . Students will be able to continue to work part time during the year .
 Students invited to apply for jobs next summer after graduation . Others have invited students to apply next summer for summer jobs .
 Letters which The Newspaper Fund has received from college students and the editors summarize the progress of the program . Letters from students and editors highlight the progress in the project .
 I had turned down a chance to go to Europe, preferring to try for a newspaper job under The Newspaper Fund program . I was offered a job in Europe but turned down the chance to work in Europe .
 The experience was my baptism in covering something about which I was utterly ignorant, dealing with a story on the spot and having to finish it quickly, and working side by side with the regular reporters . It was my "baptury in covering"

 Postmaster Thomas J Gilgun launched his 1961 ‘Mail Early For Christmas’ campaign . Gilgun said today as he launched the 1961 “Mail Early for Christmas” campaign .
 Postmaster: Here are the things to watch to help in getting every Christmas card and package delivered before December 25th .
 Be sure each address is complete with full name, street and number, city, zone and state . Be sure that the address is accurate .
 Remember, also, that you can include your Christmas card or letter inside your gift packages if you will add the appropriate First Class mail stamps to the postage for the package itself . Add the appropriate stamps to your gift package if you want to include your card .
 By doing this soon, you’ll save lots of time that might be spent standing in line later on . By doing so, you'll save time that may be spent waiting in line .
 All cards sent by 4 cents postage may include a personal handwritten message . They'll be forwarded or returned, if necessary .
 It’s socially correct to do this, and enables both you and your friends to keep your mailing lists up-to-date . It's social correct to keep up with your friends and enable them to keep their lists updated .
 Postmaster predicts that this year’s Christmas mail will set an all time record . 850,000 pieces handled in pre-holiday season of 1960 . Postmaster points out the importance of planning your Christmas mailings now .
 Christmas cards and packages dispatched and delivered before Christmas Eve . He said that through the excellent cooperation of the public during recent Christmas seasons, he has been able to get all of the cards .

 Baldwin W Callahan, Minister of Missions and Stewardship of the Massachusetts Congregational Christian Conference, will speak at> the Second Congregualational Church . Callahan is a minister of Missions .
 From 1929 to 1949 he was pastor of the First Congregational Church in Gardner, Massachusetts . During that time he served the denomination in a variety of ways, such as Dean of the Pilgrim Fellowship Summer Conference, and member of the Executive Committee .
 In October 1949, he became Minister of Missions and Stewardship for the Massachusetts Conference . In that capacity is now serving the six hundred churches of the Congregational Church in the state .
 His present work includes both missionary and stewardship promotion among our churches . He is also known for his efforts to promote stewardship of the church .
 He is preaching somewhere practically every Sunday . He speaks to many groups during the week on some phase of current Missionary or Stewardship interests .
 During the Spring of 1953, Mr Callahan was a participant in a six weeks’ study tour of the Congregational work in Hawaii, Japan, the Philippines, and Hong Kong .
 The Union Thanksgiving Service will he held in the First Congregational Church this year . The service will be on Wednesday evening, November 22 at 7:45 o’clock .
 Massed choir composed of choir members from six participating Churches will sing under direction of Mr Robert White, Choir Master of the Congregational Church .
 The Reverend Ralph B Putney of the Church of the Epiphany will give the sermon . The Ministers of all the Churches will take part in the service . The Reverend Putney will be giving the sermon at the end of the service.
 The Mother Church brings you this lecture . Reserved seats are available for those attending their first Christian Science lecture . All are welcome .

 Ed describes his favorite bridge situation, as dummy opposite a pretty girl . As guest editor this week, Ed talks about bridge situations . Ed describes the bridge situation .
 Duplicate bridge differs from contract play, as each N-S team competes against all other N.S teams . Duplicate play is also the case with the East-West teams, as is also with the West .
 Top scores are obtained in one of two ways; either in obtaining the best contract for your team, or preventing your opponents from obtaining theirs . Top scores can be obtained in either way; or in the best way to obtain your team's best contract .
 A perfect illustration of this occurred on Board 2, Section B, of last week’s duplicate session . Board 2: Section B of the duplicate session.
 North A J 8 4 V K 8 6 3 ♦ 9 8 5 A 10 8 5 West East East A A Q 3 V Q 7 4 V A J 10 9 5 ♦ A K 10 7 3 2 ♦ Q 6 * Q J 9 7 * K 6 1
 The AS was led, trumped in dummy in dummy, HQ played and finessed, a small heart continued and taken with the H9, Mrs. Mrs. Smith .
 Atkinson played the DQ, continued a small diamond to dummy’s DK, AD was played on which declarer parked her losing spade . The last trump was taken by declarer, clearing North of trumps, then conceded the AC, and made six hearts .
 The contract as played can be held to five if North refuses to trump any of dummy’s diamonds in which case declarer must lose hand . Declarer must also lose hand, making North's HK good . The contract is played as played .
 East-West teams were allowed to play this contract in either 4H or 51 1 . The teams were able to arrive at the contract because they were permitted communication at the lower bidding levels .
 West knew he had heart support for his partner, a void in spades (which would probably he the opening lead), diamond control and club support . West also had diamond control, club control, and club control .
 East knew from the bidding that her tcyim had heart and diamond control, she said . "I'm a fit in two suits," she said of her new owner .
 After East opens III, South bids four spades . Let us sec how the results would have been if after East opens .

 Analysis of South’s hand shows a minimum of eight sure tricks, and if there is even distribution in spades he has nine sure tricks . An analysis of South's hand shows there are nine sure trick cards .
 The MOST he can go down is 3 tricks, probably only one, and if his partner has one ace, or a King on the right side, 10 tricks are assured . The MENSENS can't go down at least three tricks .
 If North has no tricks, East-West may have a slam in any suit except spades . Even more important is if North has any tricks, it may have no tricks .
 A small slam in diamonds is unbeatable against any defense as can be seen . Ironically, a small slam of diamonds is a good defense . The diamond is a diamond .

 He was the game’s leading ground gainer with 81 yards in 18 carries . He carried four consecutive times inside the 10 yard line to get over on his touchdown buck from a yard out .
 Late in the game he made two important first downs that helped Virginia to run out the clock with South Carolina threatening . Virginia ran out of the clock in the final minutes of the game .
 A sophomore, he started the season at halfback, hut three weeks ago . He was shifted to fullback in an attempt to get more speed in that position . A sophomore at the University of Washington, he is a junior in the NFL .

 Jane Miller delivered a lecture on the origin and development of a museum . The De Cordova is not a museum, but a lively Art Center with all sorts of goings-on . Miller: "Any community can have an art center"
 The location should be in such a beautiful spot that people will go out of their way to go there, or it should be a central location, easily reached by all . The location, like that of the DeCordova Museum, should he .
 Julian De Cordova bequeathed his property on a hilltop overlooking Sandy Pond to the town of Lincoln . He also donated a considerable sum of money for its perpetual maintenance .
 He made no narrow specifications hampering its use other than the requirement that it be used as a public museum and park .
 One of the finest art centers in the United States has taken form . Fred P Walkey as executive director .
 The building, completely modernized, holds hanging exhibitions, and sponsors all forms of art, drama, music, poetry, poetry and the dance . The building is now a modern art museum .
 Classes are held in all types of creative art for both children and adults . Art classes are held for both adults and children .
 M iss Miller showed slides of museum activities, including exhibits, painting classes, festivals, festivals . Miller also showed slides from exhibits, art classes and festivals .
 She described enthusiastically the unique outdoor summer program of creative arts for children . She described it as a unique outdoor program of creativity .
 She told of the services to the surrounding communities, the talks and exhibits arranged for schools civic groups, and industries .
 A new wing is planned to acco| midate more classes and provide more space for exhibitions and administrative offices . The new wing will be planned to accommodate more classes .
 Membership includes priority on class lists, discounts on the purchases of books and reproductions, access to the lending library, notices exhibits, and other privileges .
 Winchester residents are already members of the Winchester Museum . Many Winchester residents already take an active part in the museum’s activities .

 Banks sell Bonds as a free service, distribute information about them, and furnish voluntary leadership . Some 70% of state Savings Bonds chairmen, 56% of county chairmen are bankers .

 Through sheer power of inspiration she has been the instigator of man’s finest achievements in music, art, literature, science, or invention .
 We fear that in imparting inspiration to man, she has, we fear, retained all too little for herself . In fields of creative art man reigns practically supreme .

 In 1048 Winchester’s assessors commenced a complete revaluation of all properties in town, a revalu ation that took about three years to complete . Winchester's assessors completed the revaluations in 1048 . Winchester is the first town to have reval
 Large area maps were prepared of the various sections of the town showing the individual properties by neighborhoods with their sale prices through the years, the unit value of land per square foot and the history of the assessing .
 Few, if indeed any other boards of assessors have such maps which were conceived and worked out to aid them in their work . The local hoard has maps which the local hoard conceived and developed .
 The maps are a valuable supplement to the usual property cards . They are used exclusively by the assessors in their valuation work . The maps will be used only by assessors .
 In Winchester the assessors arrive at valuations in the field, not around an office table . To aid them in their determination the big area maps go with them on their assessing trips .
 At any time it becomes necessary to look at an individual property in a neighborhood the assessors through their maps appraise; every piece of property in the immediate neighborhood, to see that the valuation of the property is proportionally sound .
 This procedure is followed whenever there is a sale of property or when there is structural change requiring a building permit . This procedure was followed when a structural change requires a permit .
 It is also used to assess new property in accordance with other properties in the immediate neighborhood . It also assesses new properties based on other properties nearby .
 When it is impossible to find comparable property near at hand the assessors cover the maps in the town to find such porperty elsewhere in their effort to adhere to their method of proportional assessing .

 Shown is the high school football team of 1927, of which Mr Knowlton was captain .
 This team were last to represent Winchester in the now defunct Mystic Valley League . They finished in a triple tie with Melrose and Arlington for the last championship of the circuit .
 Winchester beat Arlington, Melrose beat Winchester, Winchester beat Winchester and Melrose . Winchester beat Melrose 3-2 . Winchester defeated Melrose 2-2 at Melrose 1-1 .
 The league broke up when Winchester withdrew from its meral ‘rship, due to the fact that Arlington, Melrose and Watertown had grown too large for the Sachems . Winchester was then a relatively small school .
 Winchester did well in the league, but really had little chance for the championship . Winchester won the league in 2010, but didn't make it to the title .
 The 1927 team made Winchester football history by playing the first post-season game in which a local team has participated . Winchester's 1927 team played the first, and if memory serves, it was the only game in that way . Winchester has never played a game in a local football post-

 Declarer, however, played a small heart to the ace and return ed a heart which my partner took with the king . Declarer's partner took a heart with the ace, but his partner took the king with a heart .

 “The Old Rugged Cross” still is America’s favorite hymn . McVey: Hymns America Loves Best; Interest in Hymn Singing Increases . “Old Rugged cross” is America's favorite hymn .
 More than 61,000 newspaper readers from coast to coast voted in the recent National Newspapers Hymn Pull . 10,482 of them chose ‘The Old Rugged Cross’ as their dearest religious song .
 Analysts said this large vote doubtless was due to the song’s popularity at hymn sings across the country . Audience Analysts say it was likely to be due to its popularity in hymn sing .
 The third favorite hymn disclosed by the National Newspapers Hymn Pull was “What A Friend We Have in Jesus,” a song which has earned a place in Americans’ hearts .
 The Christian Herald Singer noted the rise in acceptance of “Amazing Grace’s” among American churchgoers . Singer: "Amazing Grace" is now accepted in the United States .
 This gospel song relates how faith provides confidence . It moved from ninth place in the 1960 Christian Herald hymn poll to fifth place in National Newspapers poll .
 The sixth favorite hymn of the 61,445 Americans who voted was ‘Rock of Ages’ The religious song describes man’s confidence in God .
 This hymn was 27th in the Christian Herald poll but moved to 10th in National Newspapers Hymn Poll . It is now 10th on the list of most popular hymns in the UK .
 This year's poll, co-sponsored by Christian Herald Magazine, recorded more than 1,900 hymns and gospel songs . Every state except Hawaii and Vermont, every state except Vermont, recorded songs . The poll is the nation’s largest interdenominational publication .
 McVey: American churchgoers do not prefer one type of religious song to another . He says it's the first definitive survey to determine the hymns America loves best . The survey was conducted by the National Institute of American Missions .
 The last two years have seen a constant controversy between hymnal editors and churchgoers . Churchgoers prefer hymns that have been the most inspiring to them and easiest for them to understand .
 National Newspapers Hymn Poll results show that American churchgoers want to sing sentimental hymns and gospel songs like ‘The Old Rugged Cross’ ” McVey said .

 He was a former member of William Parkmun Lodge of Masons . He was also a member of the Second Congregational Church of West Newton .
 His hobby was antique clocks and he made some 25 to 30 grandmother and Massachusetts mantel clocks . He also made Simon Willard banjo clocks .
 "An excellent craftsman, his models were beautifully done and universally admired," he said .
 In 1927 he married Elizabeth Carpenter of Newton and Martha’s Yineyard, and after their marriage they lived in Reading until 1939, going from that town to Newtonville . After their marriage, he moved from Reading to Reading, then from Newtonville, then Newtonville.
 Recently he married Marguerite Blanchard of Wellesley, who survives him with two daughters, Mrs. Mrs. Blancheard .
 His mother, living in Woifeboro, N.H., and two brothers, Roger W., of Wayland, and Dr. Haven, of Wellesley, are among his four grand-children . He also has two brothers and two sisters .

 She assisted her husband in conducting the business in emergencies often driving one of the old horse-drawn hacks in all sorts of weather .
 She continued the business after her husband’s death and into the era of the motor-driven cabs . The business is still in the Fitzgerald family, being run as a taxi business by her son, Frank .

 Thanksgiving Reflections Page Four . The Winchester Star looks at Thanksgiving in its entirety .
 Pilgrims gathered together for the first Thanksgiving feast through the dangers, suffering and death that beset them . It is thanks to God; gratitude to the Divine Spirit that has brought those gathered together .
 Thanksgiving to these same Pilgrims was not primarily a time for rejoicing, though they had every reason to rejoice . Thanksgiving was a time of rejoicing for the first time of year .
 It was a time to he grateful for the blessings of a Divine Providence and to ask God’s help in the years that were ahead . Rather than a time of gratitude, it was to be grateful for blessings of Divine Providence .
 The Pilgrims felt they had much for which to he thankful, and it was significant that their thanks was of giving, not getting . The Pilgrim's thanks were of giving not getting, not receiving .
 They wanted to return to the nc responsible for their well being something of the gifts they had received at His hands . They wanted something to be returned to them that had been given to them .
 Today Thanksgiving is much more the holiday than it is the holy day . The emphasis has been placed more on the mundane than on the spiritual aspects of the day .
 Thanksgiving has become a day for having fun rather than an occasion for acknowledging our blessings . A glance at the observance of Sunday today, and a comparison with the Sabbath conduct of bygone days, indicates why Thanksgiving is more fun than a holiday .
 The pilgrims, in their own way, enjoyed themselves on that occasion, and of course in olden times any sort of feast was the best sort of pleasure . The pilgrims' feast was a feast of the best kind of pleasure in old times .
 Governor Bradford called attention to the good things to eat and drink that were a part of the observance . Governor Bradford on that first Thanksgiving called attention . The first Thanksgiving was the first Thanksgiving of Thanksgiving .
 Pilgrims did not permit their holiday rejoicing to set aside, or even overshadow, the principal reason for the first Thanksgiving, which was gratitude to God . The first Thanksgiving was a Thanksgiving of thanksgiving to God, not rejoicing .
 In our enjoyment of Thanksgiving we would do well to remember the Pilgrim conception of this day . To remember the ‘giving’ part of Thanksgiving, to pay tribute to the Divine Providence which has blessed us .
 We have every reason to he thankful on this Thanksgiving, thanks to freedom of speech, freedom of worship and freedom of the press . We are especially grateful for the strengthening of that feeling of brotherhood that is prompting the more fortunate to help those in need .
 "The beginnings of mutual understanding and tolerance among men, creeds and nations is yet another reason for deep satisfaction"
 Let us not entirely forget the more sober side of Thanksgiving this year . Thanksgiving is a sober holiday .
 Perilous as arc the times, and dangerous as are the days in which we live, we still have much for which to render thanks . We still have a lot to give thanks to those who have helped us to survive .
 "The heritage we have received from our Pilgrim fathers, in itself is cause for thanksgiving and the dedication of ourselves anew to the principles for which they were willing to risk their lives in a strange new world," says President Obama .
 When liquor stores open and grocery stores close on Saturday holidays, the time has come to take a good, sober look at our Blue Laws .
 One of the first things that hits you in studying the Blue Laws is their complexity . The Blue Laws are complex and difficult to understand .
 We're not going to settle this issue in one editorial, no matter how sore we were last Saturday that we couldn’t buy hot dogs to go with our beans . And we’ve not settled this issue with one editorial . We’ll not settle it in one
 The Sabbath was made for man and not vice versa, according to the Bible . After all, if the* Bible tells us that we are to keep the Sabbath holy, it also says that the Sabbath was not for man .
 State laws forbid hunting on Thanksgiving, but we know that the Pilgrims did .
 We don’t like schoolboys to play ball on Sunday, because it’s not ‘holy,’ yet many of us think nothing of sitting hack with a can of beer in our living rooms and watching <>1,000 hooting fans see the Giants
 We forbid folks to buy raw clams at the shore, hut they eat fried ones there by the ton . People eat fried clams by the end of the year at the beach .
 We say no mowing lawns on Sunday, while shooting galleries and Ferris wheels are a scant half-hour away . Ferris wheels and shooting galleries are a short distance from the city .
 Big ads insist that families that play together stay together . While at our seashores gift shops are closed to the family on the one day they can go out for a drive .
 We close five and ten cent stores while drug stores sell everything from cosmetics to clocks, not to mention paper back hooks and, in some places tee shirts . We close 5 and 10 cent stores, while we close 5-10 cent stores .
 Horse-racing was perfectly fine on V eterans Day, but officially, at least, buying Pablum for baby was not . Horse racing was fine on the day, but official, it was not.
 Our readers gripe with some of the things they gripe about the government . CNN iReport: What do you think? Share it with us .
 The Blue Laws are irrational and encourage disobedience and evasion . They discriminate against some and favor a few businesses, The Blue Law says .
 If you close supermarkets in Massachusetts, folks can drive up to New Hampshire to get hamburg . New Hampshire can also get a hamburg in New Hampshire .
 There’s always a way to do what folks have to do, with or without official approval . There was no official approval for the move, but there was a way of doing it .
 Ban a hook and you increase its sales; forbid liquor consumption and you create bootlegging . Ban the hook and increase sales; ban liquor consumption creates bootlegging . Ban a . hook and . increase its . sales . ban a hook .
 It’s the old human story of angering folks into doing something, even if they don't want to, because you tell them they can’t, says CNN.com's John Sutter . Sutter: It's the old story of people angering into doing
 We stress, once again, that we are not advocating one policy regarding the Blue Laws as opposed to another . We stress that the Star is not advocating a policy regarding Blue Laws .
 Our point is that whatever the Sunday laws should he should he, they should he be fair and consistent . We are happy to clarify that the laws should be fair .
 "They should represent the interests and wishes not just of a self-appointed elect but of the entire community," she says . And they should represent not just the interests of the self-elected elect, she adds .
 If a Legislature votes to close grocery and clothing stores, it should also close liquor stores and race tracks . Liquor stores, race tracks should also be closed, lawmakers say .
 State retail business to lose $20 million in one ‘holiday,’ it might give some thought to closing vegetable stands on the highways . The state retail business is expected to lose more than $1 billion in one holiday .
 Every so often in these columns we stress the importance of zoning and urge those who feel its an unwarrantable intrusion in the rights of property owners to take a look at communities where there is no zoning .
 So many communities have had irreparable damage done them hv lack of authority to prevent improper development . It's hard to understand why those without the protection of zoning do not institute it as soon as possible .
 Marblehead Harbor is a popular tourist spot in Marblehead, Massachusetts . Developers have been looking at the area for 1 i or 11 stories apartment buildings .
 Not at present a single zoning ordinance in effect along tin 1 harbor that would prevent a developer from erecting such buildings, or indeed anything he wants to build .
 All that is to be done is to commence construction within ‘JO days’ alter a building permit is issued . All that lias to do is to begin construction within 'JO days'
 Phis fact and repeated rumors that property along the waterfront can he had is giving some Marhleheads food for serious thought . Phis is fact and rumors that he had a waterfront can .
 Marblehead Harbor setting would feel much more secure if the land there was protected by zoning . Undoubtedly those who do not want to see any change in the picturesque setting would be more secure .
 Winchester has such protection, but from time to time efforts of the i Manning Board to change or modify zoning, tightening restrictions in the public interest, are strenously opposed . Winchester has no such protection . Winchester is a city that has the right to have its own zoning authority, but the
 This is not to say that changes in the zoning By-laws should be voted without investigation or that the 1 Manning Board can do no wrong . It is not that changes to the zoning by-law should be made without an investigation .
 Winchester is one of the better communities of the Greater Boston area in which to live . By and large, however, there can he no doubt that zoning has helped Winchester .
 We would wager Marblehead, or those who would keep intact the attractiveness of this picturesque town, would he glad of the protection that zoning give& to u b here in Winchester . Winchester residents would be glad of zoning protection .
