 A serious error has crept into the discussion for or against shelters — that it is a moral issue . It's a serious error to say shelter is moral issue, but it's not moral, it's an issue .
 I doubt that anyone would seriously question the desire for peace of the vast majority of ppoplo in all lands . However, what peace means to each individual varies greatly .
 In the Western world at least, freedom is a necessary ingredient of anything that can truly be called peace . Freedom is necessary in order to make peace, but freedom is also necessary in peace, writes CNN.com's John Sutter .
 'How to attain it is a matter of individual belief and choice, with due regard to the rights of others' How to attain the right to freedom of expression is individual belief .
 To imply that the man who builds a shelter for his family is resigned to war and will automatically give up working for peace is as mistaken as the implication of many on the other side of the argument . The man who does not build one cares nothing about his family ands refusing to face
 Each individual must take facts and opinions available to him, and choose the actions he feels are most conducive to the continuation of civilization in the world .
 In this context, I do regret the tendency of many to give as proven facts much that is, at best, a matter of educated guessing . The “facts” varying according to which expert is chosen for quotation .
 The probability of attack, the total megatons delivered, the hypothetical enemy’s ability to deliver the bombs accurately for the greatest devastation, and the actual damage that would be caused under war conditions are all guesses work . Let us pray they remain that way.
 Those who choose to follow President’s request to build shelters have been severely ridiculed, and called everything from ostriches to warmongers . Taking precautions to increase the chances of survival, and recover from disaster is not a new idea .
 Most of us buy fire insurance (and support a fire department) not because fires are inevitable, but because they are possible . Most people buy insurance not because of the possibility of a fire, it's because it's possible .
 Many pay etxra to have seat belts in their cars, not because they care nothing for the slaughter on our roads, but because they do . Many pay for seat belts because they don't want to be part of the slaughter of our roads .
 He also does not cease to work for safer and saner driving . "Death or mutilation can happen to him and his, and is not just something that happens to other people"
 Let us not have our eyes so firmly fixed on peace at the international level, that we forget that Christian love and forbearance, that makes peace possible, is learned here at home . Christian love is the key to peace in the Middle East .
 "To impugn the character and motives of the person with whose ideas or arguments we disagree breeds anger and hate," says CNN.com's John Sutter.com .
 In conclusion may 1 suggest that civilization is not a matter of industrial capacity which gives us fine homes, cars, and a high standard of living, nor is it in churches, schools, or works of art, dear as they are to us .
 civilization rests in the heart and mind of man and cannot be destroyed until man, with his capacity to love beauty and to worship God, is himself destroyed . No, civilization rests on the heart of man .
 The Star suspects that a better word than “guesswork” might be found to describe scientific estimates of the effects of nuclear bombing and fallout . It is not the first estimate of how much damage has been caused by fallout .
 One of the more hopeful aspects of the cold war is, in fact, the remarkable consensus of American and Soviet scientists on the genocidal effects of both . The Cold War was one of the most brutal periods of the Cold War .

 We seem to forget that the Russians fear us and our nuclear power, as much as we fear them . Put we seem to have forgotten that the Russian fear us, as well as the Russians .
 Many people still visualize war as a nice, neat, little war in a little meadow with a band of soldiers fighting . And I do not think that many people realize that if a war were to erupt, it would not be a nice and neat war . Many people don't realize
 It will be a terrifying, destructive, nuclear war, and not many will live to tell of its horrors . Not many will survive the war, but many will be shocked by the horrors it will inflict .
 Those who retire to your shelters as the ‘inevitable’ war approaches are folding up centuries of the progress of man and adopting the primitive life of a cave man .
 Some stolid Americans have withstood all the bombs and radioactivity, etc. But let us now assume that some stolid American has withstood the bombs .

 If a war comes, it will not be one bomb dropped, or two, but many, and there is no end to the resulting destruction . "There will be many more bombs dropped, and many, but there will be no end," says CNN's John Sutter .
 The thing for us* to do is not go around building our hopes of survival in a bomb shelter, but build our hopes, in the idea that there will not be a war . We* should not build ourselves in bomb shelters, but in the hope that there won't be a

 Human sorrow is caused by a man’s false sense of separateness from the world, says the authors . Their insight is that human sorrow is due to a man's false sense .
 Their objective is to free men from the prison of egotism and childish dependence, enabling him to accept the world as it is with maturity, creativity, compassion, compassion and a capacity to love .
 "Free association" is the method of “free association,” a spontaneous play of thought and emotion . The method of "free association" has been a key part of psychoanalysis .

 Psychoanalyst stresses that he cannot ‘save’ the patient . Like the Zgn masters, however, he cannot "save” the patient, however .
 "He can at best guide him, as a participating observer, into that complete attunement with reality both inside and outside of him which is wisdom"
 As in Zen, as in the teaching of the historic Buddha himself, there is no external refuge, no finished set of answers to which one may turn . Zen is no place to turn to, but as in Zen there are no external answers .

 I urge you to publish the latest release from the Atomic Energy Commission regarding the effect of nuclear blasts . I therefore urge you . publish the . latest release .
 You will find it, for instance, in the Christian Science Monitor of November 13 . The story will be published in November 13.
 As a nuclear scientist, although not a bomb expert, I feel qualified to help clarify some questions concerning the nuclear radiation released during and after a blast . I'm not an expert on nuclear radiation, but I'm qualified to answer questions .
 Most of the errors and inaccuracies, in the part of the editorial covering this topic, were expertly pointed out by Messrs. Messrsrs. O'Neill and his colleagues .
 Brooks and Boecker need to clarify some things, but I believe some further clarification is needed .
 The following points represent mostly observed indisputable facts but also a few educated estimates . The following is an attempt to make a point for the world's first time .
 When 1 speak about nuclear radiation, it may help the uninitiated reader to think of X-rays, although the nuclear radiation from a bomb is somewhat more complex . The nuclear radiation in a nuclear bomb is more complex than the X-ray .
 A nuclear bomb will for a split second during the explosion release a tremendous amount of primary nuclear radiation . Primary nuclear radiation will be released during the blast . Primary radiation is released during a nuclear explosion .
 The hulk of this primary radiation will be stopped by a few miles of air or 10 feet of concrete or dirt . The radiation is the main source of the U.S. nuclear bomb .
 Primary radiation is not generally regarded as a danger to anybody far enough from the explosion to survive the heut and blast effects . The primary radiation is therefore not generally considered a danger .
 The explosion leaves a residue of radioactive material in the air and, what is more important, if lion also takes time to build up i its harmful effect .
 If it were only for l’all| out, Dad would either be able to I get home in time, or he would stay | in another shelter and get home afI ter a few days . Dad would stay in the shelter, or stay in a shelter for a few
 Fallout radiation has about the mme penetrating power as the X rays currently used in deep-seated cancer therapy . Fallout radiation is similar to the radiation currently used to treat cancer patients .
 Any material, preferably heavy substances be tween you and the sources, will cut down on the intensity . Any material you want to use will need to be tweened up .
 Bombs exploded high above the ground produce very little local fallout . The discussion above has been concerned with the fallout of the bombs exploding high above ground .
 The radioactive residue from the bomb material will be present, however, and most of it will be carried up to very high altitudes . Most of the radioactive residue will be found in the area, but most will he carried it .
 Some of the confusion that was evident in the Star’s editorial and also in the answer to Mr Boecker can be traced back to this word usage by the sources of information .
 What 1 have given above are cold data, presented for the purpose of removing misconceptions about the effects of nuclear radiation from an explosion and from fallout .

 It is very important to note that it is only the primary radiation, because of its natural anti enormous j intensity that will induce radioactivity in other materials . The radiation will also emit radioactivity into other materials, such as hydrogen and helium .
 The radioactive materials are carried by the wind over a wide area and settle on the ground in the form of dust . The radioactive material is carried by wind and settles in the air in a large area .

 It is regrettable that so few scientists concern themselves with the contamination of vegetables and milk, for example, that has resulted from radioactive fallout even from nuclear tests suspended in 1958 .
 Even in 1957, a midwest rainfall contained so much radioactivity as to induce one million Geiger counts per minute per gallon of rain water . The radioactivity was so high that it induced a Geiger count of 1 million per minute .
 From the tests suspended in 1958 alone some 3,600 cases of leukemia are estimated, not to mention bone cancer, genetic mutations, stillbirths, and diseases of the muscles and thyroid, to indicate just a few .
 The present fallout levels will double when the 1962 spring rains bring a large portion of the radioactive material to earth . It is estimated, moreover, that as a result of the Soviet Union’s recent terroristic bomb tests, the present fallout will double .

 Newconstruction, it is pointed out, is a mutter of great importance to every community since it affects the economy in many different ways . New construction is an important part of the economy .
 Besides work, it creates a demand for lumber, hardware, stoves, refrigerators and other durable goods .
 In Winchester, for its size, there was more home building in the year than in most parts of the United States . Winchester is a city of about 500,000 people . Winchester was the largest city in the U.S.
 The rate compares favorably with the national figure, 6 units per 1,000 population . The rate is higher than the average rate of units per person in the UK .
 Throughout the nation generally, residential construction was in the doldrums in i960 . Residential construction in the U.S. was in an industry slump .
 There was a drop of $2.2 billion, representing an 18 per cent cut in new dwellings . There was also a drop in $2 billion in new homes .
 Some authorities place the blame for the national setback on the high interest rates and the tight mortgage market that prevailed . Some blame the low mortgage market for the collapse .

 Norma E Porras of 11 Hutchinson Road completed the 1961 Postgraduate Seminar in Pharmaceutical Chemistry offered by the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy, Boston .
 The program included a series of eight lectures given on Tuesday evenings from September 26 through November 14 . The lectures were intended to assist the practicing pharmacist in his modern role as therapeutic consultant to the physician .
 At the conclusion of the course on November 14, the fifty-eight registrants received certificates in recognition of satisfactory completion . The course was completed in November .

 TB Christmas Seal campaign chairman of Middlesex County thought of a method recently that some residents are using now as they send their checks to the Christmas Seal Campaign . Residents are using this method to send checks for the campaign .
 The original idea Anne suggested a short time ago not only helps to build better community health but also helps residents in balancing their checkbooks . Anne suggested the original idea a few weeks ago .
 Anne suggests that when checks are written for the current Tuberculosis Seal Campaign the writer includes the amount shown in the cents column of their checkbook . Anne suggests using the cents to make sure the amount is included in the column .
 Anne points out that many people can't increase their contributions by dollars . Anne: "If only 10 people sent in 10 cents more than their usual gift. . . well there’s another dollar... and think how it would be if a lot of people did the same thing."
 “Nickles and dimes can add very quickly to make dollars that fight tuberculosis in Middlesex County,” she said . Nickles and Dimes can be used to raise money to fight tuberculosis .
 Anne entered the TB Hospital in Waltham shortly after the first of last year . She hopes to get back to work after the Christmas holidays this year .

 Knapp was’ one of the speakers on November to at the annual meeting of the Assembly of tin* Massachusetts C ouncil of Churches, composed of twelve major denominations working together .
 The dav-long program began with an ecumenical service in historic Trinity Church in Copley Square . It was followed by a luncheon, afternoon business meeting, and a dinner program in the Hancock building .
 Knapp stressed that “each denomination in our fellowship has contributed some emphasis of importance to the total Christian Com munity.” Knapp said .
 The Rt. Sees Improved CatholicProtestant Relations with the Catholic Church . The retiring president of the Massachusetts Council, the retiring president, will speak at the end of his retirement .

 Roy Pearson, dean of the Andover Newton Theological School of Newton Centre, points out that an attempt to establish the church’s self-image almost inevitably ends in the conclusion that the church is a schizophrenic personality .

 Coach Knowlton believed the Officials had not chosen him because of his fine won and lost record as a coach, but for his character building and what he has done for the boys who have played under him .
 At this point the toastmaster called attention to two coming football players at Winchester High School attending the dinner with their fathers .

 His remarks were strictly entertainment and it would be hard to name the more popular of his anecdotes . His remarks are strictly entertainment, and it's hard to think of more popular ones .

 Mr Niblock said that the “coach of the year” award was a great, and well deserved tribute to Henry Knowlton .
 In closing he paid tribute to Henry Knowlton, saying he had never known a man of finer character nor one who did more for boys .
 Friends of football need have no fear of those who want to make nothing but intellectuals out of our boys, says Kozlowski . Knowlton is teaching the game, while footballers like him are teaching it, he says .
 Many, he said, look down on football, but properly taught, there is nothing like it to discipline the body, mind and spirit . Football is a discipline discipline that discipline the mind, body, spirit and spirit of football .
 Too much emphasis can be placed on studies as opposed to all around men like Barry Wood of Harvard and Albie Booth of Yale, he continued .
 Coach Knowlton told the meeting he had been the official in the recent Melrose game who called two fumbles against Winchester . As an example of the coach's relations with officials he said he was the official at the Melrose- Winchester game .
 Henry knew the official had called them as he saw them and in the way he thought it was right . Henry knew he had done what he thought was the right .
 Mr Kozlowski recalled working a game in which Joe Bellino seemed to be roughed up by an opposing player . He said Bellino was "taken down" by a player in the game .
 The official had not seen the play develop and asked Bellino if the opposing player had deliberately tried to rough him . Bellino said he did not see the play and asked if the player was deliberately roughing him .
 This is typical of the Knowlton teaching and influence of his boys, according to the speaker . This the speaker believed . This was typical . This is the typical . of the Teachlton . influence .

 He felt humble, he said, because there seemed so many coaches equally, or more deserving of the honor than he . He said he felt humble because of the lack of respect for coaches .
 Football had been good to him in many ways, including friendships he had made through the game, he said . Football had given him the chance to play in the Premier League for the first time .
 He listed many officials among his friends and expressed his admiration for all officials . He beieves that officials are a very necessary part of any game .
 He is not among those, he continued, who believe there is too much whistle blowing . He said he does not believe there are too many whistles blowing .
 Rules are made to be enforced and one of the lessons boys who play football must learn is that the game must he played within the framework of these rules . Rules must be enforced in order to ensure the game is played in the right way, says Mark Hughes .
 A respecter of officials himself, he told his audience he has always taught his boys to respect them . Even though he had encountered officials who “carried the ball” equally as well as his best backs, he always believed them to be fair .
 He closed his remarks with a sincere expression to the Association of New England Officials for the great honor shown him .

 Walter Houston Clark, author of The Psychology of Religion, will address the parents and teachers of the First Baptist Church on Monday, November 27 at 8:00m. to speak on the psychology of religion . Clark is one of the outstanding resources on the description of religious growth in childhood and
 Clark is dean and chairman of the Hartford School of Religious Education . Clark is a past president of the American Association of Schools of Religious . Education .
 He will describe the origin of the concept of the divine, what the child's religion is like, the growth of religious maturity emerging from the tensions of youth, and the factors which lead to a variety of religious experience .
 This will be the beginning of bimonthly addresses at First Baptist, directed at describing to parents and teaching staff the broad scope and deep sources of re ligious education .

 In the typical self-contained organization, some twenty to thirty pupils are assigned tq each teacher, and each group is placed in a classroom where most of the instructions takes place at the hands of that one teacher .
 He must provide as best he can for the range of individual needs and abilities in his group . The coach must provide best for the group's needs and needs .
 In addition, he must perform a variety of clerical duties and supervisory tasks on a non-instructional nature .
 Under the team teaching pattern, groups of teachers take joint responsibility for the instruction of a segment of the school population . In contrast, under . team teaching patterns, under the team .
 The clerical and secretarial needs of these teachers are cared for by a clerical aide . The aide is a member of the school's staff .
 Parents of the children in the team teaching program raise questions about the school's curriculum .
 Each year an achievement test is taken by every child in Winchester schools . Each year every child takes the test at every school in the city .
 The results of these tests were just one criteria by which all the pupils in the present fourth, fifth and sixth grades were grouped . Tire results were based on the results of the pupils' tests .
 There are one hundred and fifty four pupils in the team teaching project at Parkhurst . Parkhurst pupils are part of a team of 100 pupils in a teaching project . The project is based on the idea of teaching children at the school .
 Achievement results were recorded from high achievement to low achievement . The achievement results of a given subject were recorded as high achievement .
 During the first few days of school in September, inventories were given to each group to re-check results of the achievement lists .
 Re-grouping once again took place to ascertain correct placement of each child . Children were placed in various locations across the country .
 This pattern followed in each subject to be taught in the team teaching project . This pattern was followed by the pattern of teaching each subject .
 The teacher is selected for a given subject area for her specialization and existing talent . One teacher is for reading, one in mathematics, another for science, etc. One teacher for reading is for mathematics .
 Pupils are assigned to each teacher, for each subject, according to their placement of achievement . The pupils are then assigned to teachers according to the placement of their achievement .
 Children can now work together with others facing the same problems . This is not confusing to the children, for now they can work together . The children will be able to learn how to cope with their problems .
 This grouping makes it possible to place pupils into different ability groups for each subject, with sufficient flexibility . Pupils can be placed in groups of ability groups in different subjects .
 All the teachers involved in the team teaching project work together to meet the instructional needs of the children by a cooperative organization of planning . Different teachers assume responsibilities within the group .
 They plan together; they observe the plans carried out and onferences for evaluative discus sions of original plans and its operations . They observe each other's plans and their operations .
 The success of team teaching depends a great deal upon the acceptance, understanding, adaptability, confidence and faith in the program by each teacher . Each teacher must accept, understand, adapt and adaptability of the program .
 The enthusiasm of the children, and The cooperation of the parents in understanding the efforts of the school and staff in providing for the children educational facilities to the best of our abilities .

 Regional Planning is not a new one, but it has become more familiar to the public in recent years . The concept of regional planning is not an entirely new one . Regional planning is a key part of the planning process .
 The speed of change and generally accelerated tempo of modern society has ere ated serious pressures on outmoded urban structures — physical, political, and economic . Modern society has also put pressure on urban structures .
 The mechanics of planning for change in major U.S. cities have developed in varying degrees, and with varying success depending upon the communities involved .
 Most Metropolitan Regions grew from the central city in a kind of overflow pattern . In the Boston area the outlying communities were established as autonomous political units separated geographically from the core .
 On the other hand, local autonomy is granted by the Legislature — it is merely permissive . Local autonomy granted by state legislators is granted only by state law .
 Less than 409c of the inhabitants of Greater Boston live within the ‘core’ city in contrast to the overall national average of 609c . The national average is 609C .
 Panel of speakers will analyze problems, explaining terminology, current impetus, and existing agencies for long-range comprehensive planning . Panel will also discuss terminology and current impetus for planning in the U.S. The panel will analyze these problems .
 They will estimate current trends and future needs in the physical environment of the community . They will attempt to estimate current . trends and . future needs .
 The Winchester LWV suggests that those who attend this panel discussion will be better equipped to understand and to weigh the needs and responsibilities of Winchester in its relation to neighboring communities . Winchester is the center of rural services in Boston and Boston .

 Parish Players must have known they faced a real challenge in choosing this for their fall play . Parish Players chose this for the first time in their history .
 Nine people on that stage made an audience actually believe that an old theatre legend had come alive . Nine people were on the stage making the audience believe it was a real life .
 The story ninges on a supper party given on the stage of an empty theatre by Sir Charles Jasper on his fiftieth birthday . The party was on the eve of his inheriting two million pounds .
 He hopes to prove a legend will came true this same evening — that the ghost of a man murdered in this same theatre will rise again and walk across the stage . Another ghost 90 years before .
 Sir Charles is murdered before eleven o’clock . His young wife manages to prove that it was murder and not suicide . Sir Charles’ ghost actually does walk across the stage, sit at the head of his dinner table .

 She and Elizabeth Shepard had a long scene in which to establish the story of the party and its significance, and both held it well .

 lung cancer is now the leading cause of cancer death among American men . Lung cancer is the most common cause of lung cancer death in the United States .
 The num ber of m^Ie deaths has increased six-fold in the past 20 years . The number of deaths has also increased in the last two decades .
 Medical authorities torn between statistical and clinical proof, unable to agree as to where the responsibility lies .
 There is no disputing the figures. However, as to the mortality from lung cancer, there is no doubt the figures are correct .
 The official report shows that there were 32 deaths among residents of Winchester from all types of cancer in the year ending January, 1960 . Winchester residents of the 1960s died from all kinds of cancer .
 Lung cancer, however, was responsible for only one, or 3, percent of lung cancer deaths . Lung cancer is responsible for one of the highest rates in the United States .
 Nationally, it accounted for 14. percent of the total and, in the State of Massachusetts, for 13. percent . The state of Massachusetts is home to the largest population in the country .
 The lung cancer toll in the U.S. is small when viewed in the light of the 260,047 lives taken in the year by cancer as a whole . The fact that it is growing is causing concern .
 Not everyone in the scientific field is impressed with the evidence that indicates cigarette smoking is the chief cause of lung cancer . Cigarette smoking has been linked to lung cancer for decades .
 Lung cancer mortality in Winchester was found to be below average . In proportion to population, lung cancer mortality was below average in Winchester .

 Get inside as quickly as possible and get into a warm, not hot, tub of water . Get inside quickly and get in a warm tub of not hot water .
 The symptoms are numbness, tingling, a sensation of cold and ashen color in the affected part . The symptoms of these symptoms include numbness and tingles .
 If you have an illness causing poor circulation of the blood, be doubly careful to avoid exposure to cold . And if you have a cold, be extra careful .
 Undue exposure to cold, places severe burdens on the circulatory system, says CNN.com.com's John Sutter.com . The cold is a sign that the health of a person exposed to the cold will be affected .
 It can cost you a finger or toe, or in the case of prolonged, unprotected chilling, it can cause death . It can also cause damage to your body or limb, or even your brain .
 Humans are warm-blooded animals and ordinarily conserve their body heat by cutting down the surface exposed to the air . Humans conserve body heat using surface-covering techniques such as cutting it off to avoid heat .
 When your body is chilled, you start shivering; this gives your muscles involuntary exercise and helps warm them . In addition, shivering gives you an involuntary exercise to warm your muscles .
 If you’re still cold, small blood vessels close down all over your body surface, with their blood-flow rate cut to as little as one fifth of normal . If you're cold, your blood flow rate is cut to one fifth .
 Your body is using your skin literally as a blanket, to conserve heat internally . Your skin is being used to protect your body from the heat .
 At the same time, your heart beats faster and your blood pressure rises, all in the effort to mobilize your internal sources of warmth against the external danger . At the time, you are trying to get warm and warm .
 This is another case where the ounce of prevention is worth the pound of cure . This is a case of 'prevention' and 'preventive medicine'

 Ritirim A Sorokiit of S.I. Street, founder of the Harvard Sociology Department, has been named to the Institute of European Studies .
 The Institute is a non-profit organization that conducts foreign study programs for American college students . The Institute conducts foreign studies programs for U.S. college students.
 Sorokin’s principal task on the council will be to advise the institute on matters pertaining to courses, standards and the over-all objectives of existing and projected overseas programs . Sorokin will be the first member of the council to be appointed .
 ‘Crisis of Our Age’ has been translated into German, Dutch, Spanish, Norse, Japunese, Portuguese, and Czech, among others .
 Sorokin is also author of “Contemporary Sociological Theories” and “Reconstruction of Humanity” among many others . Sorokin: “Russia and the United States.”
 Most of these works have been translated into two or more foreign languages . Most of them have been published in a number of languages .
 Dr. John Sutter is the founder, first, professor and first chairman of Harvard’s Department of Sociology . Dr. Sutter was the first chairman and founder of Harvard's Sociology Department .
 Sorokin is the director of the Harvard Research Center in Creative Altruism . Sorokin: We need to find a way to improve our relationship with each other .
 An honorary member of several European and American academies of arts and sciences, Dr. John Defterios is also a member of the U.S. Academy of Sciences .
 Sorokin's works are among the most frequently translated sociological treatises in the world . Sorokin’s works exert a continuing and growing influence throughout the world. Sorokin is one of the world's most prolific sociological writers .

 Mystic Avenue may have extended down to the bridge before the Parkway was built .
 After the construction of the Parkway there was a short driveway from it to the bridge . The Parkway was built in the 1960s and 1970s .
 A standpipe to fill the old watering-carts on the Parkway stood at the entrance of the drive .
 Painted red, the old wooden wooden bridge stood just south of an island that split the river . The remains of granite masonry at its northern end were visible at the northern end of the bridge .
 Story had it that this masonry was the foundation of a bridge that crossed the river, giving access to a summer house on the island that was a part of a big estate in Rangeley .
 The wooden bridge was used by commuters from the side hill to reach the old Mystic Station which preceded Wedgemere, though it was not located just where it was built . It was used to connect commuters to the station which preceded it .
 The bridge was torn down and replaced with a longer structure located just north of the red bridge, that gave access to old Manchester Field . The new bridge was built in the 1930s .
 This bridge also spanned an island, just north of the one near Mystic Avenue, was removed when the river was moved in connection wtih the building of the present Manchester Field .

 The New England Shopping (’enter on Route | I in Saugus, a “regional’’ or kingsize shopping center in real estate I parlance, is the product of years of creative planning, negotiating, financing, engineering and construction .
 Milton (J. and Alan T Green) conceived the plan and mobilized the economic resources and faith it took to proceed from idea to reality . Convinced that the urea was natural, Milton (Milton) and Alan (Alan) Green conceived the idea .
 Their father Isadore, and two brothers Benjamin and Frank, started one of the early 5 and 10c chains .
 By 1929 their chain consisted of 50 stores throughout New England and the East . By 1929 the chain had 50 stores in New England .
 Green Stores merged with McLellan Stores this year . The Green brothers devoted their interest to the real es tate operations of chain store commercial properties .
 Milton ami Alan Green entered the business in 1937 and 1950 respectively and now are the two active members of the firm . Milton and Alan Green enter the business together in 1950 respectively .
 Alan and Milton graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Graduate School of Business administration where they were outstanding athletes . Milton and Alan were outstanding students at Harvard College .
 Milton Milton cap tained Harvard Track Team and held the intercollegiate and world record in the high hurdles . Milton was a member of the Harvard track team . Milton held the world record for high hurdles and high hurdles at Harvard .
 During World War II, Alan served in the Submarine Service . Milton was an Air Combat Intelligence officer in Naval Aviation . Alan served as a Navy Submarine .
 They also have diversified and active interests in middle income apartment homes as well as urban and suburban commercial properties .
 The year 1954 brought the germ of the New England Shopping Center concept . The New England shopping center concept was born in 1954 .
 The Green brothers negotiated with the Town of Saugus for land that then comprised the Town Farm . Having decided that the time and place were right, the brothers negotiated for land .
 Experts in the field from Harvard Business School, were making comprehensive studies of traffic, population, economic growth, ease of access, access, labor pool, travel time and travel time . Meanwhile, experts from the field of the field were making detailed studies .
 The area was determined to be the most densely populated site of its kind in the entire country . The area is determined to he the most populated site in the country .
 Ease of access from as far away as ten miles and more was quick and simple . Ease-access was easy and easy to access from ten miles away from the site .
 The entire area I was thriving* Conditions were per] feet for the establishment of a vast regional shopping center with much more than simple local or neighborhood appeal .
 The land was purchased in 1955 and the Greens started working immediately . The Greens have been working on the land since then .
 Architectural plans were discussed with many of the leading architects of the nation . Greens conveying their own ideas and concepts as to design features they wished to incorporate .
 In this center they are located at the very center of the shopping area around a courtyard containing a children’s play area and space for fashion shows, art shows and seasonal promotions .
 16 foot wide walkways around the crescent accentuated by landscaped garden areas, planters, and patterns of brick and concrete patterns .
 These walkways provide a continuous weather-protected arcade leading to all stores entrances . All stores entrances and thence from the courtyard to the parking facilities in the rear .
 Sears Roebuck’s largest store in New England, Baker Shoes . Baker Shoes, Dorothy Muriel's and Brigham's, Endicott-Johnson Shoes . Endicot-Johnson shoes, W T Grant, Household Finance Corp., Kennedy Butter and Egg Stores, National Shoes
 Woolworth, Elm Farm, Emric’s Luncheonette, Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Field's Hosiery Shops . The town also includes a medical center, a bank, a barber shop, a jewelry store and a bank .

 Mystic Glee Club gives a special concert at the* Walpole State Prison .
 The invitation to sing came from a committee composed of church loaders in the state and prison officials . The committee attempts to bring specially selected entertainment to convicts .
 The program was composed of lighter and more popular music . It is proving to be so well received by the club's audiences .
 The inmates at the prison, composed entirely of convicts, guards and officials, enjoyed the musicals “Gigi” and “My Fair Lady’s” musicals . The listeners were made up entirely of prisoners and guards .
 The remainder of the program was made up of spirituals, barbershop numbers, sea chanties and a few religious selections which showed the versatility of the club .
 Wendell Withington directed the Club and Frances Randall Cabot was the accompanist . The Club was set up at the end of the year .
 Mystic Glee Club will present its annual winter concert December 16 at the Junior High School auditorium . After giving several concerts in surrounding towns and cities during the next two weeks, the group will give a good turn-out .

 A number of them have come to Headquarters to talk things over with him and Officer Cogan . They have also come to headquarters to talk about their relationship with him .
 Some parents have brought their youngsters to the police station to hear what the police have to say about their actions . The police are eager to supply advice in their effort to keep hoys and girls out of trouble .

 Parents resent any interference on the part of a stranger with their youngster’s complete freedom . For one thing parents do not know policemen as they did the old route officer .
 Police make scant contacts with young people unless they are sent to break up a fight or to assist at an accident . Police, cruising along in automobiles, make scant contact with youngsters .
 They do not know the kids personally as the old route officer did, and do not have the advantage of mutual knowledge and understanding . Instead of a route officer, the new route officer has a job with the school district .
 What few youngsters were hanging around at night years ago were pretty much known and pinpointed for possible trouble by the police . Now, the police say they are aware of the dangers of young people hanging around .
 There arc just too many youngsters on their own today to make this possible . There arc too many young people in the world to make it possible .
 The only salvation of the Police in a sincere attempt to prevent juvenile crime lays in the home and parents . Police say parents are responsible for their children's safety .
 If the Police can get the cooperation of parents, if they can bring to the attention of the parents the awful danger in which their sons and daughters stand because of their anti-social tendencies, a start can he made in rehabilitating our boys and girls .
 Ignorance on the part of parents of actual conditions as they affect their children has permitted many an essentially good boy or girl to drift into conduct that finally makes necessary punitive action by the police .
 Chief Derro and his department arc striving to prevent this from happening . It is to prevent it from happening again .

 It would seem the least they can get from parents is cooperation and support . It's the least parents can expect from parents to support their children .

 Harry Edward Brown died early Thanksgiving morning November 23, at the Winchester Hospital after four years of failing health . Brown was one of the last of his generation at the Central Fire Station in Winchester .
 Flags on the common and public buildings were displayed at half-staff in his honor . Flags were displayed on the public buildings in honor of the soldier .
 He was born January 11, 1877, in Effingham, N.H., and spent his early life there, later as a young man living there .
 He came to Winchester in 1916, and built the house in which he lived at 13 Rock Avenue . He moved there in 1916 .
 Prior to entering the Fire Department, he was foreman for George Poland, a local building contractor . He learned the carpenter’s trade and was a carpenter before entering the fire department .
 During World War I he worked at his trade at the Boston Naval Shipyard . He worked at the shipyard during World War One .
 Mr Brown was appointed a call man in the Fire Department October 1, 1916 . He was appointed by the department in 1916 .
 He received a provisional appointment on March 30 1919, and was made a permanent firefighter September 30, 1919 . He was made permanent firefighter on September 30 .
 He served under three chiefs, the late David H DeCourcy and John J German, and the present Chief James E Callahan . He served as a member of the late Chief of the Police Force .
 He was appointed to special duty on the department’s fire alarm . April 3, 1930, and retired Jan uary 23, 1943, .
 During his years in the department he made many im provements at the station through his skill as a carpenter . He made many of the best imitations of the station .
 He was a member of the Carpenter's Union and of the Winchester Fireman’s Relief Association . He was also a fireman's union member .
 On January 1, 1901, Mr Brown married Bridget Agnes Cullen of Winchester . Mr Brown died October 3, 1956 .

 Mary Waters Kelley, widow of Erskine Hawes Kelley, died Wednesday afternoon, November 2, at Winchester Hospital . She was a member of the family at the Home for Aged People .
 She was born August 18, 1876, in Charlottetown, P.E.I., but went as a girl to Woburn, growing up in that city and attending the public schools . She was also a girl who went to the public school in that town .
 They lived for 30 years in Winchester, making their home on Wildwood Street before moving to Andover . They lived in Andover, Massachusetts, for about 30 years .
 For twelve years they lived in Andover until Mr Kelley’s death, at which time Mrs. Kelley died . For 12 years, the Kelley and Mrs Kelley lived there for 12 years .

 Stephen Cutler Greene and daughter of C Fred, and Louise Eberle of Winchester, died early Friday morning, November 24, at the Putnam Memorial Hospital in Bennington after a brief illness with spinal meningitis .
 She had visited her parents in Winchester the week previous to her death . She had been in the best of health when she died .
 Greene was born June 5, 1928, in Boston though her parents were residents of Winchester at the time . Greene was also born in Winchester, Massachusetts .
 She grew up in town, attending Winchester schools and Winchester High School, from which she graduated in the class of 1946 .
 A member of the scholastic honor roll, she was a three sport athlete and winner of the Mansfield-Wheeler Sportsmanship Cup . She was also a three-sport athlete .
 Voted the girl who had done most for the school, the most popular girl and the best all around senior . She was secretary of the student council, a member of the executive board of the Athletic Association and on the staffs of both the student paper and yearbook .
 After two years at Colby Junior College, and her marriage to Mr Greene September 11, 1948, she accompanied her husband to Milford, Connecticut . Mr Greene was completing his studies at Yale Divinity School .
 Greene accompanied him to his first pastorate at the First Parish Church in Island Pond Vermont . Greene accompanied Greene to the church . Greene was a member of Greene's congregation .
 Mr Greene became minister of the Second Congregational Church in Bennington . From the post five years ago they went to Bennington where Mr Greene was minister .
 His wife assisted him with his work in many ways, as a member of numerous church committees and in the general role of a minister's wife .
 She was genuinely beloved by those, young and old, fortunate enough to know her well . Greene who did not like her, and she was genuinely loved by those who knew her well. Greene . Greene was not a fan of Greene, but she was a hero of the day . Greene
 Always friendly and considerate, with a sincere liking for people, she enjoyed an unusually wide circle of friends . News of her untimely passing brought a very deep regret .
 Greene leaves behind three children, Elisabeth Everts, 11; Frederick Eberle, 8 and Nancy Louise Greene 5 . Greene leaves three children with his wife .
 At the service at her husband’s Church last Sunday there were many clergymen in attendance . Some clergymen from as far distant as Burlington .
 A committal service was conducted at the family lot in Wildwood Cemetery Monday forenoon . A funeral service was held at the funeral home .
 Cart also conducted a largely attended memorial service at the First Congregational Church on Monday afternoon . Cart conducted the largely attended service . Cart's funeral service was held at the church .
 Franklin Pynn, 73, of 24 Clematis Street, died Tuesday morning, November 28, at the Winchester Hospital after a long period of failing health . Franklin was retired superintendent of Wrought Iron Kitchen Equipment Company .
 He was born September 15, 1888, at Harbor Grace, Newfoundland, and grew up there learning the trade of a sheet metal worker .
 In 1911 he came to this country and soon after settled in Winchester, making his home in town for half a century . He came to the UK in 1911 and settled in the town of Winchester .
 He was for many years a member and active in Waterfield Lodge of Odd Fellows . He was also a member of the First Baptist Church .
 For a time after coming to this country Mr Pynn had his own sheet metal business in Boston under the name of Trask,Pynn Co. He had a sheet metal company in Boston .
 In 1944 he became associated with the Wrought Iron Kitchen Equipment Company in Boston . He was shop superintendent at the time of his retirement four years ago .
 Florence Chase of Winchester is survived by six sons and six daughters . Franklin Pynn, Jr., Jr., of Waltham, is also survived by Franklin Chase, Jr. Florence Chase, of Winchester .
 Also surviving are 18 grandchildren and one great-granddaughter; a sister, Mrs. Mrs. Smith . Also surviving include 18 grandchildren, 18 great granddaughters and 18 grandchildren . Mrs Smith also survived by her sister, a sister-in-law .
 Andrew H Hughes of Toronto, Canada, and Willis Pynn of Saugus. Hughes of Canada, Canada and a brother, Willis. Willis Prynn of U.S. Hughes. Hughes and Pynynn.
 Funeral services will be held Friday afternoon at 2 o’clock at the Graham Funeral Home in Woburn .
 Joseph E O’Donnell, Jr., pastor of the First Baptist Church, will officiate . The service will be held at the church .
 Memorial contributions may be made in his name to the Winchester Hospital Building Fund or Cancer Research Foundation .
 Joseph T Callahan died suddenly Thanksgiving night, November 23, at the Winchester Hospital, following an acute coronary attack . Joseph T * Callahan was a constable of Winchester for 10 years and well known in the local oil burner field .
 He entered the hospital on the Tuesday before his death for exploratory X-rnys in no way connected with his heart . He had entered hospital on Tuesday before he died for tests that weren't connected to heart .
 He was born June 22, 1906, in Winchester and spent virtually all of his life in this town . He attended Winchester schools and graduated from Winchester High School in the class of 1924 .
 He first worked for the Winchester firm of Kimball <fc Earle, and later formed the partnership of Kelley & Callahan . He later formed a partnership with Kelley .
 He had been for the past 10 years associated with Fitzgerald Fuel Oil Co., as credit manager . He had worked for the company for more than 10 years .
 He had served the town as constable since 1951 and had been a special police officer for 15 years . He had also been a constable for the town since 1951 . He has been a police officer in the town for 60 years .
 He was a town meeting member for Precinct 6, serving from 1928 to 1941, and from 1951 until his death . He was also a deputy tax collector and had been a town council member . He died at the age of 92 .
 He was a member and past exalted ruler of Winchester Lodge of Elks and was in the communications division of the Winchester Civil Defense . He was also a member of Winchester Elks .
 For six years he served as manager of the original Immaculate Conception Drum and Bugle Corps . He is now the president of the University of California-based Drum & Bugle corps .

 Born in Boston, she grew up in the old Boston Highlands district, now Roxbury, being educated at private school there .

 The sets and costumes of the Tracy Music Library of Boston were the first item on view in Washington last week .
 This has much W inchester interest because of the president of the Library, Mrs. Mrs. Dorothy Drexler . This has been a major interest in the library since it was founded .
 The Department of Defense issued a directive 72 hours before opening that the three male leads, all servicemen, could not be in the show . The production, staged by the American Ligiit Opera Company, made local and national news .
 The ban was lifted by the Department of Defense within 24 hours . The Pentagon was deluged with complaints from interested parties . The ban, allegedly issued because of union pressure, was lifted 24 hours after complaints .
 Objection withdrawn, reportedly, when it learned that members of the American Light Opera Company cast were unpaid . Objection was withdrawn when it was learned that cast members were unpaid, reportedly .
 The story made headlines in the three Washington daily papers, the local radio and television stations, and was carried by UPT and AP wire services and the ABC and NBC networks .
 Tracy Music Library supplies costumes and sets for each of the ALOC's shows . ALOC is based in Tracy, California, and is based at the Tracy Music Museum in Tracy .
 Gene Barth, who for five years was artistic director of Theatre Marque, offBroadway, off-Broadway . Barth: "Theatre Marque is a great place to raise money for people who want to see theatre."
 The sets and costumes were executed by Tracy Music Li brary . After this production will become part of its vast lend ing library which supplies theatre groups across the country .

 The Symmes’ Back from Tour Of the Orient is located in PA 9-2696 WI .
 Marshall Symmes of Yale Street have returned from a two-month tour of the Orient . They visited major cities of Japan, including Tokyo, Nara, Osaka, Kobe, Kyoto, and Yokohama .
 They also visited the Presidential Palace in Manila, and the war memorial to those lost in World War II located just outside Fort McKinley in the Philippines .
 Anthony Duquette, formerly of Winchester, was captured by the Japanese on Corregidor and perished in a ship at sea . He was killed in a battle with the Japanese .
 At Kamakura, Japan, the Symmes visited the famous “Daibutsu,” or Great Buddha, which they say is some three stories tall . They say it is a great tourist attraction .
 In Tokyo the Symmes stayed at the Imperial Hotel at the same time that President Sukarno of Indonesia and his entourage were booked at the hotel . In Tokyo they stayed in the hotel at the time that the president was booked there .
 The Symmes did not get to travel in Communist China, although they did visit the port of Kowloon and looked across the “bamboo” curtain, which is, of course, actually an electrified steel fence .
 The Symmes also visited the beautiful port of Hong Kong and stopped off at Hawaii on the way home .
 On their way to Japan they flew to Seattle where they had supper . They flew by night over the Pacific to have breakfast in Tokyo .
 Symmes travel lectures will be still more interesting . We suspect that with the hundreds of pictures they took during their new travels, they will be even more interesting.
 Marshall Symmes made it back to Town Meeting Monday night in time to keep up his record of attendance . In any case, he returned to the Town Meeting to continue his attendance record .

 The Medical Missionaries of Mary announce their annual Christmas Bazaar for Saturday, December 2 . The Bazaar will be held at their Novitiate House .

 “Many accidents and serious traffic delays on # Massachusetts highways during past winters were* caused by cars being stuck in snow or skidding on ice.” “Cars being stuck or skidded on ice’s Massachusetts highways caused by accidents and traffic delays,�
 Much of the trouble encountered by motorists could have been prevented by proper vehicle maintenance, equipment and more thoughtful driver practices, said registrar .
 Good snow tires can provide up to 51 per cent better traction in loosely packed snow and up to 28 per cent improvement on ice than will regular tires if road conditions are not too severe or too steep .
 A car with regular treads travelling 20 MPH on dry pavement can be stopped in 21 feet . A car travelling 20 mph on dry ground can be pulled over in just 21 feet, experts say .
 Use of vehicles only when necessary when snow and ice are on highways or when serious storms are threatened will reduce the hazards of driving .

 Mr Clarence Blake spoke on pewter at the November meeting of the Antique Study Group . Mr Blake was speaking at the meeting in November .
 He started his talk by explaining that pewter is an alloy composed principally of tin with copper, antimony and antimony, bismuth and sometimes lead as the other ingredients .
 Early pewter was manufactured by the English method, comparing it with the American method .
 These are quite different from the large, deep hammer marks of modern pewter . These were quite different to the large and deep hammer mark of modern .
 Mr Blake gave the names and dates of the leading early pewterers of this country . He also gave a list of the names of those who died in 17th century .
 He told members what is rare, what is desired by collectors, what was made before 1825 and what followed .
 Brittannia is a superior grade of pewter and was used for all sorts of household objects . Most of the made after 1825 is made from Brittania . This is the superior grade .
 Marks were explained and again comparisons were made between the English and American . Marks were also explained and were compared to each other .
 Marks help but one with a good knowledge of pewter can recognize a piece as being made by a certain man by telltale characteristics . The piece was made by the same man in the 1930s .
 Any members wishing to do re-search on pewter know what books to read and where they can be found as Mr Blake was, as always, generous with his knowledge .
 Blake brought in pieces from their own collection for the group to see and study at close range . Blake also brought in some pieces from his own collection .
 As Mr Blake was explaining he was showing a piece to illustrate his remarks, he showed a piece of his remarks .
 Brittannia ware offers variety, pleasing design and sound workmanship . Those who can never hope to own a piece of early pewter can be happy in the knowledge .

 Once a backwoodsman boasted that his hound Tige was the best hunting dog in seven counties . The dog was once a hunting hound .
 He said he never went hunting that Tige did not tree a varmint, and that by the way he barked old Tige always told him what the varmint was . He said Tige told him by the time he went hunting he would never go hunting again .
 A newcomer to the settlement, who thought that the old-timer must be stretching the blanket a bit, offered to bet that old Tige could not tell one varmint from another . A newcomer thought that Tige must have been stretching his blanket .
 When they reached the tree and held up their torch, sure enough there was a bobcat . The bobcat was the first bobcat to be seen in the wild .
 The newcomer was ready to pay the wager, but the night was young and old-timer was eager for more hunting . The old-timer was eager to more hunting, but he was ready for more .
 Then suddenly his bark hanged to a long howl that seemed to shake the trees and hills . Then suddenly he howled with a long, high bark that shook the hills .

 Sent by First Class mail, they are sorted and delivered first, and if you include your return address on each envelope, they will he forwarded in the event of a change of address, or if they are undeliverable, it will be returned .
 Only your signature is authorized on cards sent at the 3 cents, unsealed Third Class rate . Also, you can write a personal message on the Christmas cards sent by First Class .
 An extra label carrying the recipients and senders name and address inside every package . Put an extra label around the world inside each package .

 Archie T O’Connell Feted at Testimonial Banquet at Town Line Cafe in Woburn . Friends, relatives and former associates gathered at a testimonial banquet in his honor .
 Tames A Cullen, former chairman of the Board of Selectmen and of the Middlesex County Commissioners, ably filled the important role of toastmaster . The guest of honor was Officer O’Connell’s brother and sister-inlaw, Police Lt. and Mrs.
 Nancy O’Connor is the widow of a retired police officer from Lynn, Massachusetts . The ceremony was held at the Board of Selectmen’s headquarters in Lynn .
 Several speakers paid tribute to the years and quality of Officer O’Connell’s service to the town . The head table guests were introduced .
 Chief Derro, on behalf of the Police Department, presented Officer O’Connell with a purse of money and his own thanks for his cooperation and devotion to duty . O'Connell was the honor guest .
 Officer O’Connell was presented with a gold police badge by the Board of Selectmen . Mr Saltmarsh, on behalf of the town, praised his long and faithful service to the town .
 John Elliott, presented Officer O’Connell with a handsomely engraved Hamilton wrist watch . The gift was the gift of his many associates and friends . John Elliott presented the officer with the gift .
 Among the guests was an old police "buddy" of Officer O'Connell, Benjamin O’Connor, a retired member of the Lynn Police . It is of interest that among the guests at the event was Benjamin O'Connor, an old officer .
 Officer O’Connell, previous to joining the Winchester Department, worked wrth Officer O'Connor in the Metropolitan District Police . O'Connell previously worked with O'Conner in Metropolitan District police .
 Dancing to the tunes of Daniel Noonan of Woburn brought the testimonial to a pleasing close .

 Lynch Junior High School building committee had no trouble at last week’s special town meeting getting the needed funds beyond their original appropriation . A permanent building committee was approved for a permanent permanent building .
 The one voice raised in opposition questioned the building committee’s paying for items such as a wellhrld fence, and tvqyewriters, feeling that by the terms of the original vote to take the land for a school the fence was the School Committee's responsibility .
 The Lynch committee has done a good job, had the school open for business when they said they would, and came out within some two per cent of their appropriation . The school is now in operation .
 We wondered if perhaps a permanent group, selected for their knowledge of building procedures could not have foreseen some of the things that needed adjusting, or additional funds after the school was completed .
 Building a school costing a million and one half dollars is a complicated job, requiring technical knowledge . Few citizens appointed to municipal building committees know how to build a school .
 This is in no sense of a reflection upon the ability or integrity of any Winchester building committee, present or past . Winchester's building committee is not responsible for the decision . This is not a reflection on the integrity of the building committee or its ability .
 Building a school nowadays is a cor.. plicated business, much more so than it used to be . Building a new school is a much more complex business than it was in the days before .
 Up a building in the old days with a solid foundation, good roof and plumbing, and the requisite number of rooms . Your job was pretty much over with. But up a building with a good foundation and a good roof, good plumbing and a requisite room is over .
 You didn’t have to worry about audio-visual aid. Language laboratories, speech rooms, conference rooms, kitchens and other adjuncts of modern education. Worry about audio and visual aids.
 It is possible for a building committee to become so engrossed in some of the features thought desirable by the school authorities that they spend money on side issues which should have gone, so far, for straight construction and necessary furnishings .
 It is the Star's opinion that the Lynch commit tee could have completed this school within its appropriation if it had not been for features sought bv the school committee .
 We do not question the desirability of most of these features, but a good argument can be made for their not being the building committee’s responsibility .
 In discussing the possibility of a permanent building committee with one who lias had considerable experience with school building commit‘ tees, we were told that such a committee might be a good thing .
 Such a committee, we were told, should include an accountant, a lawyer, an engineer and some one acquainted with building procedures and contracts, some one who could talk the language of the architect and contractor . We were told that such a committee should include accountant, lawyer, engineer, lawyer
 Such a committee would take over once the town decides to build anything . The committee would be in charge of the town's development plans .
 Its members might of course make mistakes, hut from their specialized knowledge their mistakes should not be serious, and should grow less as the committee continues to function .
 Building committee members would start with a knowledge of building your average building committee member has to acquire by costly trial and error . Building committee would have to learn a lot from building experts .

 I have read with the greatest interest your excellent editorial on civil defense and the letters of reply . I'm very pleased with your excellent response to your editorial and your excellent letter .
 You are to be commended for having performed an important public .service in your community by creating a public discussion on this issue, which has previously been the subject of one-sided and misleading handouts from the Civil Defense authorities .
 The scientific statements made in your editorial are in the main correct, and the small corrections submitted by Dr. Dr. John Defterios are in fact correct . Dr. Defterios says the scientific statements are correct .
 First, defense against anything but an unimaginably small nuclear attack is not possible . Defense against a nuclear attack would not be possible, experts say .
 The destruction to our economy and social structure would permanently end democratic government . That is, al though some individuals might survive, some individuals may survive . The destruction of our economy would permanently stop democratic government. That is al though though some people might survive .
 False security engendered by the civil defense program materially increases the danger of war . False security is offsetting any potential, marginal protection offered by the program, says author .
 Your readers may by now be tired of numbers in this connection, but the following data, taken from an analysis by Prof. Prof. John Defterios, is a former Air Force Officer of the UK Air Force .
 Gordon S Christiansen, chairman of the Chemistry Department at Connecticut College, may serve as an antidote to the totally unrealistic letter of Mr Boecker .
 The radiation level at the end of the first hour would be 7500 roentgens per hour . In a region remote from the blast and fire area, but in the direct path of the fallout, the radiation level would be more than 7500 per hour. In a remote region
 In any area which for any reason has a higher level, for example being a little closer to one of the explosions, or as a result of a larger attack, there might well be as much as 15,000 roentgens per hour .
 Under these conditions, it would be impossible to come out of the shelter after two weeks . Between the 0th and 12th month, the average level would be 7 roentgens per hour, coming to 3000 per hour . This is very likely a fatal dose .
 Under these conditions, it would be possible to emerge only for very brief periods of say an hour a week for the first six months . Under such conditions, the government would only be able to emerge for an hour-a-week .
 "How one expects society to be rebuilt in the face of all the other obstacles with only that much labor is a mystery to me," says author . "I don't know how society can be rebuilt with that little labor," she says .
 It would be more appropriate for us to ask them the same thing. Perhaps it would be better if we had asked them to tell them the truth .
 Wooden structures out to 18 miles would be flattened before being ignited . Wooden structures would have to be flattened and then ignited .
 These fires would cause a firestorm which would burn until every combustible item in the fire radius was consumed . The firestorm would then burn until all combustible items in a radius were consumed .
 Such a firestorm was caused in Hamburg in World War II by 2.5 kilotons of incendiary bombs . The bombs boiled the water in the canals and glazed the bricks in the buildings .
 Such a firestorm on a very small scale occurred in Los Angeles in the recent brush fire, destroying Dr. Dr. Martin. Martin .
 Libby Libby is a noted nuclear physicist and expert on shelters . Libby's articles on thermonuclear survival are appearing in newspapers throughout the country .
 In this case, the intense heat set fire to the railroad ties which were used to reinforce the shelter .
 Within the firestorm area, almost everyone will die, Tom asphyxiation, carbon monoxide poisoning, or burns, he says . Not to labor the point, it suffices <> say .
 There is no reason whatever to l doubt that, if they wished, the Russians, with their giant rocket boosters, could place in orbit, bombs of much larger size which ould do that much damage without even being brought to earth .
 It is absolutely untrue that the Russians are unable to deliver such weapons in view of their ability to orbit very largo satellites . The Russians are not incapable of delivering such weapons, it is said .
 Even if they could not, one of their trawlers could very easily drop such a weapon into the ocean off our coast, where, when it exploded, it would do almost as much damage to our nearby coastline, and deliver much more radioactivity .
 The above considerations also answer most of the points of your corespondent Mr Brooks .
 He raises the question of treason in addition, however, and this is worth a few words . The question is raised by the president of the United States .
 Brooks thinks that honest differences of opinion are “near treasonable,” I am puzzled as to why he wants to defend this country at all . Brooks' views on differing opinions are ‘near treble-asonable”
 Free speech is one of the things which distinguishes America from Russia. Surely, free speech is a thing which distinguishes us from Russia? Russia .

 There is evidence already that the Administration is making drastic changes in its program and downgrading individual shelters . Other faculty members around the country are republishing the letter with hundreds of additional Signatures .
 I hope all this will give your critics reason to reexamine their position. I hope it will give them reason to rethink their position . I hope this will inspire them to re-evaluate their views.

 Estimates of destruction and deaths depend on the exact nature and extent of a possible attack, and the particular objectives it would be concentrated .
 Also under debate is the effectiveness of shelters, whether they would prove havens of refuge or death traps . Also under question is whether shelters are havens or fiendishly efficient death traps.
 Even the doubtful protection that shelters may provide can be shared by only a small section of the community . Even though shelters can provide, they can't be shared with a small group of people .
 We know that possession of individual shelters is already resulting in un-neighborly and un-Christian attitudes toward our less fortunate friends and neighbors . The shelter is a place for people who are less fortunate to live under shelter .
 In addition, billions of public or private money spent to this end are at best profoundly speculative, quite possibly wasted . In addition to the billions of dollars spent on this end, the money spent on the project is also profoundly speculative .
 We do know that, assuming survival, the world to which we would emerge would be a nightmare of horror, with knee-deep ash, radioactive fallout for an indefinite period, transportation and communication obliterated, buildings reduced to rubble .
 The one thing worthy of intensive thought and action is the development of retaliatory power that can be understood by even Russia (which, I am confident, has been and is being done) Redoubled exertions for negotiations tending toward international disarmament and nuclear control .

 Marcy commenced shooting in 1958 at Brown Lodge Camp near Burlington, Vt., and she took it up with the idea of proving to her parents she could do something well at camp . Marcy took up the shooting as a way to impress her parents and prove she could .
 Last winter she qualified for the Shaker Heights Junior Rifle Team . She began practicing outside of camp . She has been shooting since she was a teenager .
 There she shoots six hours a day, but she is limited to a few hours weekly during the school year . There is no time for her to shoot in the summer .
 Marcy is the only girl on the five-member Shaker Heights rifle team . She was selected by her coach to receive the National Rifle Association medal . The medal was awarded to the best all-around member of the team based on shooting, sportmanship and attitude .
 She gets a lot of support in her shooting from her parents, who follow her to every match possible and shoot every shot .
 Marcy's father taught marksmanship in the infantry during World War II . Her father, a former Winchester High athlete, used to shoot with Marcy frequently .
 Marcy is so fond of shooting that she urges all her friends to give it a whirl, and occasionally her urging backfires . Some of the boys who compete with her find themselves on the short end of the match .

 Since the close of World War II Mr Brown has been in charge of all sales activities of Pilgrim Laundry Co., Boston, most recently as vice president-sales and board member .
 Mr Brown was sales manager of Glendale Farms and Harrington & Co., retail and wholesale milk distributors in the Newark, New Jersey area . Prior to the war years he had been sales manager at Glendale and Harrington .
 While in Newark, he also was editorial contributor and columnist for several trade journals of the dairy industry .
 Mr Brown is widely known in New England for his interest in rocks and minerals . In addition to his business activity, Mr Brown has an interest in minerals .
 This hobby has led him to acquire one of the largest and finest collections of fluorescent minerals in New England .
 His interest in the earth sciences has also led him into putting together a very strong library of earth science material, books and publications . The library is probably the largest in the Ejoston area, outside of the colleges and universities .
 Mr Brown has frequently been a speaker at various meetings and conventions, as well as a contributor to various publications . Both in relation to his business activity and his hobby interests, Mr Brown is a hobbyist .
 He is currently a member of the Advertising Club of Boston, the Boston Sales Executives Club, and the Boston Mineral Club . He is also the president of Boston's Advertising Club .

 Following the panel session, delegates marched to Holy Trinity Church . Following the session, all delegates gathered at Holy Trinity church .

 He is a former Archdiucesan program chairman and Archdiocesan secretary . He has just completed the term of Archdiocese secretary .

 A Winchester man has completed a musical slide rule for scales arid keys in music . The new slide rule has been completed by a Winchester man . It is similar to the orthodox slide rule used for figures in the music industry .
 The musical slide rule was designed for the piano and associated orchestra instruments . Its inventor, Herbert F Rondeau of 57 Thornberry Road, calls it a “scale chart” and says it has been designed for piano .
 Chart scale tells you in just -what key to play with open instruments like the piano, strings and trombone . Simple manipulation of the chart scale will interest you especially, for a simple manipulation .
 Mr Rondeau was born in Cambridge Springs, Pa., and was graduated from high school there .
 He got a Bachelor of Science degree in Physics from Case Institute of Technology . He has spent 24 years in industry .
 He is now an industrial physicist, advanced design engineer and consultant in materials, measurements, analysis and design .
 Mr Rondeau is the holder of three patents, two more applied for and three in process . A relative newcomer to Winchester, he has lived here only 19 months .
 His hobbies are oil painting, theological philosophy and the study of musical engineering .
 Even basic chords or triads which add body and color to a melody are clearly displayed . Even the basic chords and triads are clearly visible .
 Not only are the more common major and minor scales shown but also the less common and perhaps more exotic harmonic and melodic minor scales . The scales are shown in the most common major, minor scales in the world . The most common and most common harmonic and minor scale scales are those shown
 A window displays the sharps or flats in the treble and bass clefs of the musical score that represents a given scale . Also a window displays a window displaying sharps/flats in treble/treble clefs that represent a musical score . A window also displays the
 In such an event the musician must transpose the score to a key other than that played by the piano . In such a transpose, the composer must use a different key to play the score .
 Scale Chart makes this transposition for the three types of wind instruments in a single setting . Scale Chart transposes wind instruments to wind instruments . Scale chart is based on three wind instruments, instruments and instruments .
 A chart is given which correlates the eighty-eight piano keys with the corresponding musical notes on the treble and bass clefs . Also a chart gives a chart showing how the keys are connected to the notes on each of the piano keys .
 The unique display of information will speed up the comprehension of these basic facts of musical knowledge . And it will also help you learn more about your favourite songs .
 This is why music teachers stress the importance of a thorough knowledge of them . Music teachers stress importance of knowledge of these subjects .

 The income from the sale of these stamps goes towards making the life of veterans in the hospital a happier one .

 The December meeting of the College Ulub Art Group will be held at the Boston Muaeum of Fine Arts on Friday, the fifteenth, in the morning of December 15 .
 At 10:15 we shall have the privilege of being’ conducted through the lovely, newly-decorated French Galleries by Miss Morna Crawford of the Museum staff .
 Miss Crawford will show us paintings by many of our favorite artist friends, Cezanne, Matisse, Van Gotfh, Gauguin, and others .
 These painters belong to the group who followed the Impressionists (such as Monet and Renoir), hut because they stressed different emphasis and changed their approach to painting, they became known as the Post-Impressionists .
 We look forward to hearing her again on Friday, December 15th . As she has spoken to the Winchester Art Group many times in past years, it is with happy anticipation .
 The exhibition of “Chinese National Art Treasures” is on view through January 14th . The second important opportunwhich the Museum offers us is to see the outstanding exhibition .
 Since 1949, the Government of the Republic of China has had these words of art stored in subterranian vaults, for safe keeping .
 Chinese paintings, bronzes, porcelains, jades, and other masterpieces of art, never before shown in Western countries . This important collection includes Chinese paintings and bronzes .
 We suggest that after Miss Crawford's talk in the French Galleries our group go down to the lunch room at 11:30 (before the rowds) and afterward meet in the Chinese Exhibition Gallery on the second floor .
 It is the custom of the Museum to have no gallery talks on these large, special exhi bitions . We can go around to gether, even if we do not have a gallery talk .
 Those who are member of the Museum must show their membership cards . Others will be asked to pay the usual small en trance fee .
 This should be one of the most delightful and important meetings of the Art Group . Art Group will meet in New York City on Thursday .

 State Director Wilton Vaugh of the Division of Motorboats announced that the system of the State Registry of Motor Vehicles in requiring owners to re-register their numbers three months in advance will be adopted .
 The law provides that boat registrations expire on the owners' birthdays so that the work of registration will be spread over the entire year and not result in last-minute rushes which require temporary help .
 The State Director recalled that many boat owners obtained registration numbers to correspond with their automobile, telephone, house numbers, college or high school or some other numbers which they covet .
 Late-comers will lose right to reduced $3 fee for renewal and be forced to pay $5 for a new number . They will lose their right to the reduced fee for renewing .
 This will make it necessary for them to repaint at least the bows of their boats and brush on the new numbers or they will have to remove the old plastic or other attached numbers and buy now ones . The new numbers will be required to be painted on the bows or the new ones
