 David Mitchell came home from Thompson Academy to spend Thanksgiving with his parents, Mr and Mrs. Mrs. Mitchell . David Mitchell is a junior at Thompson Academy .
 Thompson Academy is located on an island in Boston Harbor, and up to five years ago used to be called Farm and Trade School .
 More and more are coming to know of this unique school and the good work it is doing . Many will recall this name, and more and more will come to know about it .
 Students to do farm work in addition to the usual classroom activities of any school .
 Each boy has a two to three hour work period, milking cows, feeding chickens, working on the school’s boat, or doing other odd jobs to help defray his tuition .
 The actual cost of board, room and tuition is $1600, but necessary adjustments are made between the parents and the dean of admissions . The cost of boarding, room, and tuition will be adjusted by parents .
 Many of the pupils at the Academy are boys from broken homes, boys with problems but definitely not problem boys . Many of them are boys who have problems but do not have problems, says the Academy .
 The school takes care of needy youngsters, many from large families, as well as boys with problems . The school is based in London, England, and takes in at least six boys a year .
 The Academy is privately endowed and receives help from various charitable organizations . It is privately funded and receives money from various charities .
 Hanscom Field, Bedford, were the means of the 11th Special Forces getting to the proper place at the proper height . The 11st Special Forces were using the field to get to the correct height .
 This particular exercise was directed by Colonel Dona J Lacouture, Operations Officer of the Wing .
 First Parachute Jump by Reserve Army Troops in History, in New England . Team was flown up to New England especially for this exercise .
 The actual parachute jumps were LEAPING FROM an AIRPLANE in FLiGffIT at parachute exercises of the 11th Special Forces .
 Paratroopers of the lltli Special Forces Group made a proficiency jump at Fort Devens . Winchester Parachutists Make First Special Forces Jump . Winchester was well represented on Sunday, November 26 .
 More than 40 Reserve Army Officers and Enlisted Men made a highly successful parachute jump . Led by the Group Commander, Colonel James R Stewart, Jr., and Plans and Training Officer Major Donald C Van Roosen, .
 A freak gust of wind forced a few troopers to land in low trees surrounding the jump field . No injuries were reported .
 The field exercise envisaged a mass drop of especially trained Special Forces troops into enemy held territory . Guerilla fighters had prepared a landing strip or “Drop Zone” in anticipation of the U.S. troops .
 Members of the 11th Special Forces simulated the guerillas as they “secured” the drop zone from “enemy” forces . They made radio contact with the U.S. troops and prepared ground panels and smoke signals for the jumpers .
 The panel signified all was clear, and the smoke indicated the direction and speed of . the ground wind the parachutists would encounter as they neared the ground, so they could take the proper precautions . The panel also indicated the speed and direction of the wind the parachute would encounter
 TrooperB did not carry full equipment down with them, hut hut, hut, once on the ground, they were required to ‘roll up” their ’chutes and assemble at a predesignated point as if they were going right into a problem .
 The elapsed time from plane exit| to finish roll-up was slightly over 15 minutes . In spite of the few cases where the parachutes had to be pulled out of trees, the elapsed time was slightly more than 15 minutes.
 Many observers from Fort Devens, Newspapers and TV Stations were in attendance to witness the historical event . Many relatives of the jumping paratroopers were also present .
 Colonel Stewart indicated that he hoped this success would encourage former paratroopers to apply to the 11th Special Forces for consideration for specialist positions .
 At the Boston Army Base, Section 4 C West, any Tuesday night, there was a team of personnel designated to interview prospective Reservists with a notion to jump and reap bonuses .
 He said that the unit is especially interested in men qualified in Communications, Demolitions and Medical Services .

 This ramp will serve the dual function of eliminating existing five-step store walk-ups and beautifying the building facade . The ramp will be used to eliminate existing five step store walk ups and beautify the building .
 The lower section of the facade will he finished in white stucco, the store fronts in aluminum, glass and redwood panels . The store fronts will be covered in aluminum and glass panels .

 Most people have developed the faculty of looking at church art without seeing it, or thinking about it, says Celia Hubbard . The Winchester Art Association held a meeting in Winchester, England .
 Much of it is a relic of a bygone era, and is used in a random, meaningless manner as decoration, out of step with the art and attitudes of the present day . Much of the artwork is a result of a lack of interest in modern art .
 Much of it is very poor work, bad painting, poor statuary, meaningless carving . Much of the work is "very poor work" and "meaningless carving", says author .
 The ail in many churches would give the idea that religion is very dull, sterile, stereotyped, says Dr. David Cameron .
 Miss Hubbard illustrated her talk with colored slides showing how the architecture, including interior decoration of many new European churches, has succeeded in expressing religious feeling with modern materials .
 Religious symbols are used effectively and singly to emphasize their meaning, rather than scattered all over the church . Religious symbols should be used effectively, singly, to emphasize the meaning of religious symbols .
 Glass is used often as whole walls, with artists designing the colors and patterns in a manner most calculated to create a worshipful atmosphere . Glass is often used as a whole wall or as a wall by artists .
 The Botolph Group, of which Miss Hubbard is the director, continuously influences the churches to use better art, especially more contemporary styles .
 Boston gallery makes available beautiful small religious pieces, instead of gaudy, poor ones .
 All pieces are in good taste, whether jewelry or statuary, wood carvings, paintings, or Christmas cards . All pieces should be in the best taste .

 In 1903 Mr McCormick came back to Boston and became associated with the United Drug Company . He was a bookkeeper and later auditor and treasurer .
 He was detailed by Mr Liggett to arrange for the annual conventions of Rexall dealers in Boston and other large cities . During that time he arranged for the conventions in Boston .
 After a year he was named by Governor Channing Cox to the State’s original Commission on Administration and Finance, serving as comptroller . He served a year in the commission . After that, he was appointed to the original Commission of Administration .
 He remained with the commission for six years . Served under Governor Cox and Governor Fuller .

 He was named temporary treasurer of the town on May 29, 1936 when the then encumbent, Dr. Dr. George W. Johnson, was elected . Dr. Johnson was elected temporary treasurer in 1936 .
 Harrie Y Nutter, became ill, continuing until November 30, that year . Harrie became ill and died at the age of 60 .
 He served in a similar capacity from August 1, 1941, to March 2, 1942, at which time he was elected treasurer . He continued in office until September 30, 1943, continuing in office .
 He served as a selectman in 1937, was a member of the Insurance Committee and a town meeting member for Precinct 5 . He was also a town council member .

 He was also a member of the Algonquin Club of Boston and of the Clover Club . He died at age 81 .

 He asked the winner of the trophy to look upon it as a way of life, as good 25 years from now as now . The winner will be able to win the trophy 25 years after now .
 Any one, he said, living their ilfe with loyalty, team spirit and sincere effort, can not help but succeed . Any one who lives with loyalty and team spirit can succeed, he added .
 Hindes was given an ovation and announced the first winner of the trophy as Tom Mooney . Mooney was given a standing ovation at the end of the match .
 Mooney presented the trophy with its replica replica for the winner to Mooney . Mooney was taken completely by surprise as he was presented with the trophy .
 Dave Thompson spoke of the connection between sports and studies . Thompson said the boy who participates in sports and learns to budget his time often does much better scholastically than one who has no tiring outside interest . Thompson: 'A boy who has a lot of outside interest does better sch
 He said the football player is quite ready to sit down with the books and not seek further diversion .
 He said the only time his studies give him any concern is at the time when he has no other athletic activity . He said only concern is when he does not have any other sports activity .

 Niblock humorously asked to be excused from speaking, saying that the football team had to listen to him at assemblies throughout the year and that he felt they could forego any remarks from him .

 The excellence of their coaching makes my work so much easier, he said, when these junior high candidates come out for the varsity, he added .

 Dr. SOROKIN looks at the differences between the United States and the U.S.R., writes Dr. WILSON SULLIVAN . Among the apparently irreconcilable differences, he says, is the difference between U.N.R. and U
 The tract is startling because it is objective, documented, courageous, and ruthlessly honest . It is an objective and documented document that is brutally honest and objective .
 It is hopeful because it defines a similarity between Russia and America which, once accepted by Moscow and Washington, could provide a reliable, because realistic basis for peace .
 Sorokin’s thesis is that despite ritualistic namecalling and cold war military policies, the differences between the U.S. and the United States.R. are less deep than they seem . Sorokin: The differences between . the . United States and . the United .
 Despite the official ideologies of both countries, practical experience and cold war requirements have forced actual, if officially ‘unrecognizable, changes in both societies . That is to say, despite official ideologies, despite the official ideology, both societies have changed .
 Sorokin shows that both America and Russia have developed economically in directions contrary to their formal ideologies . Sorokin: Both countries have developed in opposite directions in economic terms .
 We have become a highly collective “corporation economy,” characterized by an increasing degree of impersonal regimentation . Actually, we have become an increasingly impersonal economy, writes David Gergen . Gergen: We have a very collective 'corporations economy'
 Sorokin reminds us, none of the directors owns more than 5 per cent of corporate property . Sorokin says they serve more as managers than as owners. Sorokin: 'They serve as managers rather than owners'
 Federal government now controls the largest sector of the economy, Sorokin says . Sorokin: Given increasing military contracts and impetus toward centralized planning to fight two world wars, the Federal government is now controlling the largest economy .
 The government’s control of our allegedly “private” economy makes it decisive . This, plus the proper humanitarian concern for social security and aid to the old, sick, and poor, makes the government's control of the economy decisive .
 Sorokin says it is more properly described as a ‘familistic’ mixed economy . Sorokin: The economy is more like a family-friendly mixed economy. Sorokin said .
 Sorokin points out, also contradicts in practical fact the major dogmas of its ideology . Sorokin: "The ideology of the U.S. government is a contradiction to its ideology" Sorokin says. Sorokin also points out that this contradicts its ideology.
 Russia has moved from its early vision of a classless state and total regimentation to a socio-economic form more like our own . Russia, he says, is moving from its vision of the classless society to a more like ours . Russia is now more like a nation more like
 The Soviet economy today is managed by an economic elite, comparable to ours in number and function . The major difference is their responsibility to the government rather than to shareholders .
 Moscow can afford to permit a larger private sector in its economy . More powerful now, now, and less threatened by civil revolt, Moscow is more powerful than ever .
 Moscow’s recent excursions into such ‘bourgeois’ devices as installment buying support this idea . Moscow has been experimenting with installment-buying devices .
 He believes that the practical requirements of coexistence are narrowing their differences . But he also believes that they are narrowing the differences .
 These narrowing differences, he says, also characterize all fields of thought, e.g. The narrowing differences are also seen in other fields, such as science .
 In the natural sciences, in which East and West scientists increasingly share methods and insights; In the social sciences, we find that bhe Soviets, by opposing our prevailing relativism, are actually cast into a more classical, conservative role .
 Even in religion, Soviet leaders are less totalitarian than they were, even in religion . They oppose Freudianism, and even Frommism for example, as grossly materialistic over-simplifications . Even in religious matters, they are not totalitarian .
 Sorokin says that they actually subsidize the 50-million-member Russian Orthodox church . Sorokin: The church subsidizes the 50 million members of the church .
 Russia’s officially espoused dialectical materialism, and despite our own formal espousal of idealism . All this, of course, is despite Russia's officially espousing dialectial materialism and despite its own formal .
 Sorokin believes the United States and U.S.R. increasingly share each other’s good and bad characteristics . Sorokin says the U.K. and the R.S.-R. share both their good and good characteristics .
 It means that, excluding irrational or stupid commitments to nuclear war, each society may grow into a third type of society serving human needs better than either does now . More hopefully, he adds, it means that each society will grow into an alternative to the current one .

 Adams Terrace Restaurant is the brand new name for Carroll's Restaurant on Winchester Terrace which is under new management . The restaurant is open all day at the time of day .
 The waitresses heretofore associated with the restaurant will remain, but the policy of food service, Mr Adams says, will change .
 From now on, food will be cooked right on the premises and the restaurant will remain open from 7:30m. to £:00m. The restaurant will be closed from 7.30m .
 Mr Adams has served the Government for four years as a dietitian . Mr Adams brings considerable exxperience to his new Winchester restaurant .
 Adams Terrace Restaurant will be more than pleased with the new atmosphere and higher quality food which will be served at the new restaurant . Adams is confident that Winchester people will be happy with the move .
 Mr Adams tells the Star that Grand Opening plans are already formulated . Mr Adams says plans for the Grand Opening are already in place .
 The restaurant is operating a full schedule even as the changes are being introduced . In the meantime, the restaurant is still operating as normal .

 I have received your letter of December 4 in which you conditionally accept my invitation to appear before the House Committee on Ruleu and explain the statements attributed to you in the public press in connection with your recent appearance on a C.B.S. telecast . I have also received
 The Rules Committee of either branch or the joint Rules Commit tee of the General Court, in matters of this nature are held privately in executive session .
 The House Committee on Rules is duty to demand that the member making such allegations explain his position in full and produce evidence he may have, if any, to support his charges .
 The House Committee on Rules must then determine what action it should recommend in its report to the full membership of the House .

 All members of the House, including yourself, have a right to be protected against unwarranted and unjustified remarks and innuendoes, the House Speaker says .
 I'm sure you will agree with me upon reflection that this course of action is in the best interests of all concerned . From your yearjf of service in the House and your knowledge of the legislative process, I am sure you . will agree . with me, I hope .
 You may, of course, avail yourself of the opportunity to be represented by such legal counsel as you desire . You may also avail yourself .
 arrangements will be made for a stenographic report to be taken of the entire hearing .
 "I want to accord you every courtesy in the conduct of the hearing," he writes . "Such safeguards, together with the presence of members of your party on the Committee and in attendance at the hearing, should certainly assuage any doubts, if such existed"
 I have no desire to preside over a kangaroo court, or for that matter a Roman circus for the benefit of the press . I'm not sure if I would preside at such a court, but I would rather be a court for the press rather than a court .
 I can find no compelling reason for altering our traditional policy and holding a public hearing at this time . I can't find a compelling reason to hold such a hearing, he says .
 I have invited you to appear to explain in full the statements attributed to you originally in the Boston Traveler of Friday, December 1st . While I do not as yet have a complete transcript of your remarks, I have respectfully invited you .
 "In all matters of this kind, the public is properly aroused and indignant," says President Obama . "I'm sure the public will be properly aroused," he says .
 Legislation is not necessary in the past, nor does it now justify what can only be regarded as the unwise and precipitous course of legislative action which you have suggested . But this fact does not justify what has been described as 'unwise' and ' precipitous'
 Ample opportunity will exist if you can substantiate your serious charges concerning your fellow legislators, to bring your position to the attention of the public .
 If, at a later point, a public hearing appears warranted on the basis of your testimony at the hearing, such a hearing will, of course, be conducted . A public hearing will be conducted. If such a case appears warranted, it will be held .
 I have no alternative but to extend to you once again an invitation to appear before the House Committee on Rules in the Speaker’s Office on Monday, December 11 .

 Postmaster Thomas J Gilgun said today that every postal employee is digging in harder than ever to insure delivery of all Christmas cards and gift packages before Christmas Day . Apply at WOBURN SENIOR HIGH SCHOOL WE 3-2181 Mail Early For Christmas, 1961 .
 The flood of outgoing Christmas cards and gifts is about equal to the torrents of incoming mail that are getting larger every day .
 A delay of a few hours at this critical time may mean disappointing your friends and loved ones on Christmas Day . A delay could mean disappointing friends or loved ones . A few hours of Christmas Day is critical time for many .
 Post Office windows will be open from 7:30m. to 6m., for your convenience . Post office windows will also be open at 7.30pm to 6 p.m. Post offices will be closed from 730m to 6pm .
 Don't forget to put your name and address on all Christmas card envelopes and package labels . Don’t forget to include the address and the name of the recipient .
 Postmaster urges that you divide your mailings into various groups, with those for most distant places going first . Tying in with the National Improved Mail Service program, the Postmaster says you should mail early in the day .
 Postmaster especially requests that you get your out-of-state packages into the Post Office immediately . Do everything possible to mail all of your Christmas gifts for local delivery by December 16 and your Christmas cards to nearby points by at least a week before Christmas .
 He suggests that you use Air Mail for every Christmas card and gift package going to distant places .
 Postmaster’s important reminders about Christmas mail . Here are a few of the Postmaster's important reminders .
 Be sure to include full name and address, postal zone numbers, and your return address, written or printed clearly on every card and package . Include full name, address and postal zone number .
 Parcels containing delicate gifts must be marked “Fragile’s” Food stuffs are marked ‘Perishable’ if they’re subject to spoilage .

 An exceptionally talented and attractive cast presented this gay and sophisticated play by Samuel Taylor in Metcalf Hall last week .
 U#e raised curtain revealed a beautiful living room set of a home in San Francisco, with a picture window at the back through which one was certain one could see the Golden Gate Bridge .
 This play requires the deft touch of a competent director . Jacqueline Sibley guided her cast with a sure hand to a finished, polished production .
 The Chinese house-boy, Toy, played by Harry Wood, is the Chinese house boy . The show is set to be shown in London on Sunday .
 At the moment he was engaged in opening the wedding gifts which were arriving for the daughter of the house, this being a privilege accorded to him as a loyal family retainer . This being the privilege .
 Mr Wood was delightful in his role; at one moment suggesting the inscrutable Oriental mind with knowledge far beyond that of ordinary people .
 John Sullivan handled his role of the grandfather very well . Sullivan was a crusty old recluse from down the Peninsula who appears only as a matter of form for the wedding, but truly loving his family and wanting above all .
 He it is who sides with her in the momentous decision she makes at the play’s end, and Mr Sullivan showed the two facets of the character skillfully and believably .
 Gary Callahan did a fine job as Roger, the young man who is to marry the daughter of the family . Callahan played Roger in the role .
 One really suffered with him as he tried to keep his girl, and his integrity too . His portrayal of the honest and somewhat unromantic fiance was sensitive .
 The scene in which he ‘tells off’s off the play-boy father of the girl was especially well done . The scene was especially good .
 He was relaxed and charming at all times, and a joy to watch as he manipulated people and situations to further his own cause . He was a joy of watching him manipulate people to further their own cause.
 An accomplished actor was made completely real and sympathetic by this very accomplished actor . One hopes to see more of him in future productions of this play .
 His daughter in the play, the pretty Jessica, was also a pleasure to watch . His daughter, who plays Jessica, also starred in the show .
 As done by Norma Wood, she was gay and happy in her marriage plans, and so pleased to have her long absent father return . When she decides to go with him for a year’s cruise, it is well understood that she will return to marry her nice young man
 Norma has talent and a good stage presence; a young lady who should be seen more often on the stage . Norma is a talented young lady and should be more often seen on stage, says Norma .
 The two other leading players were Billy Ann Maley as the mother, and Cecil Prest as the step-father . Cecil Prest played the stepfather to Billy Ann and Cecil Maley in the film .
 This is a well-matched pair, both gifted with a sixth sense of the theatre . This is the first time the pair have appeared together in a theatre together .
 "They were fun to watch and to listen to, as they reacted to conversation or action from the other actors," she says . "It was a great experience," she adds .
 Maley is lovely to see, her costumes were beautiful, and she moves with grace and assurance . Maley's costume was beautiful and she moved with grace, assurance .
 She handled the difficult role of a happily marnervous apprehension as to what effect his presence will have upon her household . The actress handled the role of being a happily-happened mother .
 Mr Prest offered another of his fine portrayals as Jim, kind, patient and understanding .
 Fhe makes his characters so real and his acting seems so natural that it is a joy to see him . Fhe says he is a 'joy' to see his characters .
 Color coordination was especially noted, as in one scene where the candles in the wall sconces matched the shade of blue in the dress worn by Miss Wood .
 This week’s picture is of the house at Symmes Corner, until recently the home of Mr and Mrs. Marshall Symmedes .
 Originally the house that stood there was built in 1715 by Ebenezer Brooks . The house was built on the site of a house built in the 17th century . It is now owned by a family of four .
 John Brooks’ niece married a French Huguenot, John Le Bosque, who served with distinction as a captain in the revolutionary war, and the John Brooks house came down to them .
 Marshall Symmes acquired the property from the Lc Bosques, including the house and land extending to what is now the South Reservoir . He paid $10,000 for the property, which is now home to what's known as the Reservoir, in 2008 .
 Not having the money, he gave his note for the property and it was not until after the Civil War that he was able to pay off the obligation . After the war, he finally paid off the debt .
 His family lived on what they raised on the farm, buying only flour, salt and sugar . Meanwhile, his family dressed in homespun and lived on the family's homespun .
 Samuel Symmes, a later widely known and universally esteemed citizen, was horn in the old LeBosque house . His brothers, Walter and Frederick, and his sister Anna were also in the house .
 In 1881 Marshall Symmes, finding the old dwelling in poor condition structurally, tore it down and built the house that stands near the location of the old house at a cost of $5,000 . The house was built in 1881 at the expense of a $5
 A part of the old building was moved to the rear of the new dwelling and used as a farm house . The old building has been moved back to the farm house in the village .
 For many years a stone cap covered the well of the old Le Bosque house in the yard of the newer structure . The cap was placed on the well at the site of the new house . The well was covered in the old house's yard .
 Marshall Symmes lived in the new house until he died, and at that time the property went to Samuel and Lawrence . The new house was built in 1926 .
 Samuel or “Sam” as he was known far and near, bought Lawrence’s interest, and the place then went to his son, Russell . Russell, who went there to live in the 40s, brought up his family there and only recently disposed of the place
 A lot of history stems from the old house and its predecessor, the Le Bosque house . The house was built in the 1930s and is now owned by a new owner .
 Marshall Symmes used to graze his sheep in what is now Rangeley . During a terrific snow storm with the snow reaching a depth of 10 feet in spots, he had to go to the animals’ assistance .
 For hospital patients, shut-ins, vacationists, or any one ried woman whose first husband rej w ^° ca rds. For . hospital patients or shut-iners, . vacationists . or any . one . woman's first husband .

 A call for a pioneering regional program to improve the education of school administrators in New England was made last Friday by delegates attending the New England Conference on School Administration in Brookline, Mass.
 The plan offers New England an opportunity to lead the nation in the improvement of school administration and the strengthening of the schools . Finis PL Engleman, former commissioner of education in Connecticut in Connecticut, said the plan offers an opportunity for New England to lead .
 The plan calls for the creation of a permanent regional council of representatives from colleges, state departments of education, school committees, and administrative associations to coordinate and strengthen their programs .
 It will sponsor additional workshops, institutes, and conferences to increase ‘in-service’ educational opportunities of practicing school superintendents and principals . It will seek financial aid to recruit qualified young men into school administration .
 The regional council would operate under the auspices of the New England Board of Higher Education . The board was created by six New states in 1955 to improve and coordinate higher education in the region .
 The education faculties of five New England univrsities grant professional certificates and doctor’s degrees in school administration have agreed on means to assure the training of sufficient numbers of New England school administrators .
 Children’s Theatre School presented three plays at Winchester High School Auditorium . Winchester school children were in for a treat last Friday and Saturday Dec. 1 and 2 .
 The rising of the curtain brought a hush which remained as the capacity crowd of youngsters sat enthralled during the performance . The fact that the treat was appreciated was very much in evidence .
 There was plenty of action for the boys, sweet fairies and elves for the girls . There was a real live black kitten and dazzling costumes and beautiful lighting effects .
 The scenery itself was enough to keep the attention of any imaginative child, painted as it was by the actors .
 In “Heidi,” for instance, the scenes in the hut of the Almuncle (Michael Fiori) were enjoyed for their authenticity . In ‘Heidi’, ‘I’m not just a movie, but a movie of the same
 Real hay was seen in the loft where Heidi (Mary Wadsworth) climbed each night to sleep . "Heidi" was seen with real hay in her loft where she slept .
 Heidi’s playmate, Goat-Peter (Brian MacDonald) captured the hearts of the children in the audience as he expertly handled live goats wheih were imported to lend further atmosphere to the play .
 The beautiful sweeping plumes on Dete’s hat as she swept in to the cozy little hut personified her battle colors as she brusquely prepared to drag Heidi off to a more ordered life in town .
 The acting was perfectly natural and there never was a hint of tenseness as the performers enacted very accurately the well-loved classic .
 Small boys and girls dressed in colorful Swiss peasant costumes danced and yodeled catchylittle tunes between the scenes and even asked the audience to join in, too .
 "A Midsummer Night’s Dream" is a play by Shakespeare . The play is set in New York and London .
 Queen Titania was lovely, graceful and unperturbed as plots were conjured up around her and her colorfully-clad fairies .
 First and Second Fairies (Rebecca Brackett and Kristen Beard) floated on wings of brightly-hued silk among the other little fairies . The fairies floated among other fairies in the colorful silk .
 Teasing, mischievous “Puck” (Geoffrey Brackett) was an imp personified as he darted from regal King Oberon to confer with his fun-bent fellow elves .
 The lighting in this play was truly lovely and kept the illusion of moonlight and shadows throughout . The lighting kept the mysterious illusion of the dark throughout .
 Robinson Crusoe, Ron Marcy, Friday, Henry Dietrich, Capt. Friday and Capt. Henry . The Crusoe and Friday played together in the early 1900s . The team was led by Captain Friday and Captain Friday .
 Songstress CONNIE FRANCIS “Never on Sunday” and Other Themes MGM 3965 . Connie’s Favorite F'olk Songs MGM 3969 .
 Crusoe led them to safety and shelter in his cave, converted from Heidi’s loft bed . Crusoe handled the bad chaps with the none-too-gentle help of Friday, who was obviously enjoying a personal revenge .
 This action was just the thing the audience had hoped to see and it is safe to guess that each youngster envied the actors their ability to portray the characters with such enjoyment .
 Robinson Crusoe was a first-class beachcomber in his beard and ragged clothes and bare feet, with a cutlass at his side . He was a beachcombing in ragged clothing, with bare feet and a ragged beard .
 For realism this little play could not be beaten and the children loved it. For realism it could not have been beaten . For realism, the children love it.
 The cannibals and mutineers ran down the aisles to the stage, giving the little ones in the audience a really big thrill . Excitement was at fever pitch .
 Veronica Sanderson played expertly the happy little tunes for Heidi, the lovely, haunting melody for Midsummer Night's Dream and Robinson Crusoe .

 Winchester boosters of W.G.B.H. educational television station will be delighted to know that the Twentieth Century Fund has given .$125,000 toward the construction of new studios for the firerazed station .
 The new gift brings the total amount of money raised by W.G.B.H. to $550,000 . The gift is the latest in a long line of donations to raise money for the charity .
 Spontaneous projects to aid the stricken station have been organized in just about every community within range of its signal .
 The gift is the first contribution of $100,000 or more to WGBH's Rebuilding Campaign . The gift supplies much needed help in our Rebuilding campaign, said the General Manager .
 The burned studios had been rented by WGBH from M.I.T. which will build for its own purposes on the old site . iThe burned studios were rented by M.T., which will be on the site of its own . i
 Mr Heckseher ’s letter said the grant would be paid by the Twentieth Century Fund after hearing from WGBH that the new studio was ready to begin .

 The final meeting in the ‘Mornings’ series sponsored by the Win Chester Wellesley Club was held in Hadley Hail, Church of the Epiphany, on Thursday, November 80 .
 It was a tribute to Mr Davis that immediately upon his appearance, the shouting and the tumult of the coffee hour died and the entire audience became hushed in eager anticipation .
 Charles T Main, 2nd, president of the Wellesley Club, remarked upon the enormous following which Mr Davis has in this community .
 In his speech Mr Davis emphasized especially the importance of attitudes in these critical times .
 He urged us to examine our attitudes and search diligently for wisdom in our thinking and in our doing .
 The determining factor in the present struggle depends upon what we do and we must be ever mindful that the Russians profit by our mistakes . We must also be mindful that Russia profit from our mistakes. The Russian President Vladimir Putin is not interested in what he says .
 Mr Davis said that we as Americans, find ourselves in an unprecedented state of uncertainty and insecurity which is causing an emotional stir among our people . Mr Davis: We as Americans are in a state of insecurity and insecurity .
 There is a great deal of doubt among civilians as to what should be done . There is also doubt among civilian who want to know what to do .
 There are extremists on both sides and perhaps they cannot be too much blamed because the pressures are so strong . Perhaps they can't be too greatly blamed because of the pressures so strong, says CNN.com's John Defterios .
 It is Mr Davis's belief that w< cannot afford to take a soft stand at the present time .
 He urges that we listen more to the smaller countries and find out what they are thinking and then act in such a way that they will want to come with us rather than with the communists .
 We cannot force them, and here again our attitudes will play so important a part, we cannot force ourselves to do so . We will not be able to change our attitudes, and that attitude will play a part .
 There was an interesting question period following the lecture . Many people remained afterward to talk with Mr Davis .
 This series of morning lectures has been under the chairmanship of Mrs. Mrs. Jacqueline Jones .

 Girl Scout Troop 9 presented the evening program for the monthly meeting of the Friendship Guild in Chid ley Hall, First Congregational Church . Under this plan, students are accepted on the basis of six, rather than the customary eight, semesters of secondary school work .
 Two years ago, the Guild sponsored Troop 9 in order that the girls might enjoy the privilege of holding their weekly meetings in Chidley Hall . The Guild sponsored the girls in order to give them the opportunity to hold weekly meetings .
 Since that time, they h*»ve wished to show their appreciation to the Guild in some special way . Since then, they have wished to thank the Guild .
 Each of the troop’s three patrols took the responsibility for some part of the evening . The troop's program was the result of many weeks of planning, with each of the patrols taking the responsibility .
 Mothers of the scouts were invited as special guests, as was Mrs. lames Stewart, president of the Winchester Council of Girl Scouts . The event was held in Winchester, Winchester .
 The program opened with a flag ceremony, followed by the investiture of a new Girl Scout . A candle lighting ceremony and a court of awards were also held .
 Members and guests were then invited to join in Fireside, a fire was lited, refreshments served, and all enjoyed the girls* singing of many favorite Girl Scout songs .
 Much interest was also shown in a fine table display which included several examples of campcraft skills . Much interest also was shown in the fine table displays .

 He was taken to Winchester Hospital where his disability was diagnosed as a cerebral hemorrhage . He was later diagnosed with a cerebral hemorrhage .
 "There was at no time any question of his complete disability or his inability to further perform his duties as a firefighter," firefighter says .

 The Fortnightly is hopeful that this year’s turnout will he the greatest ever . This is an old tradition which has proved inspiring and uplifting to anyone who has observed it .

 Museum of Science Completes Ten Years at Science Park . Museum is dedicated to people who find in it stimulation, challenge, and enjoyment . Museum's most important thing about a museum is people — young and old — find stimulation .
 Buildings aren’t half as important as people, but they have to come first . Buildings are half as much as people .
 Review of the first ten years at Science Dark looks at the Museum of Science in Boston . Review: The museum's policy and the problem of the museum's lack of transparency .
 More people than any other science museum its size anywhere in the world . Ever since the revolutionary Museum opened its doors a decade ago it has attracted people .
 Boston’s Museum of Science had close to 3,000,000 visitors in its first 10 years . Museum's halls far beyond their planned capacity, forcing the building of its major central unit far ahead of the original development plan .
 In one short decade Boston has seen the Museum achieve more than half its overall plant goal . The Museum's plant goal has been achieved by more than 50 percent .
 Already finished and in business are its East Wing, Planetarium (New England’s first major theatre of the skies), and Auditorium .
 Central Building will double present exhibit and program space, as well as provide a visitors’ restaurant, enlarged library, and offices . Central Building is the seven-story Central Building which will double showrooms, and provide visitors' restaurant .
 By herculean effort, the Museum’s dedicated leaders have raised close $9,000,000 to date . The Museum is raising funds to raise funds for the Museum .
 Their immediate need is to wind up the Central Building Campaign and open up this much-needed area to the public, is $700,000 . The need for $700k to wind-up the campaign and open the area to a wait- ing public .
 It will send thousands of curious, knowledge-seeking youngsters out into the world better able to understand and appreciate its wonders, achievements and needs .

 I objected to erection of a nursing home at the proposed site because a part of the land affected is located in the general residence and light industrial districts, such use being forbidden by the Zoning By-Laws . I parking facilities and also objected to the erection of the proposed nursing home
 Objectors say the operation of Mr Saraco’s salvage business would create noise and smoke which would result in complaints by the nursing home against the operation . The objectors stated that the use of land in the light industrial district could seriously affect the . use of adjacent land .
 They say heavy traffic and trucking on Swanton Street rendered the proposed site undesirable for purposes of a nursing home . They also contend that heavy traffic on the street rendered the site undesirable .
 The Board of Appeal recognized €* the problem posed hv the location of the proposed lot in three zones with the necessity of getting permission to erect the nursing home under the provisions of the Zoning By-law applicable to each .
 A small portion of the land on Loring Avenue some 5,000 sq. ft., behind the part of the lot in the industrial district, is located in the general residence district . The land is located behind a portion of Loring Ave.
 The Board of Appeal may authorize the use of land in general residence for any purpose permitted in a single residence district . Under the Zoning By-law the board of appeal may authorize use of . land in . general residence .
 With permission of the Board land in the single residence district can be used for a convalescent or nursing home . Land in the district can also be used in convalescing or nursing homes .
 The Zoning By-laws permit the use of land in the industrial district for any purpose which may be permitted in single residence, general residence and business districts . The industrial district is located in industrial district .
 Board of Appeal found that if the use of land for a nursing home is permitted in either a general residence or single residence district, such use is permitted also in an industrial district . As a result, the Board of Appeals found that such use was also permitted in industrial districts .
 This reduced the Board to consideration of the land in the light industrial district . The Board was reduced to consideration by consideration of land in light industrial area .
 The Board therefor felt that if the Board permits the proposed use for a nursing home of a portion of the land in question located in the general residence district, the proposal would be permitted by the law . The proposed use of the portion . of the . land in the light industrial district
 This brought the Board to consideration of the question of whether a nursing home is a residence or a business establishment . The Board is considering whether the nursing home should be considered a residence .
 The decision was guided by the Town Building Laws, Section 14 of Division 4, which classifies buildings according to occupance as residence buildings, public buildings, and business buildings .
 The only buildings at all comparable to the proposed nursing home, in the opinion of the Board of Appeal, which are classified as residency buildings are apartment houses, dormitories and hotels .
 It is therefor the Board’s feeling that though nursing homes are not specifically classified, the proposed nursing home falls more logically into the classification which includes hospitals rather than residence buildings .
 This differs from the definition of a rest home where j the purpose is “providing care inj cident to old age to persons over j B0 years of age’s age who are not acute1 Y8 ly ill or in need of medical or nursj jj
 Board unanimously voted to grant appeal from Building Commissioner’s decision and recommended that the permit requested by the petitioner be granted subject to the provision that construction be commenced within three years from the date of issue . Building Commissioner's decision was overturned by the Board .
 The nursing home will be two and one half stories high, of attractive design, fronting on Swanton Street, of first class construction, faced in brick, with an estimated cost of $300,000 .
 It will contain 82 beds and have a staff of 14 or 15 people . It will also have a kitchen and housekeeping staff . The new hospital will be opened in 2015 .
 There will be a parking area for about 14 cars at the front of the building on Swanton Street with a large area at the back and on the easterly side with estimated space for 40 to 50 additional cars . The parking area will be for 14 cars .

 In order to conserve our time and energy and keep our blood pressure within the limit of safety the Star is announcing that in the future stories with which pictures are requested must come to this office, complete with the pictures .
 We find we are wasting too much time trying to match pictures with stories when each comes to us separately . We find it too hard to match photos with stories .
 We feel that it is the obligation of the organization or person who wants the picture and story in the paper to get them together . Not to expect us to keep track of each and get them properly matched, we feel .
 It would be helpful and possibly ensure the desired publication of pictures and stories if those interested in them give us advance notice that they are to come. It would also be helpful to possibly ensure publication of them .

 Advice on the care of animals during the winter months was issued yesterday by Dr. Dr. Andrew Hammond .
 Schnelle: "Both dogs and cats, whether they live in the city or in the country, deserve special thought and care because of the hazards created by winter" Schnelle says . Schnelle said, “Both dogs ... and cats ... deserve special consideration and care"
 Following a heavy snowstorm, it is dangerous to allow dogs to run free, since they are likely to stay within the confines of plowed thoroughfares and thus risk being struck by cars .
 Attention should also be given to the feet of dogs and cats when they contact sanded sidewalks or streets .
 The sand is usually treated with calcium chloride to prevent its freezing and this is irritating to the tender webbing between the toes . This is usually used to prevent the sand from freezing and irritating .
 The pet’s feet should be wiped dry and if very hairy, like that of a cocker spaniel or poodle, washing is advisable . Washing is also recommended for a very hairy dog or a poodle dog .
 Rock salt or other defrosting agents used on sidewalks are also irritating . Rock salt is also very irritating to walkers .
 The three bridesmaids wore similar gowns of champagne peau de soie with matching wide bow head bands . Both dogs and cats can be -allowed outdoors even in extremely cold weather if they are active .

 Nichols died Sunday, December 17, at a nursing home in South Natick after several months of failing health . Nichols, a former widely known resident of Winchester, was a well-known Winchester resident .
 She was in her 94th year and until she entered the nursing home last spring had been a resident of Winchester for more than 60 years . She had been in Winchester, Winchester, since she was 94 years old .
 She was born June 29, 1808, in Dover, N.H., and spent much of her childhood there . Her grandparents' home is now the property of the Society for the Preservation of New England .
 In 1892 she married Nathaniel Marsh Nichols and they lived for a time in Haverhill before moving to Winchester in 1900 . In 1900 she moved to Winchester and moved there with her husband .
 Her late husband, who died Dec., 1947, was for a time custodian of schools in Winchester, later serving on the Board of Public Welfare and for 30 years until his death, as Collector of Taxes . For 30 years, he was Collector of taxes .
 The Nichols' first home after coming to Winchester was on Mystic Avenue . The Nichols moved to Winchester, Winchester, in 1964 .
 Nichols was honored by Governor Samuel W McCall of Massachusetts with a citation for her work in preparing Winchester for bombing during World War I . Nichols was also the first honorary life member of the Winchester Red Cross Chapter for her years of service .
 An honorary life member of the Oval Club in recognition of her many hours of work at the Veterans Hospital in Bedford . She was at one time on the grounds committee and an active worker in other ways for the Winchester Hospital .
 She was one of the charter members of the Winchester Historical Society . She was also a charter member of a Winchester historical society .
 Nichols was vice president of the President’s Club . She was also vice-president of the New England Women's Club . Nichols was an active member of the First Congregational Church .
 She and her husband were active for many years in the Appalachian Mountain Club . She was active in the club .

 Joshua J Vernaglia of 2 Robinson Park, a Boston attorney, died suddenly at his home Wednesday evening, December 13 . He died after a brief illness following a heart attack .
 He had not been troubled previously and his death, entirely unexpected, came a severe shock to his family and friends . Mr Vernaglia was the son of Louis, and Henrietta Vernagalia .
 He was born September 22, 1906, in East Boston, and commenced his schooling there .
 As a boy he moved with his parents to Medford, but he continued in school in Boston . He graduated from Boston English High School . As a teen, he moved to Boston with his family .
 He first practiced with Samuel L Bailen at 73 Tremont Street in Boston . He was admitted to the bar the next year .
 He was associated in practice at the same location with Melvin Breath, former mayor of Chelsea, and his brother, Frank Breath . Later he was associated with Melvin and Frank Breath in practice .
 At the time of his death he had his own offices at 73 Tremont Street, Boston, Boston .
 Associated with him were William Foley of Boston and James Cassidy of Dorchester . Associated with them were William J Foley and James F Cassidy of Boston .
 He was a member of the Massachusetts Bar Association, a member and former director of the Winchester Boat Club . He was also a director and member of a Sons of Italy in Medford and of the Eastern Association of Lawyers .
 He came to Winchester eight years ago from Medford, building the house in which he lived at the corner of Cambridge Street and Robinson Park . He moved to Winchester 8 years ago and now lives in the city .
 On November 11, 1940, Mr Vernaglia married Hazel E Mulkerin of Medford, principal of the Center and Wait Schools in Medford .
 She survives with a son, Joshua J Vernaglia, Jr., of Winchester . She also has two brothers, Dr. Dr. and two brothers .

 The Giants kicker was bumped by an Eagles player trying to block his punt . The hump was an infraction of the rules, and was immediately called by the official nearest to the play .
 The end result was that instead of the Giants losing the hall and some mure of their waning morale, they got the hall hack, a lo-vard advance on the penalty and an all-important first down .
 From this unexpected good fortune, the rejuvenated Giants proceeded to move steadily down field for the game-winning touchdown . The Giants went on to score a touchdown in the first quarter .

 From 1928 when she joined the club, she served continuously on nearly all the committees, often as chairman, Antiques . From the year 1928 she joined, she joined nearly all of the committees .
 American Home, Conservation (in which she >vas particularly interested and was five times on the State Conservation Committee), Literature, Nominating, and others .
 She was also several times chairman of Pilgrimages, for she was very fond of adventuring and visiting historical places .
 She was one of The Fortnightly's most loyal and faithful workers . Always willing and tireless in many activities, she was tireless .
 A tree will be planted in her memory at the Memorial Forest of the Massachusetts State Federation of Womens’ Clubs .

 No fancy formula is necessary or any particular pill, or even a dramatic rearrangement of customary meals . Instead, you can find a way to get a healthy start to the day .
 All that is needed is a little thought, and some understanding of facts that can be lifesaving . Facts that cun guide a whole family to better health .
 Every day every generation needs body-building protein, vitamins minerals . We know that every day, every generation, needs bodybuilding protein and vitamins .
 Every part of the body at every age can flourish only if properly nourished . Bones, teeth, muscles skin, skin, eyes and eyes, eyes, blood vessels, all part of body can flourish if nourished, says Dr. Andrew Keen .
 To be sure, growing youngsters must have more of the essential nutri ents than oldsters, but this should present no problem . Growing youngsters need more of these essential nutrsents .
 A child’s normally big appetite guarantees him enough of his requirements, so long as the daily meals guarantee him and all the family a good variety of wholesome foods . A large appetite guarantees a child's full appetite .
 By the mid-twenties it’s time to stop, look, and listen, to count the calories and cut the size of servings . By the middle of the 20s it's time to look at the calories in your diet .
 This decade may mark the height of youth, but nevertheless calorie needs are decreasing, and they continue to diminish with the passing years . This decade's youth may be the peak of youth but calorie intake is decreasing .
 Grandparents in middle years may appear as spry and vigorous as ever, but energy requirements are 10 to 30 per cent less than those of their 40-year-old children .
 Restaurants should cooperate by serving grandparent portions as well as children’s meals . Grandparent portions should be served in restaurants, not just for children .
 Of all the hazards contributing to heart disease one of the most serious is overweight . The Massachusetts Heart Association has pointed out .
 Weight watching is one of the best possible ways to build health and guard against heart disease . Weight watching can be a great way to protect your heart health .
 Parents who set a meal-time example of pru dence are helping themselves to health and bequeathing a priceless gift to their children .
 Good food habits firmly established in childhood and wisely followed throughout adulthood pay big dividers . Good food habit pays big dividents, says author .
 Stuffing may be fine for poultry, but its poison for people, young and old alike . Stuffing is fine for birds, but it can be deadly for people who eat it .
 “saturated” fats are found in some dairy products and in meats . “Saturated’ fats, such as those found in dairy and meats, may need special attention . Fats, too, should be taken to account for the health of the body .
 All of the facts aren’t in yet, it may be that diets rich in saturated fats may not be desirable for all . This may be especially for those who may be prone to heart disease .
 Even the arteries of teenagers can show changes, and these have been attributed to unhealthy food habits . Even teenagers can see changes in their arteries, according to experts .
 By some substitution of skim milk for whole, of fish and chicken for meat, and more use of vegetable oils and margarines . More use of margarine and vegetable oils .
 By inclusion of a variety of fruits and vegetables, and enough whole grain or enriched bread and cereals to satisfy everyone’s needs, you can satisfy all your needs . This is a healthy way to get around the world .
 By discriminating resistance to desserts, desserts can be found in the U.S. desserts .

 Star Market Co. named Leonard C R Langer treasurer . New England supermarket chain named Langer at annual meeting . Langer was elected treasurer at Star Market's annual meeting Monday .
 Langer will also serve as chief financial officer of the company . Stephen P Mugar, president, stated that Mr Langer . Mr Mugar has been named the president of the firm .
 During his teaching career Mr Langer acted as consultant to numerous government and industrial organizations, including General Electric, I.B.M., and Bell Telephone Co. During his . career he acted as a consultant to many government and . industrial organizations including General . Electric .
 In the fall of 1961 he returned from a 15-month tour as Visiting Professor of Finance at IMEDE in Lausanne, Switzerland . He also conducted studies of European corporate financial management and the organization of the Euro pean capital markets .
 Star Market Co. operates 30 super markets and two home center stores in Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Maine and New Hampshire . The company has two home centers and 30 supermarkets .
 For the fiscal year ended September 30, the Company reported record sales of $86,000,000 . For the previous period, sales were 11 per cent higher than the previous year .
 Star recently announced plans to acquire Brigham’s-Dorothy Muriel's, Inc., a chain of 74 ice cream, confectionery and bakery stores in the Greater Boston area .
 Oc curs is a sort of human miracle when peace and goodwill, love and friendship prevail . Here, for a season, oc curs a season of a human miracle .
 Christmas carols fill the air, and waning friendships reach for renewed contacts . Curt nods give way to friendly greetings; selfish pursuits yield to friendly thoughts and remembrances .
 June is full of feelings of human brotherhood which is the essential spirit of Christianity . June is of sunshine and the balmy breath of roses .
 The universal joy of Christmas is indeed wonderful . And — praise be! — perennial. And, praise be, perennial.
 You cannot cut Christmas out of the calendar, nor out the heart of mankind, says author . You can't cut Christmas from the calendar or from the heart, he says .
 Peace, joy, faith, love, home, hope and cheer are words we all can understand . Peace and joy are peace, joy and home, home and cheer . Peace is peace and joy, love and home are words that we all understand .
 Human antennae must be permanently attuned, as they briefly are at Christmas, to things of the spirit, as opposed to things selfish and material . The answer is, of course it could, but to accomplish it must be permanent attuned .
 It may even be that, little by little, the world moves in that direction . The world is moving in that way, and it may be that it's happening .
 The whole of mankind has burst forth with a revolution of rising expectations among the under-developed, and with a deeper concern for the underprivileged, wherever they may be .
 Let church bells ring, carols roll over the wide earth, Christmas trees be lighted and Christmas stockings hung, children chortle over presents, friends renew old contacts, and families gather together in loyalty and love . Let the world ring with bells ringing and carols rolling over
 Let this uneasy world find its faltering way, slowly but surely, toward Peace. And, last but not least, let this uneasy . world find their faltering . way . toward Peace .

 Five grade school boys from California, Michigan, Oklahoma and Wisconsin are winners of national championships in the “Punt, Pass and Kick” youngsters throughout the United States .
 P & K."" contest was launched this year by the Ford Division of Ford Motor Company and its dealers, in cooperation with the National Football League . The contest is a collaboration between the NFL and Ford dealers .
 The winners, their fathers and the Ford dealers who sponsored them will embark late this month on an expense-paid ‘Tour of Champions’ The event includes an official reception at the White House in Washington, D. C., and a trip to the National Football League’s
 The five champions will reeevie trophies and autographed footballs . They will be introduced to a nationwide television audience during half-time ceremonies at the NFL title game .
 The young champions posted the best total scores for punting, passing and place-kicking distance and accuracy in final competition . 85 other boys who qualified for the championship round were also in the competition .
 The 70 finalists were regional winners . They vie for national honors in half t ime competition at a selected NoI VTinber game of each of the NFL’s 14 teams .
 Contest scoring was based on distance and accuracy, with one point for each foot the hall traveled in the air, minus one point the ball landed to the right or left of a center line .
 The 56 pound, 50 inch tall youngster won by a comfortable margin in the final competition . He performed at the half-time of selected NFL games throughout the country during November .
 Parents, participants and sponsors alike endorsed the program strongly . Parents and sponsors of the program have also endorsed it .
 Forty-one years ago, four members of the executive committee of the National Tuberculosis Association put their hands in their respective pockets and brought out $100 .
 The NTA added $100 to the pot and the sum of $500 was turned over to Dr. Dr. John Sutter . Dr. Sutter was awarded $500 by the NTA .
 He was able to complete his lifelong study of lung anatomy . He was then able to write the book which is still the standard reference text .
 The first grant was made under TB Christmas Seal sponsorship . That was the first grant to aid research made under the sponsorship . It was made in response to the Christmas Seal .
 The next year, 1921, the NTA’S research program had a budget of $20,000 and made four grants . The NTA's research program was budgeted for four grants that year .
 In the forty years since, the organization has appropriated about $3,700,000 for research grants . In the past 40 years, the foundation has received about $4,000 .
 Scientific research is man’s puny but valiant attempt to find what makes the world of nature tick . Scientific research aims to find out what makes nature tick.
 Each apparent advance leads into a new maze. J0SEPHS0N Real Estate i* WALTER Y J0 SEPHS 0N INSURANCE J i dec""-3t ^ e*i«w ; ■* trim m\.m t*im
 For instance, TB doctors know that TB germs can be knocked out very handily by some drugs, in a test tube . For example, some drugs can be used to knock out germs in tests .
 TB is only one problem among thousands that must be solved if TB is ever to be finally licked . But they are only one of thousands of problems that must have been solved if it is ever licked.
 In most diseases, antibodies prevent a I second attack if the person be1 comes infected again . In most cases, these antibodies prevent the person being infected with the disease .

 Employees at AMPEX Stereophonic Soi will receive an annual profitsharing bonus from a company which totals $180,000 this year .
 Distribution is made solely on the basis of length of service with the company . The distribution is made based on the fact that the company has a history of distributing its products .
 Each employee with more than one year of service is tfiven one unit and an additional ten per cent for each successive full year of . service . Each employee is given an additional 10 per cent of service for each year .

 Since its charter was issued in Columbus, Ohio, in May, more than 15,000 have joined . Most of these members are buttonholing their friends to join and support it .
 No effort has been made to put a major public relations push behind the program . Outside of half a dozen test advertisements in widely scattered weeklies, and an advertisement in the Toledo Blade, there has been no effort .
 Growth has derived largely from volunteer speakers at meetings of unions and civic organizations . Growth has come largely from volunteers at unions, civic groups .
 Goal of SIXTY NOW is to amend Social Security to permit retirement at 60, with benefits of $200 a month, plus $100 for each dependent of any age . Goal of 60 is to allow retirement at age 60 with $200 benefits a month .
 Advertisements, speakers and advocates argue that at surh a benefit level, at least five million working Americans would promptly retire . They say that much or all of this retirement would result in immediate job openings for six or seven millions who are unemployed or only partially employed .
 The average benefit under Social Security is less than $80.00, and the majority of those who retire under the law actually draw much less .
 They see in their plan a “shot in the arm” for the economy, with millions retired on a spendable income . Millions employed at full wages to replace them, and the market enlarged as u consequence .
 Most of the 15,000 members have conn* from the Toledo area . The daily mail brings new applicants from all over the country, with 20 states now represented .

 All the patients in our Veterans Hospitals in Massachusetts will benefit and Christmas will he a lot brighter for many of the patients, as gifts will be distributed to them by the Dept, of Mass. The Dept. of Massachusetts .

 Old Sturbridge Village is offering a special winter tour schedule for elementary and high school groups . It has been announced by Miss Elizabeth Hitz, director of the School Admissions office .
 Two hour tours will be conducted Monday through Friday with visits to Village homes, shops and craft areas . Starting January 15, 19G2 will offer tours of Village homes and shops .
 The program will include demonstrations of fireplace cooking, candlemaking, spinning, weaving and printing .
 Students will actually participate in these tivities under this learn-by-doing program . Students will be able to participate in this program .
 During the past year more than 35,000 school pupils visited the Village in organized class groups . The Village is based in the village of Buryury, in the north of London .
 Reservations are necessary for the tours and may be made through the School Admissions Office, Old Sturbridge Village .

 An automobile driven by Richard E Conrad of 10 Jason Street, Arlington, went out of control and hit a car parked on Highland Avenue . The accident occurred on Christmas Day, about 9:41 m.m.
 Conrad lost control of his car when he hit a patch of ice or snow, police say . Conrad was returning to Arlington when he lost control, he told police . Conrad told police he was returning from Arlington to Arlington .
 Before it actually stopped snowing some time through Sunday night snow estimated by the street clearing crews as about 16 inches deep had blanketed the town .
 Town Engineer Wakefield told the Star he and his workers bad estimated the storm as good for about eight or nine inches . Wakefield said he anticipated no real trouble with the storm . Town engineer said he and workers estimate the storm will only get a few inches of rain .
 The storm commenced during Saturday night, but by 1:00 o’clock Sunday morning the storm did not seem too bad . By noontime Sunday Sunday the worst of the storm seemed over .
 By late afternoon the storm seemed definitely over, and there was nothing in the weather reports available to the town that warned of what impended . During the afternoon the snow increased, but by late afternoon, it seemed to be over .
 Town workers were eager to get home for Christmas Eve, and there seemed no reason for further snow removal at that time . Town workers said they were eager for a good night's sleep .
 The storm, however, was far from over, and by late evening it was snowing hard . By late evening, it had snowed hard .
 Tired plowing crews were called back to work at 3 o’clock Monday morning . Plowing crews had to return to work after a long night of sleep .
 The snow was wet in the middle and hard to handle where it had drifted, though the wind was not as bad as Winchester has often experienced in the past . The storm is expected to last for several days .
 Crews had main streets open by 7 o’clock Monday morning, but it was much later in the day before some of the side streets were plowed .
 Cars left on the street all night all night made the work of men doubly difficult . The work of police officers was difficult to do .
 In some places cars were left in the middle of the road, making it impossible for the plows to get into the streets . The plows were unable to get in the streets because of the snowfall .
 Winchester Mother on Way Home For Holidays Fatally Injured As Truck Rams Car Mrs. Mrs. Smith . Smith was on her way home from work when she was hit by the truck .
 Mary Virginia Laurenti of Williamsville, N. Y., was on her way to Winchester for Christmas with her husband and their two young children . Her car was rammed by a heavy truck on the Massachusetts Turnpike in Hopkinton .
 News of the accident during the pre-Christmas season came as a deep shock to the entire community . The accident happened during the early Christmas season .
 Mrs. Laurenti, the former Virginia Loftus, accompanied by her husband, Jeremiah E., their son Eugene Arthur, 6; and daughter Marguerite Ann, 3; were driving from their home in Williamsville, a suburb of Buffalo, to spend Christmas .
 Laurenti stopped her car in the safety lane of the highway so that her husband could clear the windshield of ice . Laurenti, who was driving, was driving when she was hit by the ice storm .
 Mr Laurenti had just finished and had re-entered the car when it was rammed by a heavy truck . Gaspare Drago, 27, of Malden, was also involved in the crash .
 After the impact the car rolled down an embankment, followed by the truck . After the crash, the truck rolled down the embankments . The driver was killed in the crash .
 Police arrested the driver on charges of manslaughter and driving to endanger . The driver was charged with manslaughter and reckless driving .
 Laurenti was pronounced dead when she arrived at the Framingham Union Hospital and it is believed that her death was instantaneous . Laurenti's death is believed to have been instantaneous .
 Both children were critically injured and their names were placed upon the hospital danger list . Both children are now in critical condition in hospital .
 Mr Laurenti was unconscious for about two hours after the accident but his injuries were not diagnosed as serious .
 The Laurentis lived in Winchester until last September when Mr Laurenti was transferred from Boston to Buffalo . He was transferred to the Buffalo office of the firm with which he is associated .
 Mr Chadwick repeated his statement reported in last week’s Star that the time for finger-pointing and hand-wringing had passed . He said the sensational nature of the T.V. film linking Boston police to known bookie joints had accomplished its primary objective of
 Mr Chadwick made his remarks at the regular Thursday meeting of the Winchester Rotary Club . The speech was generally considered as one of the most forceful speeches he has made .

 Both men were taken in the ambulance to Winchester Hospital, Winchester . Mr Derro was treated by Dr. David Derro at Winchester Hospital .
 Winchester firefighters washed down the Highland Avenue Englewood Road area of gas spilled in the accident . Winchester firemen were called in on a stand-by basis by the Melrose Fire Department in Thursday morning’s 6:45 o’clock fire .
 1961 was an extraordinary year in Winchester, with more than the Town’s customary share of controversy, sorrow, high honors, politics, and community activity . 1961 was a year of honor and sorrow for the Town .
 Maribcl Vinson Owen and her two figure-skating daughters died in an airline crash on February 15 . The mother-of-two was killed along with her two daughters in the crash .
 "It was a shock from which not one of us has yet fully recovered and one that will always be with us," says the family . "Not one of them has ever fully recovered from the shock," says father-of-one .
 Police Chief Joseph J Derro urged this week that everyone driving over the New 5 ear s week end observe the most absolute caution, lest through careless driving, they take their own life .
 The Chief’s warning came in the wake of the tragic Thanksgiving Day accident at Symmes Corner . Two teenagers were killed when they lost control of their car and rammed into a wall .
 The Chief has placed the tangled wreckage of the car on the lawn in front of the abandoned Wadleigh School as a dramatic reminder to young people not to speed while driving .

 Army Engineer Division, New England has awarded a contract to the architect-engineer firm of Alonzo B Reed, Inc. of Boston to carry out the first phase of the National Public Fallout Shelter Survey in many Massachusetts communities .
 Surveys by the Alonzo B Reed concern under this contract are to be curried on in Arlington, Bedford, Lexington, Medford, Somerville and Winchester . Surveyors will curry on surveys in six cities .
 Those communities which are not included in this first phase will he included in later phases . Those communities will be included in future phases .
 It is anticipated that ail communities will he surveyed and acceptable shelters marked by June 1962 .
 Survey calls for locating public shelters which will accommodate a minimum of 50 people . The shelters will be located in public shelters that will accommodate at least 50 persons .

 Cape designed by the Wills’ firm is comprised of the basic form and practical interiors of the early American houses combined with a plan which allows the flexibility and yet the privacy of modern day living .
 It has warmth and charm so necessary to make a house a living expression of our way of life . Above all, it has the warmth and charming so necessary .
 The living, dining and multiuse rooms are grouped around the kitchen, all opening directly onto a living terrace and swimming pool area through sliding glass panels . The plan is arranged with the living, . dining, multiuse and living rooms grouped around a kitchen .
 The bedroom wing is separated from the rest of the house, yet is accessible without passing through any other room . It is located in a separate part of the property which is accessible from the other side .

 El Citl El Cid, a $10,000,000 film production portraying the life of the Spanish warrior lord, is now playing at the Astor Theatre in Boston . Year Of Honor And Controversy, a film based on the Spanish death of El Cido, is
 To appreciate and enjoy this movie it is essential to understand the historical events which were taking place in Spain in the eleventh century . The movie is based on historical events in Spain which occurred in the 11th century .
 During the same period in history, independently ruled Spanish kingdoms were emerging and this led to civil war . This led to jealousies, greed and suspicion of one another .
 Christian kingdoms were attempting to wrest their counLiy from the Moslem caliphs . The Christian kingdoms joined with various Moslem kingdom against one another .
 It was into this confusing and conflicting period of history that the Cid was born . The Cid is born into a confusing period of confusion and conflicting history .
 Rodrigo Diaz of the town of Viva r, north of Burgos, Spain, was a title bestowed on Rodrigo Diaz . Cid is a word from the Arabic Seid meaning leader-a warrior with the wisdom to be just and merciful .
 He was destined to be Spain’s epic hero and his deeds, factual and legendary alike alike, were first to be heralded throughout Spain by troubadours . His deeds were later to be recorded in Spain's first important literary work Poema del Cid .
 Rodrigo’s life story, portrayed by Charles Heston with Sophia Loren as his wife, Chimene, recreates, in the greater part of the film, those events which have taken place prior to those preserved in the Poema .
 Essential to most Hollywood pro ductions today is the love element, and thus the central theme, is the dedication of Rodrigo Diaz to his responsibilities for all others around him, for his family .
 "The movie is authentic in every aspect once w'e realize it is not a portrayal of the epic Poema del Cid," says director .
 For a realistic and veridical vista of Spain in the Middle Ages, its moral code, customs, dress and architecture the three hour-plus saga is considered worthwhile .
