 Mrs. Virginia Loftus Laurenti of 36 Hetzell Road, Williamsville, N.Y., wife of Jeremiah Eugene Laurenti and daughter of Mrs. Jeremiah Eugene. Laurenti . She was born in New York City .
 Arthur W Loftus of Ginn Road, was fatally injured Wednesday night, December 20, when her automobile was rammed by a heavy truck on the Massachusetts Turnpike in Hopkinton . The driver of the truck was killed .
 She and her husband and their two children, Eugene Arthur, 0; and Marguerite Ann, 3; were on their way to Winchester to spend the holidays with Mrs. Mrs. Martha's family . She and Mrs. Arthur and their children were traveling to Winchester .
 Laurenti, who was driving, had stoppe'd her car in the safety lane of the highway so that her husband could clear the windshield of ice . Laurenti's husband had to clear the ice from the windshield .
 The Laurenti car rolled down an embankment after the crash followed by the truck . Laurenti rolled down the embankments after the accident .
 The operator of the truck was arrested on charges of manslaughter and driving to endanger . The operator was arrested after the accident . The driver was charged with manslaughter .
 Laurenti was pronounced dead upon her arrival at the Framingham Union Hospital . Laurenti died at the hospital .
 The children were critically injured their names being placed on the danger list . The children's names were placed on a danger list after the incident .
 Mr Laurenti was unconscious for two hours after the accident . He was not believed to be seriously injured though he was unconscious .
 She grew up in Winchester, attending the Winchester schools . She graduated from Win Chester High School in the class of 1940 . She was a member of the Class of 1940 class .
 Laurenti en tered the Boston City Hospital training school for nurses, from which she was graduated with her R.N. in 1944 . Laurenti was born in 1946 .
 She later served on the staff of the Winchester Hos pital, for the most part as a nurse in the operating room . She later worked at the hospital in Winchester .
 In addition to her professional interest, she worked actively in aid of the hospital as a member of the W inton Club and Friends of the Winchester Hospital .
 Her entire life aside from her care of her home and family was devoted to the bet terment of the hospital . She was dedicated to caring for the hospital patients .
 She and her husband were married September 6, 1952, and lived in Winchester until they moved to Williamsville, N. Y., last September . They were married in 1952 and have been together since then .
 Besides her husband and children, her mother is a retired remedial speech teacher in the Boston public schools .
 Frank Knight of 55 Mystic Valley Parkway, died suddenly in her sleep Friday morning, Dec., at her daughter’s home at the age of 97 . Frank H Knight died of a sudden, sudden death .
 She had been in her usual health the day previous and was looking forward to the arrival of family guests for Christmas .
 She was born Apr., 1864, in Port Elgin, N.B., where she grew up and was married to John Lamb who was for many years principal of the high school there .
 Mr Lamb died in 1941, but his widow continued to keep her home in Port Elgin . She had made her home with her daughter in Winchester for several years .
 She was a staunch member and very active in the work of the Trinity United Church of Port Elgin . Her hospitable home was always open for church, civic and social affairs .
 In complete possession of her faculties to the end, she was fond of TV and kept informed of current events . She kept informed on current events and TV .

 Dean Wheatley, 67, of Linden Lane, Sherborn, died in Sherborn . Former Winchester Athlete died at the age of 67 . Wheatley was an Olympic gold medalist .
 Sherborn, general manager of the International Purchasing Company of Wellesley, died suddenly at his home Friday, December 22, following a heart attack . Sherborn was a former football star at Winchester High School .
 Wheatley had been bothered by a heart ailment, which it is believed had been with him for some time . Wheatley spent November abroad and upon his return he had returned to England .
 Mr Wheatley was bom in Halifax, N S. f . He came to Winchester as a boy and lived with his family at 22 Park Avenue . He was born in Halifax .
 He entered Winchester High School with the class of 1913, and as a freshman made the school football team . His sturdy physique and great speed made him an effective line plunger in the old days when fullbacks were used exclusively to buck the line .
 A severe knee injury, which later prevented military service, forced him out of the backfield in his sophomore year . He finished his football career as a tackle . The injury prevented him from doing military service .
 He was also a member of the school track and relay teams, and of the old Phi Delta Society .
 The death of his father caused Mr Wheatley to leave high school in the middle of his junior year . The family moved to a farm in Ashland, Oregon, after the death .
 Mr Wheatley was associated with International Purchasing Co. of Wellesley for 40 years . He was a director and general manager of the firm at the time of his death .
 A noted horseman and a former New England field hunting champion, he was former secretary and whip of the Millwood Hunt .
 He rode with both the Myopia Hunt and the Quonset Hunt in Rhode Island, where he was field master . He was also a member of the Norfolk Hunt and rode with several other hunts .
 Mr Wheatley leaves his wife, Charlotte, a granddaughter of the late war-time Governor Samuel Walker McCall, and Mrs. Mrs. Wheatley .

 U.S. Army Chemical Section stands ready to give fallout predictions if it ever becomes necessary . First United States Army Information Headquarters announced this week . Chemical section is ready to predict fallout predictions .
 The Radiological Center is located in Radiological Division of the Chemical Section . It is the most important part of the First Army Headquarters .
 First Army’s Radiological Center personnel will take one look at wind patterns plotted on their Fallout Prediction Map and be able to tell accurately which area will receive the fallout . The wind patterns will be plotted on the Fallout Prediction map .
 For example, if a detonation of megaton size should occur in Albany, N. Y., on a given day with the winds from the west, fallout in the next fight could be expected over the Fort I meet an even more deadly enemy devens-Boston complex in eastern
 Rad Center would notify Civil Defense and post commanders throughout the area . Immediately the j sure which way the winds blow in Rad Center, the area would be notified .
 All posts within First Army area would bring their fallout maps up to date . At the same time all posts within the First . Army area will bring their . fallout maps .
 Private First Class Marilyn J Brown, 19, of Brazil, Indiana; Master Sergeant Albert Pough, Jr., 34, of Detroit, Michigan, and Sergeant First Class Clarence Hungerford, 38, of Bridgeport, Conn. The other three victims were identified as Sergeant First Sgt. First
 Pough, a paratrooper and veteran of ten battles in Korea, makes the overlays for the Fallout Prediction Map . Pough is a veteran of 10 battles in the Korean War .
 Wellversed in the art of fighting as holder of the First Don Black Belt for karate, Pough understands that order to provide accurate warning to all citizens in the affected area .
 Sergeant Hungerford is a veteran of the invasion at Anzio, Italy, and four other campaigns before being wounded near Mount Belvedere, Italy . Assisting him is Sgt Hungerford, who was wounded in the battle .
 Radiation Sealer is the operation of a radiation sealer . Radiation sealer is one of the daily tasks of the radiation sealers .
 This information is then indicated on the Radiological Background Count Chart located above the machine . The background count is indicated on a Radiological background count chart . This information can be used to help identify a patient .

 The mechanism is power driven and automatic in action, and it includes a track by which the clips are fed into position for the crimping operation .
 Prior mechanisms of the foregoing type have had the disadvantage that a different crimping head and crimp feeding track have been necessary when substituting one size clip for another .
 The changing of the crimping head and feed track is time consuming, increases labor costs, and involves added expense for equipment . Changing of the head and track is a time consuming process .
 This is accomplished by adjusting a special cam, preferably with four faces, that is mounted rutatably in a dot in the plunger which, by its motions, causes the ( limping jaws to move into or away from their crimping position . The cam is mounted in a
 The invention is made for a clip feeding track that is capable of accomodating up to four or more different sizes of clips without the necessity of changing the track when the clip size is changed . As another feature of the invention, provision is made .

 Surely every one is fervently hoping that the coming year will he a happy one, tor us individually and for the strife ridden world .
 We can start toward making the world happier by genuinely trying to be happier ourselves in our relations with each other . We need to try to make ourselves happier by trying to make our relations happier .
 When we say “Happy New Year” we can mean it, and we can try to live through the year in the spirit that prompted the greeting . We can also try to remember the spirit of the New Year .
 Among our friends are many whose new year isn’t likely to he happy unless we do something to help make it so . Among them are many who are not likely to be happy if we help them .
 Wishing these friends a “Happy New Year” can be just a mockery, if that is as far as our effort goes in their behalf . Wishing them a ‘Happy New Years’ can be a mockery .
 Most of us must depend on our relationships with others for our happiness anyhow . Most people depend on their relationships with other people for their happiness, says CNN.com's Robin Williams .
 Few of us are so all sufficient as to find satisfaction wholly within ourselves . Few are more satisfied with themselves than they are with others .
 We can all help to make the world happier and better by actually living our New Years greeting through the entire year, by doing what we can to make those with whom we come in contact happier .
 Life is a cooperative venture and those who arc most cooperative, who are most tolerant, friendly and who give most of themselves to others arc the happiest . Those who are tolerant, tolerant and friendly are most likely to be the happiest people .

 Nancy Atkinson and Greta Hawley were dealt a hand in a recent rubber bridge game . The pair dealt a number of interesting hands that developed during the evening's play .
 The bidding was of minor importance and the final contract was 0 spades by south . The bid was not a big deal and the contract was signed by the south .
 The opening lead is the heart king — before reading further, see if you can spot the correct line of play . Check out the opening lead in the opening play .
 North A K Q x x V None ♦ 10 xx A A K xxxxx Xxxxx . West East A J 10 x Ax V Xxx V xxxxx ♦ K J x ♦ xxxx A xx A Q J 10 . South A A xxxxx V Q J
 The opening heart lead is ruffed in dummy, the club ace is cashed and the club king is  cashed . Declarer discards a heart — declarer discarding a heart . The club ace and club king are cashed in dummy .
 A small club is led, ruffed by the declarer and a spade is led to the dummy . A spade leads a small club, ruffing by the Declarer, and a club ruffles by the player .
 The west hand has 2 spades, the dummy with one and the east hand with none . This leaves the west hand with two spades . This, of course, leaves the dummy and the dummy .
 An established club is played and declarer’s last heart is discarded . Now, an established club has played and declared its last heart .
 The west hand can ruff if he cares to, but no return he makes can hurt the declarer . All of his diamonds are thrown on the established clubs - all of them are thrown in .

 Robert W MacArthur of 42 Cabot Street, is serving aboard the icebreaker, USS Burton Island, which smashed a path through Antarctic ice four to eight feet thick to open McMurdo Sound to sea traffic a month earlier than had ever been done before .

 Norman Buchbinder of Newton Centre appointed vice chairman of the Metropolitan Division of the 1962 Campaign of the Combined Jewish Philanthropies of Greater Boston .
 He will have personal responsibility for the CJP fund-raising efforts in Winchester as well as several other communities .
 Sumner Redstone is Chairman of the 1962 Metropolitan Division, which has responsibility for raising funds in this appeal in close to 40 suburban communities in the metropolitan area .
 In making the announcement, Mr Redstone said “we are delighted to have Mr Buchbinder head this important area of our 1062 campaign.”
 "His past record of dynamic leadership in many civic causes lends a great deal of stature to the significance of these Divisions," he said .
 Mr Buchbinder is a vice-president and a member of the Board of Trustees of Allied Research Laboratories, Ine., a scientific company engaged in research for government and industry . He is also a vice president of the board of trustees .
 In I960 he served as Advance Gifts Co-Chairman for Newton in the Districts Division . He served in I960 for Newton .
 He is treasurer of the Brotherhood of Temple Mishkan Tefila . He has served as financial secretary of the financial secretary .
 Mr Buchbinder is also a member of the Board of Directors of Hebrew Teachers College Associates . He has served as a teacher in the past .
 He has served as treasurer and president of Newton-East Little League . He has also served as president and treasurer .
 Immediate permanent position includes clerical duties, five-day week . The position is described as "temporary" and "temporarily"
 One is the driver’s view, as he grips the steering wheel, hits the brakes, and experiences that helpless, hopeless feeling of riding a vehicle out of control, skidding relentlessly toward the inevitable crash . Another is the view of the driver's view .
 The other is the scientist’s view, characterized by years of research and analysis carried on by the Committee on Winter Driving Hazards of the National Safety Council .
 Chief Derro discusses what scientists have learned and what we in turn can learn from them . He also discusses what we have learned from the prob lem .
 Winter braking distances on winter surfaces are from three to 12 times as great as on dry pavement . Braving distances are three to twelve times greater on winter pavement . Skid tests have been carried out under all types of winter driving conditions .
 The most slippery surface of all is moist ice, at or near the melting point . moist ice is the most slippery ice surface in the world .
 So he careful on glare ice when temperatures are around 30 degrees above zero . He is careful to avoid glare ice in the winter .
 Contrary to popular belief, traction on winter surfaces is not improved by letting air out of the tires . Instead, let air out is not better traction on the surface of winter surfaces, it's better traction .
 Light, compact cars tend to slightly outperform heavier vehicles in braking on ice . However, larger cars display belter ‘cornering’ ability .
 In stopping ability, which might also be called “accident preventability,” reinforced tire chains were again proved superior . In stopping . ability, they might also call ‘accident preventionability’
 On loosely packed snow braking distances for regular tires averaged 60 feet, for snow tires 52 feet, and for reinforced tire chains 38 feet . The braking distance is 60 feet .
 Smooth tires (should not be used), regular tires, winterized tires, snow tires, mud-snow tires, tires with embedded metail coils with serpentine ribs, sunders, regular tire chains, reinforced tire chains . Smooth tires should be used .
 They advise against traveling unnecessarily during very severe snow or ice conditions . They declare it vital for those who elect to go to he equipped with adequate traction .
 Pushing the brakes lightly instead of tramping down heavily on slippery pavement . Steering in the direction of a skid to recover from it .

 We do not deny that a large percentage of current TV fare is vapid, some of it definitely objectionable . Much of the show is a sheer waste of time, and much of it is a waste of money, we say .
 People do have time to waste, and with the ever-shortening work week, a great many people are presently going to have a lot more of it . But people do have to waste. We're not wasting time, but we're wasting it.

 Company “C” of the 319th Engineer Battalion held their last meeting of the year last Wednesday night at the Sons of Italy Hall on Swanton Street . Company C’s Last Meeting of the Year was held at the hall on Wednesday .
 The regular meeting consists of two hours of drill on military procedure . The meeting is a two-hour long drill session .
 Captain Donald V Gearan, Commander of the Company, announced that he and his staff were holding a Christmas party after the scheduled drill .
 Captain Gearan also thanked the entire company, officers and men for the splendid record the company had achieved . The ship was the first to carry out a full crew of men .
 He expressed his thanks to the Sons of Italy for their cooperation throughout the year . At the same time, he said he was grateful for the support of the Italian community .
